PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987/88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australia Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesmanlike leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Assets Test: Family Farm
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That family farming and small business assets are unsuitable for inclusion in the assets test for Austudy, Assistance for Isolated Children and other education allowances.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm and the assets of other small businesses from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Assistance for Isolated Children and other education allowances.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke-free International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii) call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (IACO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by IACO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

LOCAL GOVERNMENT (FINANCIAL
ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1991
The Bill relates to Local Government funding arrangements and has four main objectives. In brief it:
(a) gives effect to the Special Premiers' Conference decision to untie local roads funds and pay these via general purpose grants;
(b) rectifies the unintended consequence for Local Government arising from the transfer of the Debits Tax base to the States and Territories from 1 January 1991;

(c) provides the Treasurer with a discretion to set general purpose assistance to Local Government at a level consistent with the underlying growth in general revenue assistance to the States and so avoid the need for frequent amendments to the Act; and
(d) provides for the movement in general purpose assistance to Local Government to be directly linked to the movement in general revenue assistance to the States and the Northern Territory.
The Bill also makes minor procedural and technical changes to the Act and deletes obsolete provisions.

In respect of local roads funds, the Special Premiers' Conference of October 1990 decided that funds for local roads would be untied and paid to Local Governments, or to State Governments where they are responsible for local roads, via general purpose grants. The decision indicated that funds would be paid at the same real level as at present.

Following consultations with Local Government and the States, the Government has agreed on the means by which it will give effect to the Special Premiers' Conference decision. It will introduce interim arrangements for 1991-92 under which:

(a) local roads funds would be untied and the bulk of funds currently provided for local roads under the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988 will be provided as general purpose assistance under the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986

(b) an additional $296.lm in base funding for councils will be provided under the latter Act in the 1991/92 financial year. This figure represents an adjustment of 1990/91 funding levels for inflation with funds to be further adjusted in 1991/92 and subsequent years in line with existing general purpose grants.

(c) existing State distributions will be maintained and inter council distributions will be in accordance with relevant principles currently operative under the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988. Of the additional $296.lm in base funding, $272.7m relates to funds that will be provided to councils using a formula based on population and road length and $23.4m relates to funds that will be provided to councils on the basis of an assessment of special works needs; and
(d) in the case of monies allocated to both Local Government and the States, the former local roads funds would be separately identified within general purpose assistance.
The interim arrangements will provide a period of stability while consultations proceed with Local Government and the States on the detailed arrangements to apply in 1992-93 and beyond.

The Government expects to decide on the longer term arrangements by the end of 1991 following further consultations with Local Government and the States and following consideration of a wide range of options.

Mr President, at this point I would want to stress that the arrangement we are proposing in relation to local road funding have been developed with the full co-operation, assistance and advice of Local Government through the Australian Local Government Association. I would want to place on record the Minister for Local Government's appreciation of this Local Government contribution and to note that it is a practical reflection of the aspirations for a more effective partnership between the Commonwealth and Local Government that both spheres of government are seeking to achieve.
The second major objective of the Bill is to adjust the funding formula in the Act to account for the transfer of the Debits Tax base to the States and Territories with effect from 1 January 1991.

The reduction in general revenue assistance to the States to compensate for the transfer of the Debits Tax Base would have, under the current funding formula, the effect of reducing general purpose grants to Local Government. The Bill provides for the effect of the transfer to be disregarded in 1990/91 when calculating Local Government funding entitlements. In the absence of any remedial action, the consequential reduction in general purpose grant entitlements for Local Government would be $9.1 million in 1990/91 and $21.8 million in 1991/92.

The need for legislative changes to the Act to accommodate changes in funding arrangements with the States highlights the need for more flexible provisions to be included in the legislation to cover contingencies of this type.
The current formula allows the Government no flexibility to vary the level of payments to Local Government as a result of changes to the basis on which payments to the States are made.

Such changes have been required in each of the previous two years-in 1988/89, because identified health grants were discontinued and, in 1989/90, because of the transfer of payments under the State Governments' Loan Council program to the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, and now a further change is necessary in respect of the Debits Tax base. The Special Premiers' Conference reforms could also require further changes.

The third major objective of the Bill therefore is to provide the Treasurer with the discretion to set the level of general purpose assistance to Local Government at a level consistent with the underlying growth in general purpose payments to the States. This is the outcome intended under the existing funding formula.
The Treasurer would be able to make adjustments to reflect changes in the classification of payments or in the distribution of expenditure responsibilities and revenue powers to the States.

The Treasurer would consult the Minister for Local Government in making the determination of the funding adjustment factor and the Bill requires that a copy of the determination is to be delivered to State and Northern Territory Treasurers, including an explanation of the use of any discretion. The Minister for Local Government would of course ensure that Local Government was also advised of any changes.

The fourth and final major objective of the Bill is to extend to Local Government the same commitment announced by the Treasurer at the June 1990 Premiers' Conference that general revenue assistance to the States be maintained in real terms for the next three years, that is, 1991/92 to 1993/94. That commitment was conditional upon its not applying if Australia were to experience a major deterioration in its economic circumstances.

Existing arrangements under the Act effectively provide Local Government with close to a real terms guarantee with approximately 97 per cent of the funding formula linked to the level of general revenue assistance to the States. However, general purpose capital payments which currently comprise the balance of the funding formula have been nominally fixed in recent years.

The Bill therefore proposes that a new set of comparable grants for the States, including the Northern Territory, be defined for the purpose of calculating the factor by which Local Government grants change. The Bill makes provision for the movement in general purpose assistance to Local Government to be directly Linked to the movement in general revenue assistance to the States and Northern Territory.
This move would greatly simplify the funding arrangements with Local Government and provide greater certainty in funding for the next three years.
The financial impact of the changes proposed in the Bill are relatively minor.

As already outlined, establishing a direct link between the movement in general purpose assistance to Local Government and the movement in general revenue assistance to the States and the Northern Territory will effectively provide Local Government with a real terms funding guarantee for the next 3 years. The estimated cost of this move is $0.9m in 1991/92 and S1.9m in 1992/93. This results primarily from the removal from the funding formula of the non-indexed general purpose capital assistance payments.
Mr President, the changes that we are proposing will simplify the administration of the legislation and will provide benefits for Local Government.
They reflect the importance which this Government attaches to the role of Local Government in our Federal system of government.

They are another measure in a long list of measures which successive Hawke Governments have taken to strengthen the capacity and raise the status of Local Government. They are measures which, when combined with the very positive developments that are continuing to occur in Local Government in a wide range of areas can only lead to a better Local Government in this country.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
AUSTRALIAN WOOL REALISATION
COMMISSION BILL 1991
There are 9 Bills in this package of wool industry legislation.

The Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991, establishes the Australian Wool Realisation Commission (AWRC). The Commission will take over the $2.7 billion debt and 4.7 million bale stockpile presently held by the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC), and be responsible for the discharge of the debt and disposal of the stockpile and other assets. The Commission will cease when the debt is discharged. This Bill also repeals the Wool Marketing Act 1987.
The Australian Wool Corporation Bill 1991, will establish the new Australian Wool Corporation which will be responsible for wool promotion and facilitation of marketing, including quality control.

The Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development (Amendment) Bill 1991 makes a number of changes to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 which are necessary to allow the creation of the Wool Research and Development Corporation by regulation under that Act. The Australian Wool Research and Development Corporation (AWRDC), will be responsible for investigating and allocating priorities to research and development projects. It will also be responsible for funding projects and subsequently monitoring and evaluating them.

The Primary Industries Councils Bill 1991 provides for primary industries councils to be established by regulation for various industries. This will then enable the creation of the Australian Wool Industry Council, which will provide advice to the Minister and the industry on the overall strategic directions of the wool industry.
The Wool Tax Amendment Bills (No's 1-5) 1991 provide for the setting of the Wool Tax at a rate of 15%.

Mr President, the existing legislation concerning arrangements for the marketing of Australian wool, the Wool Marketing Act 1987, commenced on 1 July 1987. That legislation was enacted to govern the operations of the Australian Wool Corporation and the Reserve Price Scheme among other things. It is well known to the Senate that for many and varied reasons, pressures on the Reserve Price Scheme became too great and the Scheme became unsustainable.

In 1987, wool was re-emerging as Australia's leading rural export industry and contributed almost $4 billion to our balance of payments. The Reserve Price Scheme (RPS) had been operating effectively for 13 years, and wool had a strong position in the world textile market.

As has been explained to the Senate in detail on several occasions over the past twelve months, the demise of the RPS has been brought about by an unprecedented combination of factors, some were at work even before the 1987 legislation was introduced and some were totally unpredictable.
With the floating of the exchange rates, the RPS was no longer able to stabilise prices simultaneously for both growers and buyers.

In the mid 1980's wool was cheap in terms of buyer currencies and demand was high. Ill-conceived optimism led to a change in the role of the Minimum Reserve Price (MRP) from that of a ``safety net'' to that of an instrument to chase up the market. The then Wool corporation lifted the MRP by 71% over 2 years on the basis of a corporation and grower assumption that a ``new price plateau'' had arrived. The value of the $A rose, our wool was less attractive and the high MRP encouraged supply. More recently, unprecedented political changes occurred in the USSR, Eastern Europe and China, which led to a substantial decline in purchases of our wool.

Last year the Government, after considering industry proposals, subsequently made a number of decisions including increasing the wool tax from 8% to 18% and then to 25%, lowering the MRP from 870 to 700 cents a kilogram, removing the ceiling on AWC borrowings and guaranteeing those borrowings, enabling the Wool Corporation to establish a Flock Reduction Scheme, and also considered the introduction of marketing quotas. The Government also set up the Vines Committee of Inquiry into the wool industry and the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council.

Despite efforts by industry to introduce measures to curb supply and efforts to provide enough confidence in the market to boost demand, backed strongly by Government, it was clear by early this year that the RPS had collapsed. With the spiralling level of debt and market forecasts at the time, the AWC announced on 1 February that auction sales were to be deferred. The Government subsequently suspended the RPS until at least 1 July 1991.

Since February, interim marketing arrangements have provided for the continuation of auction sales without the RPS, pending the determination of future institutional and marketing arrangements. During this period the Supplementary Payments Scheme has been in operation.

It is now a new era. The recriminations and disappointments of the past eighteen months should remain in the past and all efforts and energy should be devoted to building a revitalised and sustainable industry.

There has been considerable effort put into determining the wool selling arrangements to apply from 1 July 1991. Numerous submissions were made to, and taken up by the Vines Inquiry, extensive consultations with various sectoral interests in the wool industry have taken place and numerous reports and proposals about how to handle the problem have been received. All have been carefully considered.

The Government has decided on the structures appropriate to take us into the next century. Some of the details in the reports received focus on operational details or strategic directions which Government considers can be best addressed by the proposed new Corporations. When they are in place, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will recommend to each of the Boards that these issues, including many of the matters in the Vines Report, be specifically addressed.

Mr President, the issues facing the wool industry can be divided into those which require strategies over the longer term and those which are more immediate, although they are of course not mutually exclusive.

The longer term issues relate to the share of wool in the world textiles market and the most appropriate industry structure and institutional arrangements to support a sustainable and viable wool industry. To address those issues the Government has taken decisions setting up the new AWC and a separate Wool Research &Development Corporation which are covered in this package of legislation.
It is now more important than ever that the industry thinks creatively about its future and determines new possibilities for boosting demand for wool to ensure its long term viability.

Wool's share in the world fibre market is declining but the rate of decline is misleading because of the large and growing markets in industrial, home and medical textile products for which wool is quite unsuitable. When you take account of those uses for which wool is suitable, it retains a very important market share, especially in the premium sectors.

Promotion, quality assurance and control and research and development, are all essential in the endeavour to sell more wool and improve returns to the industry. Under the proposed package of legislation the new Australian Wool Corporation will have a facilitating role in the areas of promotion, marketing and quality control.
It will oversight the activities of the International Wool Secretariat and have a major role in influencing the policies and strategies the IWS adopts.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will be recommending to the Board of the new AWC that it closely considers the recommendations of the Vines Committee relating to the governance and management of the IWS to ensure that the IWS gives Australian woolgrowers the best possible value for their promotion dollar.

To date the wool promotion strategy has been to concentrate on top end quality markets to support a price premium over other fibres. It is only lately that the industry is putting more effort into increasing the volume of wool sold into the apparel and non-apparel wool markets. This involves rethinking promotion strategies and resource allocation. For example, the role of blends and the opportunities offered by branding, are now beginning to receive close scrutiny.

The new Australian Wool Corporation will set quality standards for wool and ensure those standards are met. In conjunction with this, the Corporation will have the power to prohibit the sale for export of wool which does not meet the quality standards set by the Corporation and also order the withdrawal from sale for export wool that does not meet the standards. Substantial penalties for offences will apply. The Corporation will be working closely with industry regarding efforts to lift the quality of Australia's woolclip.

Part of the creative thinking to be done by the industry will include better production methods and the adoption of new technologies to improve the efficiency of wool marketing. An obvious means to achieve a high degree of efficiency is to ensure that commercial activities, to the maximum extent possible, take place in the private sector.

The new Australian Wool Corporation will be required to adopt the role of a catalyst in facilitating activities in the market including the increased acceptance by the private sector of responsibility for marketing. The full implementation of sale by description is one such area where this could occur. Another is for increasing responsibility for quality control to be placed with industry participants. Both have moved along the track in recent years, but much more needs to be achieved and the pace of reform speeded up. The structure of the new Corporation means that it will be well placed to ensure this occurs.
The development and application of new technological innovations in the industry will be the responsibility of the new Wool Research and Development Corporation.

The new Australian Wool Industry Council (AWIC) will form the primary focus for the co-ordination of all aspects of wool industry policy. As a properly constituted policy and co-ordination body for the industry it will replace the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council which has been in operation since September last year.

The AWIC is a consultative body, which will not override the other corporations. It will be a source of advice to the Minister and the industry and will provide a forum within which the various sectoral bodies can discuss matters of overall industry significance. It will, either on its own initiative, or at the Minister's direction, examine matters affecting the interests of the wool industry and propose overall strategic directions for the industry.

The Wool Industry Council will be required to review the corporate plans of the Corporation, the Commission and the Research and Development Corporation and provide advice to the Minister. It will also be required to hold industry strategic review conferences every 3 years. The Council itself, will be required to meet at least once every three months and there will be monthly meetings of the Chairperson of the Council and Chairpersons of the other three wool statutory authorities.

The Industry Council will be required to provide leadership for the industry in a balanced and well informed manner. It has been set up so that the broad range of wool industry interests are represented and well informed decisions affecting the long term interests of the industry can be made by industry itself and by government. This arrangement can only benefit all those participating in the wool industry.

Mr President, the significant issues facing the wool industry in the short term are the $2.7 billion debt and the 4.7 million bale stockpile. Also of concern is the rate of tax to apply in coming years and the ability of growers to pay it. This package puts in place measures to deal with these issues.

A balance has had to be found between the national interest objectives of debt management and the health of the industry on one hand, and the management of the debt and stockpile and consequent financial burden on growers on the other. It is this balance that the Government has sought in its recent decisions.

The management of the debt and stockpile is central to recovery from the present crisis in the wool industry. As the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has stated on a number of occasions, the Government has taken the decision that responsibility for the debt and stockpile must remain with industry. Any further capitalisation of debt would delay recovery.

The industry is confronted with a series of balancing acts. The elimination of the debt versus the level of tax we can reasonably expect growers to be able to afford; the use of the stockpile as an asset to reduce the debt versus the potential to adversely affect market prices for wool; the immediate sale of non-wool assets of the AWC versus the realities of the current property market are all factors in the equation.
The Government has had to make decisions which are in the best interests of both present and future woolgrowers, processors, merchants, and all Australian tax-payers.

To make our balancing act even more difficult, none of us is able to predict with any degree of certainty what the future holds. Our projections can essentially be regarded as best guesses only, albeit guesses based on past knowledge and detailed analysis.
We have decided that a debt repayment program is the best way to address the debt and stockpile, because of its flexibility and the elimination of any possible increase to the debt.

A debt repayment program which allows the stockpile manager to meet debt targets with the best mix of property asset and wool sales is more robust and better able to adjust to market circumstances than other mechanisms considered by Government.

Disposal of wool from the stockpile will need to be managed carefully. The Wool Realisation Commission will be required to maximise the value of each of its sales. The announcement of an annual debt reduction target, together with a known rate of tax, will enable the market to make an estimate of the sales required from the stockpile to meet the target. The Commission will not be a mystery player. Its annual bottom line is already public.

If, at the end of the repayment period and discharge of the debt, there is a surplus, this surplus is to be redistributed in a way which best benefits woolgrowers. The actual mechanisms for that redistribution will be worked out co-operatively at the time. The guidelines for the AWRC will provide for that to happen.

Mr President, the question of what is an appropriate tax rate, and in particular what is the rate that growers can afford, is critical. If the rate is too high there is a risk that the viability of the industry could be placed in jeopardy. Alternatively if it is too low, Australian tax-payers will be required to assume part of the debt on behalf of the industry and the stockpile will remain overhanging the market.

The Government has announced a rate of 15%. A number of proposals for other tax rates, which include to a greater or lesser extent assumptions about the complex or currently uncertain issues of the starting debt, production, markets and price, have been put to the Government. These proposals have been examined. However the one thing they have in common is that they increase the risk bourne by the Government on behalf of the tax-payer, when the Government is already considerably exposed as a result of the wool industry debt.

On current estimates any wool tax under 15% incurs additional risk for both wool growers and the Government in the event of a market downturn. Such a downturn would require either an increase in the wool tax or the sale of more wool from the stockpile. Both would reduce returns to growers. The only responsible approach for Government and industry is to adopt a wool tax rate that is both prudent and sustainable.
The 15% tax rate is integral to the package adopted by the Government and the government does not intend to resile from it.

The Government accepts that a 15% wool tax means that significant numbers of specialist wool growers will have no farm cash operating surplus in 1991/92. However that would be the case whether one were to adopt 12% or 15%. In practice the effect of the difference on farm cash operating surplus for the average grower is in the order of hundreds of dollars, not thousands.

The hard reality is that the Government is not looking to preserve each and every person in the sheep industry who was there at the 870 and 700c/kg floor prices. There have been many new entrants in recent years taking advantage of the high prices. It follows that some woolgrowers must leave the industry irrespective of any action by the Government.

The Government has announced significant increases in the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS), which will assist these woolgrowers. Commonwealth funding for RAS has increased from its current level of $64m to up to $160m in 1991/92. Commonwealth funding could be increased further up to $240m in the next year should conditions so warrant. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is still negotiating with the states over the application of these funds.

The Government's decision on wool tax also reflects its decision that responsibility for the debt will remain with the industry and the 15% reflects in part the requirement to rely principally on the wool tax to service the debt.
In recognition of the position woolgrowers face in the first year, the Government will facilitate a $200m interest free loan and has required the debt to be reduced by only $20m in 1991/92.

Under the new legislation, the tax will be apportioned three ways between the AWC, the AWRC and the R &D Corporation. Each year the AWC, the AWRC and the R &D Corporation, will recommend the appropriate level of tax for their requirements. Those recommendations will be taken into consideration in prescribing the rate of tax under the regulations.

Mr President, this Bill provides the institutional framework to address the debt management and stockpile issues through establishing the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. On the day of commencement, the assets and liabilities of the Australian Wool Corporation, with the exception of the R &D and promotion reserves, will be transferred to the Commission.

The objective of the Commission will be to manage and eliminate the debt and stockpile in a manner that is in the best interests of the nation and woolgrowers in particular. The Commission will be required to acquit the debt within 7 years or less and will itself cease to exist upon the sale or transfer of all assets and repayment of the debt.

The Commission will have the flexibility to determine the timing and combination of asset sales and stockpile sales that can best achieve the debt reduction schedule. In the first two years it is expected that the Commission will negotiate the sale of most of the non-wool assets including warehouses and wool stores. Wool House in Melbourne will be transferred to the Commission, but it is anticipated that it will continue to be the office premises for the Commission, the Corporation and the Research and Development Corporation.

The Commission will have operational flexibility in managing releases from the stockpile, but will be subject to a set of Ministerial Guidelines to be formulated between the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Minister for Finance and the Treasurer.

The Commission will regularly publish figures on the stock sales achieved, the quantity remaining in the stockpile and the balance of the Stockpile Fund. Operators in the market will therefore have up to date knowledge of the levels of stocks held and the amount of debt remaining to be paid off, as well as likely income of the Commission through asset sales and tax levies.

The Commission will also have a discrete task in the management and wind up of the Supplementary Payments Scheme. As that Scheme is presently being funded by the Market Support Fund it is most appropriate, with the transfer of the Fund to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, that the Commission see the Scheme through to completion.

This Bill provides that the Commission will be required to develop and update annually, a 5 year rolling Corporate Plan which will be prepared after consultation with industry. The Plan will be reviewed annually to ensure that the strategy for management of the debt and stockpile remains relevant, and protects the interests of all participants in the industry and those of the Commonwealth.

An annual Operational Plan will also be required and will be regularly reviewed. As part of this process, the Commission will be required to report annually to the industry on the results of the year's trading.

The Board of the Wool Realisation Commission is to be made up of a part-time Chairperson and 8 other Members. These Members will comprise the Managing Director of the AWRC, the Managing Director or another Board Member (other than the Chairperson) of the new AWC, and five Members with experience in designated fields of activity. In the case of the Commission the emphasis will be on financial and business expertise as well as commodity trading, storage and distribution, property management and woolgrowing. Two Members of the Board will have experience in woolgrowing. As well, there will be a Government Member.
These arrangements place greater emphasis on a broad base of expertise and experience among Board Members so that the wider interests of the industry can be taken into account in decision making.

The first Board, with the exception of the Managing Director, will be directly appointed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, after receiving advice from a selection committee which the Minister has already established. This committee has the same form as that provided for in the legislation.

The Minister has established this selection process in advance of the legislation to enable the Boards of the Commission and the two Corporations to operate from 1 July 1991. This committee is well into its task and Honourable Senators will be aware that Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has already announced the appointment of Mr David Clarke as the Chairperson designate of the Commission.

Provision is made in the Bill for Selection Committee arrangements relating to subsequent appointments to the Board. Each selection committee will comprise 7 members, a Presiding Member appointed by the Minister, plus 6 other persons appointed by the Minister, three of whom are to be appointed after consultation with Wool council. It is the Minister's intention that the Chairperson for the AWRC will be one of the Minister's nominations for the Committee making selections for the AWRC Board.

The Selection Committee arrangements for all Statutory Marketing Authorities (SMAs) are under review in the context of the Government's decisions on the Davis Report's recommendations on Statutory Marketing Authorities. The role of Annual General Meetings of SMA's are being reviewed and this may have an impact on the way wool industry representatives are nominated to selection committees. Government will assess the implications of this for the wool industry selection committee arrangements at that time. The proposed arrangements in this Bill will remain until then.

The Bill also provides that the staff of the current AWC who transfer to any of the three new organisations will preserve their rights and entitlements throughout the transitional period. The revised institutional structure will present many challenges for the staff who transfer to one or other of the new organisations. It will be with their cooperation and support that much of the success of the new arrangements will rest.
It is vital that the expertise and experience of the professional staff of the AWC is retained. The mistakes of the past cannot be laid at the feet of the staff, many of whom counselled against them.

Mr President, the Government is now putting in place new institutional arrangements which will take the industry into the next century. The short and the long term issues have been addressed and appropriate arrangements decided. It is up to all individuals and organisations interested in the future of the industry to get behind these arrangements and make them work. The Government is heartened by the response from industry to date, and we are sure that with the right decisions by the new organisations the wool industry will recover to regain its place as Australia's premier rural industry.
I commend this Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
AUSTRALIAN WOOL CORPORATION BILL 1991
This Bill establishes the new Australian Wool Corporation (AWC).

The new Australian Wool Corporation will facilitate the adoption of appropriate strategies for the promotion of wool, the efficient marketing of Australian wool, and the adoption of proper measures to ensure a high quality for Australian wool.
Mr President, I have already outlined how this particular Bill fits into the total package of legislation for the wool industry.

Let me make quite clear that the role of the new AWC will not include any direct participation in the process of buying and selling wool in the market, other than for technical development purposes and market feasibility studies. The marketing of wool is a matter for the commercial sector to undertake. It is this fundamental aspect that will make the new Corporation entirely different in function and character from its predecessor.

Instead of participating in the market the new AWC will have a role as a market facilitator and will act as the catalyst to ensure that the market is operating as efficiently as possible. As part of the function of encouraging the Australian wool industry to adopt plans for the improvement of the marketing of Australian wool, the Corporation will be required to encourage the adoption of sale by description.

However, it is recognised that the commercial sector may have difficulties in being able to fully take on, at least in the short term, responsibilities associated with programming of wool sales. For this reason the new Corporation will continue to be a major participant in this process for the time being.

In relation to promotion, the new AWC will have the function of promoting or arranging for the promotion of all Australian wool to ensure that these programs serve the best interests of Australian woolgrowers. Currently programs are primarily carried out by the International Wool Secretariat (IWS), based in London, but the present AWC carries out domestic promotion of wool in Australia.

The Vines Committee made a number of recommendations in relation to the governance and management of the IWS and considered that the organisation needed to come under close scrutiny to ensure that we are getting the best value for our promotional dollar. The Minister for Primary Industries and energy will be asking the Board of the new AWC to take up these issues with the IWS as a matter of urgency including the issue of whether, as Vines recommended, the IWS should take over responsibility for wool promotion in Australia.

The new AWC will also be required to develop and implement programs to safeguard and improve the quality of Australian wool. Part of this function will be to set appropriate standards for ensuring the quality of wool and woolpacks, ensure that wool offered for sale meets relevant standards, to keep a register of woolclassers, and to encourage and facilitate the training of shearers and shedhands. The Corporation will have appropriate regulatory powers and functions in this area but the government would wish to see it adopt a co-operative and consultative role in seeking to encourage rather than impose change in these areas.

The new Australian Wool Corporation will be required to encourage the commercial sector to take responsibility for the efficient marketing of wool and will act as a catalyst in preparing the commercial sector for the acceptance of this responsibility. There is no doubt that there will be changes in the coming years. In the absence of the Reserve Price Scheme, the futures market is likely to play a key role in the new market structures. Those companies that take the lead and offer the most efficient and effective service to their clients will succeed.

The new AWC will be required to prepare both Corporate and Operational Plans each year. The Corporate Plan will be a 5 year rolling plan and will be prepared in consultation with the wool industry. The Corporate Plan will define principal goals, outline strategies, and nominate performance indicators and must receive Ministerial endorsement before coming into effect. The annual Operational Plan will detail the activities required to give effect to the matters set out in the corporate Plan, but consistent with the Davis Committee recommendations it will not specifically require the endorsement of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

The new AWC will hold an Annual General Meeting no later than 1 May each year. A register will be established of all woolgrowers who have paid wool tax and who have applied to be registered for AGM purposes. The AGM will provide an opportunity for registered growers to debate and vote on motions to receive the annual financial statement and annual report of the AWC, to vote on recommendations relating to the prescribing of a wool tax rate, and have the capacity to propose motions of no confidence in the AWC Board.

These arrangements reflect the Government's decisions on the Davis Committee recommendations to improve accountability of Statutory Marketing Authorities (SMAs) to their shareholders, who in this case are the woolgrowers.

The constitution of the Board and Board Selection arrangements will be similar to those for the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. The Board will be made up of a Chairperson and 8 Members. These will include the Managing Director of the new AWC, the Managing Director or another Director (excluding the Chairman) of the Wool Research and Development Corporation, and 5 other Members with special expertise or experience. The special expertise required will be in wool growing, wool processing, marketing of commodities, finance, product promotion, business management, and industry standards and quality control. There will also be a Government representative.

In an endeavour to make appointments to the Board so that it can operate from 1 July 1991, the initial Board will be directly appointed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy after receiving advice from a selection committee which the Minister has already established. That process is already underway.
The Minister has already announced Mr Mac Drysdale as the Chairperson designate.

The appointment of the Managing Director will be up to the Board, and the Managing Director of the Research &Development Corporation will of course be appointed by the Board of the Research &Development Corporation.

Appointments to subsequent Boards will be made through the selection process outlined in the Bill. As I mentioned earlier, these selection committee arrangements may be varied if and when changes are made to selection arrangements for other SMA's.

Mr President, this Bill and the package of associated legislation provide for an institutional structure and market arrangements which enable the wool industry to recover from the present crisis and establish a sustainable and viable future for the Australian wool industry.
I commend this Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY
RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT
AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 to provide the establishment, constitution and operation of a Wool Research and Development Corporation.

The only provision in the Bill which applies to all Research &Development Corporations established under the Principal Act, not just the Corporation to be established for the wool industry, is a provision removing the 65 years age limit for directors of R& Corporations.
In February the Government announced its intention to establish a Wool Research and Development Corporation to replace the Wool Research and Development Council.

This recognised the need for an independent commercially oriented body which was removed, as far as possible, from industry politics and equipped with the expertise and powers necessary to effectively encourage commercialisation of R& results and to forge appropriate links with the International Wool Secretariat.

In April the Government announced the structure of the Wool R& Corporation board and the structure of an industry selection committee to provide nominations for that board as well as for the boards of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the new Australian Wool Corporation (AWC).

This Bill gives effect to those announcements and makes the Wool R& Corporation accountable to the woolgrowers who fund the Corporation by way of an annual general meeting (AGM). Direct accountability through an AGM was recommended for statutory marketing authorities by the Davis Committee of Review of Commonwealth Statutory Marketing Authorities.
The logic of an AGM is as strong for R& Corporations as it is for statutory marketing authorities and in time all R& Corporations will be required to hold annual general meetings.

The Bill also contains parallel provisions to those in the Bills establishing the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the new AWC which provide for the transition to the new structure, including a provision preserving the rights and entitlements of employees of the current AWC who transfer to the Wool R& Corporation.

As part of its charter, the Wool R& Corporation will need to establish direct links and better co-ordination arrangements with the International Wool Secretariat. The Chairman of the Wool R& Corporation will be asked to take this matter up with the Board and with the International Wool Secretariat (IWS).

Such a realignment of the linkage with the IWS will ensure that R& work done by the IWS is fully in accord with R& Corporation priorities and will facilitate better co-ordination of R& commercialisation done by CSIRO and IWS.
I commend this Bill to Honourable senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES (INDUSTRY
COUNCILS) BILL 1991
The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the establishment of industry councils for certain primary industries.
There are already industry councils for the meat, horticulture and pig industries. These councils have made significant contributions to policy development in their respective industries.

In October last year, as part of the response to the recommendations of the `Davis' report on statutory marketing authorities, the Government foreshadowed the extension of statutory policy councils to the wool and grains industries.

This Bill provides a legislative framework under which industry councils can be established by regulation for particular primary industries. The Government will be taking early action to establish wool and grains industry councils following passage of the Bill.
In the case of wool, the Australian Wool Industry Council will replace the Interim Wool Policy Council established in September last year.

The object of the industry councils established under this legislation, as is the case for the existing industry policy councils, will be to facilitate the development of sound government policies for these industries by bringing together representatives of different participants in an industry to have an active role in advising the Minister the on policy formulation.

The functions and powers of the councils, set out in part two of the Bill, provide that the industry councils will be given a more central role in reviewing and coordinating industry policy than is the case for the existing policy councils.

This is reflected, for example, in the first function listed in the Bill, under which an industry council is required to review and report on the strategic direction of the industry. In carrying out this function, a council will need to review the activities and general strategies of the other statutory authorities in the industry, specifically the statutory marketing authorities and the research and development corporations and councils.
The coordinating role of the industry councils will also be strengthened in a number of other ways.

The councils will be able to convene industry review conferences and can be required to do so under the regulations. It is intended that the Australian Wool Industry Council will convene such conferences every three years.
The convening of review conferences by the Grains Industry Council is a matter for discussion with the grains industry.

There is also provision for the councils to convene regular meetings of the chairpersons of other statutory bodies in the industry and the regulations may require that such meetings be held. The purpose of these meetings is to enable the chairpersons of each of the industry's statutory authorities to be well informed of the activities of their counterpart organisations and thus ensure the coordinated development of industry strategy.

In the case of the Australian Wool Industry Council, in order to maximise consultation and coordination in the wool industry at this critical time, monthly meetings will be held of the chairpersons of the council, the Australian Wool Corporation, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian Wool Research and Development Corporation.

Part three of the Bill provides for such matters as the composition of industry councils, appointments to the councils and meetings of the council. The membership of each council will be determined in the regulations following consultation with the industry concerned.

In a media release of 30 April 1991, the Government announced that the proposed membership of the Australian Wool Industry Council would comprise a chairperson selected by the Minister; the chairpersons of the new Australian Wool Corporation, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Wool Research and Development Corporation; as well as the Presidents of exporters', brokers', private treaty merchants' and processors' organisations; and a Government member.

Membership will typically cover the major industry sectors which together make up the particular industry or industries covered by the industry council. This will of course include representatives of key industry producer and processor organisations.

The membership is also likely to include the chairpersons of relevant statutory marketing authorities and research and development corporations or councils. Depending on the particular circumstances of the industry, members may take office in their capacity as office holders in industry organisations, may be appointed on the nomination of industry bodies or may be appointed directly by the Minister.

Meetings of an industry council will be held on a regular basis and at such frequencies as may be required by the regulations. Regulations will be prepared which will require the Australian Wool Industry Council to meet at least four times a year.

Part four of the Bill provides councils with the power to establish committees and working groups. This is intended to ensure that, if required, the council can set up functional committees or subject specific working groups. Provision is available under this Bill for working groups to actively involve a broad range of people including council members.
The provisions of part five of the Bill include arrangements for employing and hiring staff and requirements for an annual report to be prepared and submitted to Parliament.

Funds allocated for the Interim Wool Policy Council of $250,000 in 1990-91 and $300,000 in the two subsequent years, will be carried over to the new Wool Industry Council when it is established. Funding will be reviewed in 1992-93. The operating costs for the Grains Industry Council will be met by the Government and are estimated at this stage to be $430,000 in 1991-92. Subsequent funding of the council will be reviewed during 1991-92.
Funding arrangements for any other councils established under this Act will be considered prior to their establishment.

The Government believes that industry councils established under this Act will provide an important focus for the industries they are set up to serve as well as providing an important link between industry and the government in the development of national policies relevant to those industries.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
WOOL TAX (NOS. 1-5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1991
These Bills will make a number of amendments to the Wool Tax Acts (Nos. 1-5) 1964.
The rate of wool tax that can be imposed on shorn wool other than carpet wool under each Act will be reduced from 30% to 15%.

The actual rate at which wool tax is currently imposed will be reduced from 25% to 15% for shorn wool other than carpet wool. The rate for carpet wool increases from 3.85% to 4%. In addition the Bills provide for lower rates of tax to be prescribed by regulations.
Wool tax comprises three components-debt management, promotion and research and development-and the components for 1991/92 will be set at 11%, 3.5% and 0.5% respectively.

The increase in the rate of tax for carpet wool represents an increase in the research and development component for all wool, including carpet wool, from 0.35% to 0.5% in an effort to maintain an adequate level of funding for research and development projects.
These changes will take effect on 1 July 1991.

The existing Wool Tax Acts include a provision for the imposition of an additional tax surcharge of 20% on shorn wool other than carpet wool. The surcharge has never been imposed and the Bills will remove the surcharge provisions.
I commend the Bills to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memoranda.
TRANSPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill is an omnibus Bill amending 5 Acts administered within the Transport and Communications portfolio. While none of the proposed amendments are highly significant, they are important for the functions of the portfolio. Details of the amendments follow.
Civil Aviation Act 1988

The Civil Aviation Act and regulations contain numerous offence provisions. There is, however, no clear articulation in the legislation of the powers of investigators when they are investigating alleged breaches of the legislation.

One of the ramifications of this has been that, recently, prosecutions for alleged dangerous goods offences were unable to proceed because of doubt regarding the extent of the search and seizure powers of investigators.

Furthermore, in its second report on air safety regulation, the Air Safety Regulation Review Task Force expressed concern that the powers of investigators were not clearly set out in the Act and recommended that the Act be amended accordingly.

The amendments proposed to the Act will provide investigators with adequate and clearly defined powers. These will be subject to strict safeguards to protect the rights of individuals against whom the powers may be exercised. The safeguard provisions proposed by this Bill are in line with similar provisions found in other Commonwealth legislation.

Section 98 is also to be amended in order to clarify the power to make regulations dealing with the Authority's powers in respect of the preparation and approval of various technical documents specified in the Bill. The Bill also allows for the making of regulations via the adoption of instruments, or other documents, as in force at a particular time or from time to time.

A major effect of these amendments will be to ensure that a person selecting a particular system of aircraft maintenance will comply with subsequent changes to the system as determined by the aircraft manufacturer or the Authority to be necessary in the interests of safety.

The Act provides that, where assets are transferred from the Commonwealth to the Authority, the Minister administering the Act and the Minister for Finance may determine the value of assets as on the day of transfer and may determine an amount which is deemed by the Act to be a loan from the Commonwealth to the Authority. On 20 June 1988, a determination was purported to be made determining the value of assets intended to be transferred to the Authority at 1 July 1988, the date when the Authority began operation, and the loan in respect of those assets. The Attorney-General's Department subsequently advised that this determination is invalid, as a consequence of technical deficiencies in the procedures originally used to transfer the assets.

This Bill allows the Ministers to now make a valid determination of the value of those assets at the values set in their determination of 20 June 1988. This action is intended to merely affirm the Authority's initial capital structure.
Federal Airports Corporations Act 1986

The Federal Airports Corporation Act is to be amended to make airport security a function of the Corporation. It will also be a function of the Corporation that it be responsible for the provision of aviation security safeguards at all Federal airports.

The Government has decided to rationalise responsibilities for airport security by making airport operators, including the Federal Airports Corporation, responsible for the counter terrorist presence, overall access control and security of the air side areas of airports.

In making this decision, the Government had two main objectives in mind. The first was to provide a single point of responsibility for security at each airport. The second was to ensure that there was a cost discipline on the provision of security measures, particularly in relation to the counter terrorist first response presence. I consider that the airport operator is in the best position to integrate the various security functions at the airport and to ensure cost effective delivery of security services.
Airport operators will be required to ensure that the aviation security functions are performed to minimum standards being developed by the Department.

From 1 July 1991, the Corporation becomes subject to income tax and its taxation year will be 1 July to 30 June. Consequently, this Bill will change the Corporation's financial year from one ending 31 March to one ending 30 June.
This amendment will preclude the Corporation from having two balance dates each year, one for statutory financial reporting purposes and one for taxation purposes, being just three months apart.

If the two years did not coincide, there would be significant inefficiencies and a substantial increase in costs to the Corporation owing to it having to duplicate many of its financial and administrative accounting and reporting functions.
Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983

The amendments to the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act enables Australia to adopt the three recent amendments to the Annex to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973. These amendments also substantially increase the level of penalties for pollution offences and will allow summonses to be served on the master, owner or agent of a ship when prosecuting such an offence.

As well as the above amendments, the Bill will make some minor amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988, the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986, the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990.

The amendment making the Federal Airports Corporation responsible for airport security at, and in relation to, Federal airports will save the Government $15.9 million in each financial year. The other amendments will have no effect on Government revenue or expenditure.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 and the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Regulations 17, 19, 28 and 31 of the Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 60 and made under the Migration Act 1958, be disallowed.

I move this motion for disallowance on behalf of the Opposition because we believe that these regulations are entirely misconceived. They will introduce inequity and unfairness into Australia's migration policies and they are out of touch with general community values. These four regulations that I am moving to disallow are part of a larger set of regulations that make further changes and refinements to the migration program.

Every time that changes to migration regulations are laid before the Senate we can reflect on the confusion of this Government and the confusion and uncertainty that have been occurring-and I see Senator Robert Ray sitting opposite-throughout all of the eight years of the present Government's term, particularly in the rearrangement and reconstruction of the Migration Act from mid 1989 on. Successive Labor Ministers for immigration have brought in new approaches, new policies and new regulations. I have had cause in the past to describe to the Senate the inconsistencies and the difficulties that have arisen as a result of these often ill- thought-out, incomplete regulation changes. But there is no time to put the general case, which has already been well established in the Parliament. I am to confine my remarks to the disallowance of these particular regulations.

The regulations we are considering today are yet another example of blundering ministerial thinking. They raise the issue of the grounds upon which homosexuals can seek to come to reside in Australia. It is, therefore, an issue which we would all wish to approach with carefulness of judgment and without stridency or bigotry. The word `homosexual' does not itself appear in the regulations. The criteria set down for these new, `non-familial emotional interdependency' visas and permits are that the sponsor and the applicant have a relationship which is acknowledged by both and which involves residing together, being closely interdependent and having a continuing commitment to mutual emotional and financial support. As well, the sponsor may not be a relative of the applicant, so we are clearly dealing here with relationships that are not of a family nature. It is obvious that homosexual relationships are the ones that will, on the whole, be relevant under these proposed new criteria.

The issue of the entry into Australia of the homosexual partners of Australian citizens and residents is not a new one. For some years it has been possible for ministerial discretion to be exercised on compassionate grounds to admit a limited number of homosexual partners. It is the Opposition's view that that is the most appropriate way in which to handle these matters, and thus we do not approve of the new policy embodied in these new regulations. Our approach is nondiscriminatory. In our view, no applicant under any of the categories for entry now in place should be discriminated against on the grounds of that person's sexual preference. However, the use of a homosexual relationship alone as a basis for admission to Australia is a quite different matter. The proposed regulations would give a particular advantage to this category of applicant, and we reject the creation of such a legal category, of such a particular advantage. The Opposition rejects the creation of a specific homosexual visa category, which in effect and incontestably is what these regulations would achieve.

Perhaps the most detailed information about past practice in this area was given by the Government in 1989 in answer to a question on notice asked in the other place by Mr Michael Cobb, the honourable member for Parkes. The then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Ray, who I am glad is in the chamber now, supplied via his representative in the House of Representatives, Mr Holding, a lengthy answer on this topic. I seek leave to incorporate the question and the answer in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Immigration: Homosexuals
(Question No. 1743)
Mr Cobb asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 6 April 1989:
(1) What procedures must be followed before homosexuals may enter Australia as immigrants and become Australian citizens.
(2) Have Members of Parliament sponsored such immigrants; if so, (a) how was this done and (b) how many has each Member sponsored.

(3) Has a program been initiated through which homosexuals may enter Australia and become Australian citizens; if so, (a) what are the details, (b) when was it initiated, (c) by whom was it initiated, (d) as a result of what demand, (e) how many immigrants, (i) from which countries and (ii) in total, (a) for each year and (b) in total, have entered Australia under the program since its inception, (f) how many applications does the Minister have before him now, (g) does the Minister personally approve all applications or is this done by his Department, (h) what public announcements have been made by the Government regarding this program, (j) what response has the Government had to the program since its inception, (k) does the program allow homosexuals into Australia over and above other immigrant groups or do these immigrants replace other groups and (l) does the Government intend to maintain, increase, decrease or stop the program.
(4) Is any provision made, or intended to be made, for testing homosexuals for AIDS before immigration is permitted.
Mr Holding-The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

(1) People are not prevented from migrating, nor from obtaining citizenship, because they are homosexual. The procedures applying to homosexuals are identical to those applying to any other applicant: that is, for migrant entry they must satisfy policy requirements for the category under which they are applying and they must meet health and character requirements; for citizenship they must meet residential and other requirements, including a good character requirement.

Homosexual relationships are not equated with marriages or heterosexual de facto relationships for migration purposes. An Australian citizen or resident cannot sponsor a homosexual partner under the criteria relating to spouses and heterosexual de facto partners. Nor is the homosexual partner of a principal applicant eligible for entry as the ``spouse'' of that person.

(2) An individual's sexual orientation is not a relevant factor in considering an application for migrant entry and hence may not be known to my Department, and is not recorded. Hence, while it is conceivable that people who are homosexual have been sponsored by Members of Parliament in accordance with normal procedures, the incidence of this occurring is not documented.

(3) There is no special program through which homosexuals may enter Australia and become citizens. However, once in Australia the homosexual partners of Australian citizens or residents may apply for the grant of resident status (GORS). In answer to the specific points of the question:

(a) Applications for GORS on strong compassionate grounds under Section 6a (1) (e) of the Migration Act 1958 may be lodged in Australia by homosexual partners of Australian residents and citizens who have entered Australia as visitors or temporary residents. Where an application for entry as a temporary resident on the basis of such a relationship is lodged overseas, it is submitted to the Minister for personal consideration.
(b) Applications for GORS on strong compassionate grounds based on a homosexual relationship have been considered personally by successive Ministers since September 1985.
(c) The first applications were considered by the Minister at the time, the Honourable Chris Hurford.

(d) Arrangements to consider applications of this kind were discussed by Minister Hurford with a task force made up of representatives of interested groups. The Opposition has been kept advised of these arrangements.

(e) The following table gives details of the numbers of GORS applications lodged, approved in principle subject to outstanding requirements being met, refused and lapsed or withdrawn since September 1985.

The country of origin of applicants year by year is not available from material at hand but a census of the nationality of applicants at the end of November 1987 gave the following results: Danish, 2; Swedish, 4; Dutch, 2; German, 11; Swiss, 2; Greek, l; Spanish, 4; Yugoslav, 1; Canadian, 9; American, 30; Lebanese, 1; Argentinean, 1; Brazilian, 4; Chilean, l; Colombian, 2; Venezuelan, l; Zimbabwean, l; South African, 6; Chinese, 3; Hong Kong, l; Indonesian, 5; Japanese, 12; Malaysian, 30; Filipino, 16; Singaporean, 9; Sri Lankan, 3; Thai, 14; Fijian, 3; New Caledonian, l; Papua New Guinean, l; Vanuatuan, l; British, 58; Irish, 4.
(f) the Minister currently has 4 applications before him; there are a further 121 on hand being processed by his Department before submission to him for decision.
(g) all applications are personally considered by the Minister.
(h) the subject has been raised previously in Parliament, in the Press and in other forums, and members of the public who have written on the subject have had full replies to their enquiries.

(j) members of the public who have written opposing these arrangements have generally been under the misapprehension that homosexual partners were being equated in migration policy with spouses. This is not the case.

(k) the small number of persons granted resident status under these arrangements has had no effect on the number of migrants approved for entry or the number of persons granted resident status on other grounds.
(l) these arrangements are expected to continue. The figures given in answer to (e) above indicate that the level of applications has remained constant at round 100-120 per year.

(4) All people applying to enter Australia as migrants or long-term temporary residents, and all persons applying for GORS, must undergo a thorough medical and radiological examination. If indicated by the doctor's examination or the applicant's history, a test for the Human Immuno-deficiency Virus (HIV) which causes AIDS would be required. Evidence of AIDS or and AIDS-related condition is cause for recommending rejection of an application.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I quote from part of this answer that needs to be very carefully read by those who are interested in the best way of dealing with this immigration matter:

SPEECH.PARA: People are not prevented from migrating, nor from obtaining citizenship, because they are homosexual.
That was the statement given by Senator Ray at that time. It is a statement that is still true of the procedure available to government without these new objectionable regulations. It continues:

The procedures applying to homosexuals are identical to those applying to any other applicant: that is, for migrant entry they must satisfy policy requirements for the category under which they are applying and they must meet health and character requirements; for citizenship they must meet residential and other requirements, including a good character requirement.

Homosexual relationships are not equated with marriages or heterosexual de facto relationships for migration purposes. An Australian citizen or resident cannot sponsor a homosexual partner under the criteria relating to spouses and heterosexual de facto partners. Nor is the homosexual partner of a principal applicant eligible for entry as the `spouse' of that person.

The answer goes on to state that applicants for grant of resident status on strong compassionate grounds based on a homosexual relationship have been considered personally by successive Ministers since September 1985. The Opposition argues that this established approach is a fair one and that to change the policy in the way the Government is now doing is not warranted. Our view is supported by the first report of the all-party Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations in November 1989. The draft regulations before that Committee included a provision for a homosexual category and the Committee rejected such a concept.

I was a member of that Committee, the first committee on migration regulations, and I am very aware of the arguments that took place at that time. I am very aware that not only I but also the Committee rejected such regulations. It is not two years since that time and we have regulations in a similar form, although without explicit use of the word `homosexual'. I believe that they should still be rejected by the Senate. I quote from the Committee's report of November 1989. The relevant paragraphs are as follows:

It is the Committee's view that the provision of a specific category of visa for homosexuals does not reflect current policy or practice. The Committee argues that although homosexuals should not be discriminated against for migrant entry, neither should they be specifically advantaged. In the past in exceptional cases where an application is based on a relationship with a strong and compelling compassionate ground, or like grounds which apply to all relationships, entry has been allowed.
Section 64u, if amended in accordance with the Committee's recommendations, would give the Minister an adequate discretion to admit those applicants who would have applied under this category.
The Committee therefore recommends that: the homosexual visa category and the consequential definition be deleted from the draft regulations.
The Minister at the time, Senator Ray, accepted the Committee's recommendation on that matter, and it is with great regret that we now see that the succeeding--

TALK.START.PARA: —I never accepted it. I was forced into it by your Committee.
—The Minister is saying he did not personally accept it, but he was forced into it by the Committee. But the Government did not go ahead with that category at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the interjection from Senator Ray that he then sought this shift in the words so that the word `homosexual' was not explicitly included, but he acknowledges that the concept that was explored at that time and then rejected by the Committee is the one that he personally favoured then and now, and the current Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hand, has agreed with Senator Ray's personal position. I rejected it then, the Committee rejected it then-that is, the Joint Committee of the Parliament from both Houses and from all parties-and I, on the Opposition's behalf, reject this approach, this addition to the regulations, now. As I say, the one firm recommendation from the Committee was then to admit a specific homosexual category. The Minister at the time accepted that, and the present Minister would, I believe, have been well advised to leave things as they are.

SPEECH.PARA: The creation of this non-familial interdependency category, even without the word `homosexual' explicitly used, is clearly designed nevertheless with homosexuals in mind. These regulations seek to give a particular new advantage to homosexual applicants for immigration in Australia, and the Opposition soundly rejects that innovation. I believe that the Senate should soundly reject that innovation.

I put to Senator Spindler, Senator Bourne and, of course, Senator Harradine that the Australian Democrats and Independents should make the comparison between this quite new regulation that would give a specific advantage to homosexuals and the established procedure and reject that new approach on the ground that it was rejected by a former Democrat, the then immigration spokesman just two years ago-that is, that there should not be such a specific advantage given to homosexuals on immigration matters and that, rather, we can rely upon the general compassionate circumstances in the consideration by the Minister when an application that is deserving of approval comes before him. The established procedure, which is quite satisfactory, is the one that is set out in the material that I have already incorporated as being the then answer to the question of the honourable member for Parkes, Mr Cobb.

The proper exercise of ministerial discretion remains the most appropriate way of dealing with the cases where there are strong and compelling compassionate reasons. These regulations place homosexual partners on a similar basis to heterosexual partners, and that is a precedent of considerable significance. I put it to the Minister and his advisers, I put it to all honourable senators in the chamber, that we are now going over a line. The Government is leading us over a line which we in this country have never gone over before.

I remind the Senate that in Australian law homosexual partners are not regarded as spouses for tax purposes. They are not regarded as spouses for social security benefits. There is no area of Australian law in which homosexual relationships lead to any family based benefits, indeed, I believe, to any benefits at all. This is the first occasion on which, by new regulations, the Government is giving an explicit, specific advantage to homosexuals in Australian law.
