I think we are entitled to be told if the Government has in mind to make changes in these other spheres, such as tax, social security, marriage-in any area of family law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Adoption.

—I heard Senator Harradine say, `Adoption'. I am asking, plainly: is there an intention by the Labor Government to bring in parallel specific advantages and benefits under any other laws of Australia in the way that it is doing with the migration regulations? I argue that to equate homosexual relationships with heterosexual relationships would not be in accord with the values in the general community at this time. The galleries of this chamber are representative of the public and of visitors to this country. I would go out to people in the electorate at any time and put to them the view, `Is this consistent with your values?'. I am saying here in the Senate that I do not believe that the Australian public wishes to see any discrimination against homosexual Australians, but they do not want to see any specific advantage given to homosexual Australians. There ought not to be a recognition in Australian law of any specific advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, therefore, that it is right for the Senate to reject these regulations, not least because they are not in accord with community values in Australia. To make such an equation is rejected by me; it is rejected by the Opposition; it is rejected by the Liberal Party of Australia; it is rejected by the National Party of Australia; and it ought, I now argue, to be rejected by the Senate-that is, by honourable senators agreeing to support this disallowance motion now before us. It is in the hands of the Democrats. It is in the hands of the Independents. If they support this motion within this hour, they reject this innovation in Australian law and we fall back on the current procedure that I have already outlined, which is perfectly satisfactory.

There are also questions of fairness and equity when we compare those benefiting from this new non-familial emotional interdependency category with those who are family members who are denied consideration under the present rules. I make this point about equity and fairness equally strongly. I refer to people such as sisters and brothers. An adult brother or an adult sister will not have the advantage that these regulations would give to a homosexual partnership that might have existed only as long as six months or even less if the Minister agrees to its being less.

Yet an adult brother and an adult sister, between whom there can be an emotional dependency, a closeness, will not have this immigration advantage. I believe that that is unfair. Many thousands of people from any number of 50 countries around the world who want to immigrate to be with their brother or sister in Australia will not have the advantage that the regulation gives to those in a homosexual relationship. It will certainly seem unjust to those people if this new non-familial emotional interdependency category is allowed to proceed.

I remind the Senate that concessional family reunion allows entry only after quite rigorous points-testing requirements, based upon education, skills, age and employability have been satisfied. The numbers of brothers and sisters who aspire to entry are so substantial that any relaxation of these criteria, if it were a parallel to that applying to homosexuals, would lead to an avalanche of applications. Thus the system does not make it easy for those closer relations to gain admittance to our country.

It follows that, while so many immediate family members are excluded from entry, introducing very relaxed criteria requiring only six months cohabitation for homosexual partners is impossible to justify on grounds of fairness, reasonableness or equity. I note that in fact the period of time does not even have to be six months if the Minister judges that he can accept a lesser period in a particular homosexual relationship. It would be interesting to hear some explanation by the Minister when he responds as to what circumstances would be likely to trigger a decision to reduce the time below the six months which is set out in the regulations.

I make one further observation. The Opposition's stance is to support the previous system of access to ministerial discretion. It was claimed in the other place yesterday by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) that this reliance I have on established procedure is out of tune with, or not accepting the thrust of, the new regulations' approach to the Act, which is to have everything specified and to minimise ministerial discretion. I am not seeking such a comprehensiveness or consistency as to deny what is lawful, and that is, that there is an exercise of ministerial discretion that can be fair and open, and even reported to the Parliament if the Minister wants to make sure that there is no backroom deal for which he does not want to be held possibly liable.

That kind of openness can be achieved by the Minister saying on a quarterly basis, `I have given consideration to this number of applicants in this area, and I have approved this many and not approved that many. I bring to the Parliament's attention that these are the principles that have guided me in every instance'. He can be quite accountable, and I believe that there is nothing inconsistent with that in the general thrust of the present Act as it is structured and the regulations.

The Opposition rejects that claim by the Minister. It is clear that the procedures of the last six years for ministerial consideration of these matters is still fully available and is the procedure actually being used by the current government and the current Minister. He can continue to use that. I put it to the Democrats again: let the Minister continue to use that procedure. There has been no complaint. No-one has complained to the Opposition. Is anyone going to bring a complaint into this debate? Why change, and so break with principles, and bring an innovation into Australian law that we ought not to accept, which is not fair and not consistent with community attitudes?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the reason it has brought this forward, of course. There is no other reason.
—I hear Senator Harradine and, no doubt, he will speak on this matter. I do not believe that the Government is as Machiavellian as that.
—Well, why are they bringing it forward?

—I will let Senator Ray speak for the Government on this matter. I do not want to impute the cynical motive to the Government that it is, in fact, by this first wedge in the door, seeking to completely undermine community values by establishing in Australian law, for the first time, some particular advantage for a homosexual relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: There ought not to be a change. The Opposition rejects these regulations. We call upon the Senate to reject these regulations. I believe that, finally, this ought to be a conscience vote in the Senate. Senator Ray is a robust Minister and the former Manager of Government Business in the Senate. It happens to be the case in the Australian Labor Party that it is--(Quorum formed)

I believe that it is appropriate that this disallowance motion be decided on the basis of a conscience vote. I appeal to Government senators who have come in to form the quorum that this not be regarded as a party block matter, but that individuals can exercise their own conscience votes, as is appropriate in matters that relate to these kinds of relationships, according to the individual dispositions of honourable senators who are elected to represent the Australian public in this place. I believe that Government senators should be able to exercise their own individual conscience votes as to what their attitudes should be to this innovation-this first occasion on which a specific advantage is being given to a homosexual relationship in Australian law.

In conclusion, the Opposition rejects these regulations that would establish a non-familial, emotional interdependency category for visas and permits because it will introduce unfairness into our migration program and is out of touch with community values. I commend the disallowance motion to the Senate, and I hope that it may be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard the Opposition's views on this motion for the disallowance of regulations under the Migration Act 1958 as absolutely hypocritical. I think Senator Teague himself in his speech has indicated the hypocrisy of the coalition's position. He is not opposing, in principle, some homosexuals being granted residence status in this country. It is process that he is going on about, and he is not going on about the principle involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition often claims that no migration applicant should be discriminated against because of a sexual preference. Quite clearly, the interdependency regulation is mostly directed at giving homosexuals rights. The Government does not walk away from that. Let me outline to the Senate how these cases have been dealt with in the past and how that has changed under the regulations.

For people to come to this country to be permanent settlers and be the beneficiaries of ministerial discretion requires them to start off with a lie. They cannot say on their application forms that they are coming to this country to apply for permanent residence on the grounds of ministerial discretion. They cannot do that. The first act that they are asked to do is to fill out the forms with a lie that they are coming here as visitors or for some other reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't think you worried about that.

—Senator Walters is not going to interrupt me today on this important issue. These people start with that particular lie, and that is one of the problems. Secondly, under the new regulation regime these applicants must then apply against a false criterion in order to have a reviewable right before the matter can ever get to the Minister. That is the nub of the question: do we force applicants to apply to come here as a spouse? Do those opposite really want that to be put into the system? There is no reviewable ground directly on compassion. People must apply under one of the criteria as set down in the regulations. So these people have to apply under a false regulation before their case can ever come before the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the sort of system that those opposite want to continue behind closed doors. They want to push this off. Why? I will tell the Senate why. I do not accuse Senator Teague, but I accuse a lot of his colleagues. They do not like this at all, and Senator Teague has given in to the rednecked pressure. There is no question about that. I know that because I know what other people in the Liberal Party, when they brought these cases to me when I was the Minister, think about that. Plenty of Opposition members brought these cases to me when I was Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and asked me to use my discretion. The system, as it has evolved, means that applicants have to go through a web of lies and deceit.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should know all about that.
—Senator Walters, the previous part of this debate was conducted without any interruption to Senator Teague. I ask for similar courtesy to be paid to the Minister.

—As I have said, this whole area is covered by a web of lies and deceit. But before we get too carried away, why do we not have a look at the numbers since this policy was implemented-I think, initially, by Minister Hurford? From September 1985 to 31 March 1991 a total of 621 applications were received. Some 467 applications were approved, 37 were refused, 46 were withdrawn or lapsed and 71 were awaiting the Minister's decision. So the big argument that this will make an immense impression on family reunion or something else is absolute arrant nonsense. It does not stop any immediate family member from coming because that is demand driven-whatever the figure is, those spouses and parents who qualify are allowed in.
—What about sisters and brothers?

—Senator Harradine asks a question. We can make that up in slippage. We never meet an exact target in any one year down to a precise number. So what Senator Harradine is talking about is making the lives of 180 people-90 couples-less miserable. Their lives will not be ones of separation or indiscriminate sexual behaviour. Are we so narrow minded that we want to jump towards a rednecked vote and make people totally unhappy? There is no equation with marriage in this. There was no equation with it when the first lot of regulations were drawn up-nor the second. The statement I made-which Senator Teague was kind enough to put on the record-stands. This is not the thin edge of the wedge and Senator Teague knows that. He knows that this was a specific response to try to create a regime of regulations which made immigration law fair for all-not just at the whim of a Minister.
—Except sisters and brothers.
—Senator Harradine, I have asked that this debate be conducted in an orderly fashion. I have asked Senator Walters not to interject and I ask the same of you.

—What we have attempted to do in the immigration field is establish a set of regulations which make it lawful to enter this country. Whilst no-one will agree on the overall regulations, I think most people accept that that is a proper regime. But once we make it an immigration regulation that people have to meet a specific set of criteria, the system Senator Teague has outlined-and I agree that it has occurred in the past-cannot occur in the future. The first attempt made was to address this question absolutely directly by putting in a regulation for homosexuals. The Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations rejected it. I do not know whether it was the general view of the Migration Committee, but some members of the Committee-including someone from the honourable senator's side of politics-asked me, `Can't you just dress it up slightly differently? Can't you come up with an approach that doesn't recognise it directly?'. That is how this regulation emerged-it took a long while, but things do in this regard. It was in response to that that this regulation appears.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that what Senator Teague is doing if he goes back to the old system is saying, firstly, someone will come to this country, will set out the wrong reason for coming here and will then live in terror that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs can use that as a reason to remove that person from the country at any time. Secondly, if a person does seek permanent residency here, that person will have to apply into a category that does not apply to him or her. People will have to say that they are tradesmen or that they are brother and sister when they have no relationship. We commit them to the second falsehood before they can get to the Minister and the Minister can use his discretion. To me, it is absolute hypocrisy to do it in that way. If we are going to grant these cases we should put them up front. If this Parliament decides that we should not, then we will not do it and no-one will have that particular right.

Senator Teague went on to say some other things. He said, `It's only six months'. It takes six months to get a temporary entry permit, but it is another 24 months before a person gets permanent residency. So it is not six months-that is a ridiculous argument to introduce. If that six months can be reduced there is still that other 24-month period before permanent residency comes into effect.

I do not want to delay the Senate. I think people have probably picked up the flavour of the debate. I am not inviting an interjection, but I think Senator Harradine will take a different approach. He will say, `No, you can't have this sort of thing' and I respect that position.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the fairness of sisters and brothers?
—That is the philosophical position.
—Order! Senator Harradine, you will have your opportunity to reply.
—No, he invited me to interject and I will interject.
—No, I invited Senator Harradine not to interject. I said that I thought Senator Harradine would put a different point of view, and he is about to put a different point of view.
—No, I am saying that-
—What I am saying in terms of the Opposition is that--
—You have not answered it.

—Those opposite have not got up here today and said, `Under no circumstances should homosexual partners be given permanent residency'. We are not arguing on that question of principle in this debate. What Senator Teague is arguing about is the process by which we bring that about. This Senate has two choices: to bring it about by way of subterfuge and disguise, by way of pushing it behind closed doors and creating illegalities, fear and loathing in the community; or it can do it by way of a clear-cut regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not talking about large numbers of people here, but we are talking about human happiness. We are talking about people I have seen who live in terror that they will not be able to live with their partners; that they will not be able to live in a relationship. They await the knock on the door from Immigration because the very fact that they are together has meant that they have had to live lies under the Immigration Act and, at any time, they could be subject to deportation because of the lie that we inflict upon them by failing to protect them under the law and under the regulations.

I do not know why we try to inflict that sort of misery upon people. I really do not know why we try to do it. I do not know what principles are involved in trying to inflict that misery and I do not understand the arguments put up by Opposition senators here today. I do not see why a Minister for immigration has to make these decisions and notify them to Parliament, not based upon the regulations, but based just upon discretion. To me, that is a Stone Age step. It is out of step with the sort of vanguardist role that government must take, and has taken, on these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears to us that the migration regulations that we are discussing today were specifically designed to remove an inequity and an unfairness. They have been specifically and carefully designed to be non-discriminatory. Basically, the regulations allow the granting of an entry visa or an entry permit to someone who is over the age of 18, has satisfied the normal health and public interest requirements and has been, for at least six months before, in a genuine and continuing relationship with an Australian citizen or permanent resident which involves residing together and having a commitment to mutual, emotional and financial support.

SPEECH.PARA: I have read through the regulations and they do not mention sexual preference or any sexual relationship at all. Before permanent residence is considered, as the Minister at the table (Senator Robert Ray) has said, the relationship must continue in the same form for at least an extra two years. Migration regulations are, on the whole, confusing and messy, but these new regulations seem to us to clear up some of those discretions that we have had in the past.

There is no specific homosexual visa category. Senator Teague said that these regulations are creating one; they are not. I have spoken to former Senator Jenkins who was on the Migration Regulations Committee at the time to which Senator Teague refers. She said to me that the problem with the 1989 regulation was that it was called a homosexual visa and the majority of those on the Committee-I am taking her word for this, but I trust it-and that included her, opted for a more general companionship visa because they thought that it was unnecessary to make a public declaration of one's sexual preference before one could get this visa. That seems to us to be entirely reasonable.

These visa regulations certainly create no new advantage. They just take away the disadvantage that existed beforehand. As far as we can see, they do not alter policy at all. They just take the matter out of ministerial discretion and put it into accessible regulations. The current Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) and past Ministers have been very good in this area, but Mr Hand might fall under a bus tomorrow. I hope he does not, but what if he does? Who comes up next? Will they be people who want to have ministerial discretion for these sorts of visas? If not, we should have the policy set out in the regulations. It should be accessible to people who want to come into the country.

We cannot see any reason for using, in the migration regulations, terms related to a person's sexual preference. So we think that this is a perfectly reasonable way to set out these regulations. The regulations can-and I image they will, as most others do-be used by homosexual partners as well as by people who have completely platonic relationships, such as two elderly widows, but are emotionally interdependent. They appear to us to be very reasonable and a mature step away from discrimination. Consequently, we will not be supporting this motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that Senator Bourne was going to give us some reasons as to why the Australian Democrats were going to support these migration regulations. Senator Bourne's main view appears to rest on the fact that her reading of the regulations does not mention homosexuals. My reading of the regulations does not either. We have heard Senator Ray's response to what Senator Teague said. Senator Teague pointed out that, two years ago, the Migration Regulations Committee had a proposal before it to establish a new homosexual migration category. Senator Teague told the Senate, as is the case, that that was rejected by the Committee. Senator Ray interjected and said that whilst that was rejected, we were looking for another form of words to cover the same thing.
—Exactly.

—Senator Ray says, `Exactly'. So in fact we are really dealing with the proposal that was before the parliamentary committee to establish a special homosexual category of migration. That is what we are dealing with here-to put homosexuals into a special category with a special advantage. I hope the Senate will excuse me for having repeated several times to Senator Ray the words, `What about sisters and brothers?' He has not responded to that because there is no response to that. The fact is that these regulations will give persons with homosexual relationships an advantage over hundreds of thousands of sisters and brothers of Australian citizens. In other words a homosexual will jump the queue as a result of this particular regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: How many of us have been repeatedly asked by Australian citizens whether we could please do something about their loved ones, their family, their brothers and sisters in other countries with whom they have close interdependent relationships? I particularly refer to the large number of people who have come from Greece, from Italy, from China and from a number of other areas where the extended family is so important, so interdependent.

How many of us have fought, on behalf of those constituents, to have their brothers and sisters being able to come to this country and have been rejected? Yet here we have special regulations which give an advantage to homosexuals over sisters and brothers. Senator Bourne's contribution falls to the ground because Senator Ray made it fall to the ground. He has admitted that this is precisely the same proposition that was put before the parliamentary Committee on Migration Regulations and which was rejected by that committee.

The second point I make is that it is ironic that we should be allowing this new category at a time when immigration to Australia has been savaged by this Government. The number of people coming into this country has been savagely cut. It is of no use Senator Ray saying that sisters and brothers might get into the country in the last few places that have not been filled. The places will be filled, all right-by others-because of the savage cuts to immigration that have been announced by this Government.

It is also rather sobering to reflect that one of the reasons for the development of the immigration programs of Australia-as in a number of countries throughout the world-has been to build up the population in this country to offset the decline in the number of births. That has been one of the reasons for maintaining a level of immigration to this country. It would be obvious to anybody listening to this debate on a moment's reflection that this special category will hardly contribute to increased population or birth rates in this country.

Another point I want to make is that I believe that this will open the way for a scam. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has recently been trying to curb the scams and rorts that have occurred in the immigration area. I refer to comments that were made by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) in the House of Representatives on 3 June when he referred to the disturbing number of scam marriages between Australian nationals and partners from other countries. At pages 4609-10 of the House of Representatives Hansard, he is recorded as having said:

One of these recent scams involved a company which operated for a number of years in Victoria, where fees up to $16,000 were being paid for marriages of convenience to enable Fijians and Indians to migrate to Australia. The sum of $4,000 went to the Australian partners, some of whom were mentally handicapped, and the rest to the Melbourne principals of this particular marriage fixing racket. Millions of dollars were made over this period from customers applying through the company in Fiji.

If these regulations are adopted, what is to stop the homosexual liaison business from thriving? What is to stop a scam of similar proportions from developing? At the very time when the Government has attempted to prevent the scam, how will it prove it? I believe that the Government needs to come up with the answer, that the Minister needs to enlighten the Senate as to how scams will be stopped under this new category, particularly, as Senator Teague pointed out, as the period of six months or even less was mentioned. Whatever happens with these regulations, the Government will have to live with the situation. If these regulations are not disallowed, questions will be asked of the Immigration Department as to their operation because of their potential for scam.

Finally, I come back to the major question of principle that was referred to by Senator Baden Teague. Senator Teague said that, for the first time in Australian law, the Government is placing a homosexual relationship on the same basis as a legal marriage. In so doing, it is giving that relationship an advantage over other familial relationships. In the very definition the Government talks about non-familial relationships, which, as I said, excludes brothers and sisters. It is significant that Senator Ray refused to answer my interjections on the discrimination that will be felt by the brothers and sisters of those Australian citizens who are seeking to come to Australia because of their emotional dependency.

I ask the Senate to consider what it is doing if it accepts these regulations. It is establishing a precedent in placing homosexual relationships on the same basis as marriage. It is opening the way for rorts and scams, which the Department is trying to close down, and it is discriminating against familial relationships, including brothers and sisters of those Australian citizens who are currently seeking to come to Australia on emotional and dependent grounds. For those reasons and the other reasons that have been given by Senator Teague, I believe that the Senate ought to reject these regulations, which are simply homosexual category regulations rejected by the parliamentary Committee but now dressed up in other words and in other terms, as admitted by Senator Ray here this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In asking us to disallow the migration regulations before us, Senator Teague, speaking for the Opposition, said that we were being invited by the Government to cross a line and that the Opposition parties were not willing to do so. I am rather sad that the Opposition parties are not prepared to cross the line of enlightenment. I believe that we are no longer in the Middle Ages. We should take account of the personal rights and liberties that are guaranteed by our Constitution and would be guaranteed by a human rights Bill if we had a human rights Bill that had not been frustrated so often in the past by the efforts of the Opposition parties.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is incumbent upon a civilised society to ensure that any person may exercise his or her political and civil rights regardless of nationality, race, religion or sexual preference. It is a great pity that the Opposition parties cannot lift themselves out of the steeped prejudice of the past and look in the face of the clear principles of human rights. It is no wonder that they want to abolish the Human Rights Commission.

I now turn briefly to some of the points that were made by Senator Harradine and, firstly, to his suggestion that Senator Bourne did not advert to the intent or definition of these regulations. Senator Bourne simply drew a wider ambit, saying that the regulations were not specifically directed at homosexual people-although it was clear from her remarks that they could be used in that way. She pointed to the fact that the general terms in which the regulations were couched left it open for them to be used by people other than homosexual couples who were in a situation of emotional interdependence.

Senator Harradine further adverted to the numbers conjuring up in some way a floodgates argument. That is hardly the issue here. As we have heard from the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), currently there are some 180 or 190 individual applications for couples on the board. The conditions imposed on couples and the matters that they need to prove, emotional as well as financial interdependence, will be strictly enforced. There is hardly a danger here of upsetting the numbers of our immigration program.

Senator Harradine also pointed to rorts and scams which certainly are in existence. But, no doubt, any regulation or piece of legislation admitting people to this country would be open for unconscionable operators to exploit. We should not hide behind that danger and neglect the principle that is at stake here. I believe it is incumbent upon us, upon the Parliament and upon the Government to ensure that the laws of this country are observed. The danger that they may be subverted by some people should not be a reason not to do what is right.

There is one aspect about which I personally feel strongly-and I express a personal view here because I am no longer the spokesperson on immigration and ethnic affairs-and that is, that brothers and sisters should be added to the categories available for family reunion migration. I am on public record as having said that. I would be happy to take whatever action I am able to take in that area to achieve that. I will lend my support to Senator Harradine in any efforts towards achieving that additional category.

Another aspect was raised: is this regulation opening up a direction towards the introduction of consideration of homosexual couples in other pieces of legislation? Adoption was raised. This is a matter that I personally have not considered in detail. I would like to defer comment on that. I believe that each piece of legislation and its potential consequences should be looked at separately on a case by case basis and in some detail. Taxation and social security were also raised. Here, I personally believe that there are grounds for considering homosexuality, and homosexual relationships should be taken account of in legislation that deals with these matters.

I conclude by saying that I fully support my Party's rejection of the disallowance motion. It is time that our society took account of the political and civil rights that every person in it should be guaranteed, regardless of race, religion or sexual preference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In responding to the debate, because of the pressure on our time I must be brief and confine my remarks to only a few matters that were raised by each of the speakers. First of all, there are many Opposition members who would have wished to speak on this motion but they were ruled out by the arrangements between our Whips to confine our time.

SPEECH.PARA: There were two Aunt Sallys put up by the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, on behalf of the Government. The first was `while Senator Teague has got good values, good arguments and is in a sound position on these matters, he has given in to redneck pressure'. Let me assure this chamber that none of us in the Opposition, least of all myself, have given in to any kind of redneck pressure. I genuinely believe that the views I express are leading the Opposition and are also the views expressed by our spokesman in the House of Representatives, Mr Ruddock. They are views held by all of us. This Aunt Sally gained more from louder speaking on the part of my good friend Senator Ray, than from any actual logical or factual base. I also reject Senator Spindler's uncalled-for remarks about `lack of enlightenment', `lack of a support for human rights of every individual in this country' and that there has been a `steeped in prejudice approach' from anyone in this debate in this chamber.

The second Aunt Sally the Minister put up was that the present procedure-the one that has been used for six years-requires applicants seeking compassionate consideration to put themselves into a position of basing their application on lies and then living in terror. Let me make it entirely clear: nothing that the Opposition is putting forward wishes any person to ever put forward a lie or to ever live in terror. Under the present procedure we seek-and through you, Mr Deputy President, I note this to the officers who are present from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, and to the Australian public-to have an application made for permanent residence in Australia which is to be a truthful statement. That application comes, through the procedures as outlined in my speech and incorporated as the procedure from 1985 on, as an application for compassionate consideration by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. We do not accept the Aunt Sally that Senator Ray referred to in regard to lies.

The Minister gave two non-answers, despite my explicit request that he address himself to the matters. The first matter was the unfairness to sisters and brothers. Senator Harradine has also rightly made that point in support of the principle that I outlined on behalf of the Opposition. Senator Spindler has agreed that there will now be an unfairness with regard to sisters and brothers. I would say to the Australian public-and not least to the Italian, Greek and Chinese populations-that sisters and brothers of the world should unite and act to get this inequity thrown out because they will be jumped in the queue by those advantaged by this procedure that the Government wants to foist upon the Australian immigration system.

The other area which the Minister did not answer was my reference to the conscience vote. Maybe the Labor Caucus is prickly about this matter and maybe Labor senators have got individual views but are just hoping that no-one will refer to the subject or require them to be of personal account. Rather, they will hide behind a general Government position. I regard the failure of the Minister to refer to or allow a conscience vote as a serious failing in the Government party. We believe there ought to be the ability for individual senators to determine their own position in this matter.

Finally, I thank Senator Harradine for his remarks supporting the thrust of the Opposition's argument. I acknowledge Senator Bourne's remarks, which I found brief but not convincing. It is true that Senator Jenkins, with us all, did refer to the notion of a companionship visa. But I assure Senator Bourne that we rejected not only the term `homosexual' but also any notion of a homosexual visa.

The Opposition will call for a division on this matter. We hope that individual Government senators may accept the disallowance motion that the Opposition is moving, and that the Australian Democrats and Independent senators also support the very sound views which I believe that I, on behalf of the Opposition, have brought to the Senate today.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Teague's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY (REWRITE) TRANSITION BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 4 June.
SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government's amendments to the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 1 to 6-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
(Quorum formed)
Clause 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 7, page 5, proposed subparagraph 513(d) (ii), line 34, omit ``12 months'', substitute ` `9 months''.
2. Clause 7, page 5, proposed section 513, add the following subsection:

``(2) For the purposes of calculating the period of time required by paragraph (l) (d), such period of time during which a person was in receipt of unemployment benefits in accordance with the Social Security Act 1947 immediately prior to receiving either job search allowance or newstart allowance shall be included.''.
3. Clause 7, page 6, proposed subsection 514(1), definition of `change day', lines 5 and 6, omit ``12 months'', substitute ``9 months''.

I simply indicate that the amendments give effect to our view that there ought to be a finite cut-off date in relation to payment of unemployment benefits or their successor, the Job Search allowance. In so far as registration with the Commonwealth Employment Service is tied into eligibility for the Job Search allowance, that reference to 12 months ought to be amended to nine months and in so far as previous receipt of benefit is to be taken into account, unemployment benefits ought to be relevant in that exercise, rather than simply a reference to the Job Search allowance.

The same goes for the changeover day. We take the view that there ought to be a cessation of entitlement to the Job Search allowance after nine months and, therefore, the Job Search allowance ought to expire at that time, rather than after 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting these amendments. I detailed in my speech during the second reading debate our position on this legislation. I do not intend to go into it again today.

—I also think that the Government's position on this is fairly well-known. Obviously we do not agree with the amendments. The important thing to note-while I would love to take up the politics of all of this, I will not do so-is that, internationally, nine months is just not an accepted benchmark. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development accepts 12 months. I do not understand why Australia is in a unique position to take a lesser figure. In any event if one looks at the percentage rates of long term unemployed, one will find that, even since the recession began, the measures of the existing Newstart strategy are working. I cannot understand why we would want to change.

—Now may not be the time to discuss this question. I have a real problem about flexibility of the Government's program in relation to the availability of courses for those who are in receipt of the Job Search allowance. The current situation is that many people who may have had intermittent employment over a period of, say, less than 12 months, are denied entry into training situations which are available for persons only after 12 months. I know that this is probably not the time to debate that. I will oppose the amendments that have been moved by the Opposition; but I just wish to foreshadow that in view of the fact that I did not have the opportunity last night to speak during the second reading stage of this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain that I can satisfy all of Senator Harradine's concerns but I will have a go at doing so. Flexibility will have to be central to the administration of the whole Newstart strategy. In the way it operates, there will be plenty of flexibility in the administrative guidelines that will be used by the Commonwealth Employment Service and my Department. Obviously, where there are no courses, people will not be required to do them. The point about the Job Search allowance is that it is not as if people are denied access to training. In fact, it is possible that after six months some disadvantaged people will be given access to the courses anyway. We will be flexible. We will not be setting impossible requirements on people.

SPEECH.PARA: By the same token, we have to have some relationship between courses available and numbers. If we are to have a number of people on whom we are supposed to concentrate, I think that it is better that we concentrate on the longer term unemployed than on anyone else. I do not for a moment believe that we ought not to be concentrating on everyone in making courses available. It is to be hoped, of course, that over the next year or two we will continue to increase the number of places in training courses, and we shall attempt to do so. Senator Harradine does have my assurance that flexibility will be the hallmark of all of this. We will not be imposing impossible duties on anyone. We will certainly be encouraging as many people as we can to take up training where it is available, whether they are in the Job Search or Newstart schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —While we are talking about that particular situation, could the Minister tell me whether at the moment a 19-year-old person, who has been unemployed over a period of, say, eight months, with the odd job in between, is not entitled to enrol in training courses. This is the situation in Hobart at the moment. Along with Senator Harradine I am asking: will the Job Search allowance change that? Will those people be able to enrol in that particular training under the Job Search allowance? Will it be flexible enough to pick it up? Are there, indeed, enough places to cope with people who are very keen to get a job, having left school and not being fully employed? Are those people entitled to enter that training area?

—As it stands at the moment, the situation is that if the relevant Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) personnel considered that the training course would enhance the person's capacity and the probability of securing employment, under the Job Search allowance rules as they currently apply, that person would be allowed to do the course. I have not said that there would necessarily be enough courses for every person who wants to enrol. That is something we addressed in March and may have to look at again. I am saying that could be done now. In any event, as a result of the legislation here today, the CES personnel will be making certain that enough flexibility applies so that if courses are not available, once people have been on the Job Search allowance for a little longer than the person in Senator Walters's example, we will not require them to do the impossible.

—The thing is that it is at the discretion of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) office. I shall give the Minister an example. A young 19-year-old had been engaged in casual work over the previous eight months and was looking for full time work. He found a training course, a short course in horticulture, which was his preferred option. He immediately went along and applied for entry to that course but was told by the CES officers that he was not eligible to enrol because he had not been unemployed for 12 months. That situation is unacceptable, and I am asking whether that is the fault of the legislation or the fault of the CES officers. What is going to happen under the new scheme? Will that be corrected or is it correct the way it stands at the moment?

—I would appreciate the honourable senator giving me details of the case later so that I can have it checked out. No, that is not right as things stand at the moment. What the person was told by the CES officer, if in fact that is the case, was not right, and that disturbs me. I should make the point here that, under the Job Search allowance (JSA) rules, after six months people who are particularly disadvantaged can get access to courses, and they will be urged to do so. The sort of people I am talking about are sole parents, and most of us would concede that those people are at greatest disadvantage, that sole parents and their families have a real struggle on their hands. Also, ex- prisoners are in a very vulnerable position, particularly in a recession, as are some disabled people and some Aboriginals. If there is a special disadvantage, after six months those rules can apply.
—What rules can apply?

—The current rules would enable these people to be given access to courses, and we do not change any of that. If the facts are as Senator Walters says, the CES officer involved gave the wrong information to the 19-year-old. Perhaps, though, it was the case that the CES took the view that the course was in some way unsuitable for the person. I have no idea. I do not know the individual circumstances of the case. But had the CES believed that this course would enhance the possibility of the person gaining employment, I am sure they would have said yes. So there must have been some reason; I just do not know what it was.

—I am wondering whether perhaps there were not enough places. Is there a restriction on places for those studies? I can assure the Minister that this was this student's preferred option. He wanted to do that particular course desperately. Why would he be denied it?

—I am reluctant to go any further on the individual case. However, with the employment access program, there is an establishment of priorities. I have just gone through some of the categories relating to how they are established. I do not want to suggest that a course will be available for every person who wants one. We cannot pretend that that is the case and I would not seek to do so. What I am saying is that it relates to where a course is available and where we consider the person eligible. Based on the facts that Senator Walters has given us, the 19-year-old to whom she referred is eligible. I would say, by the way that, from her record here we know that Senator Walters does not misrepresent the facts, so I accept that the person has told her that. So, I think, on that assumption, a mistake was made. As I have said, if the honourable senator can give me the details I will check the matter. However, our view is that if a place is available for a person in that category that person would be sent to it. But a judgment would have to be made that it would enhance employment prospects, that the person would be capable of doing the course and that it was suitable for the person, et cetera. That is a decision that has to be made at the shopfront level. It is not one that can be made here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Walters has outlined correctly the particular case relating to this matter. In her contribution in the second reading debate, Senator Patterson emphasised the need for flexibility in these training arrangements. I am sure we all appreciate the fact that, where a person has been intermittently unemployed for a period of eight months, it indicates a couple of things. One is that the person is really trying to get into the paid work force and trying to make a contribution. Secondly, it probably indicates, more than anything else, the state of the economy, and today there are examples of people who have had three or four jobs over only a few months. Because of an industry going out of business or transferring to the mainland or somewhere else people are finding themselves out of a job.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that, psychologically, it is important to give those people the opportunity at that stage to train in a preferred area. I accept what the Minister says but, notwithstanding, I feel that the Department has some sort of priorities in this regard and that the people who have perhaps been intermittently unemployed over a period of eight months are pretty low on the priority list when it comes to training programs. I would be disappointed to find that that was in fact the case. I am interested in what the Minister is going to do about the case raised by Senator Walters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want anything I have just said to be read as meaning that a person in the category referred to by Senator Walters is a low priority. A person in that situation is not a low priority. He would not be as high a priority as someone who had been unemployed for three years and who was perhaps in greater strife but nonetheless he would be a priority. Let me make this clear: after six months, anyone who is unemployed can get access to a labour market program. It is then a matter of priorities at the local level as to whether or not a decision is made to send the person along. That has to be made at the local level.
—Eligible for? They can't get access.
—A person can get access or is eligible--
—It's semantics.

—Let's not argue semantics; I do not think anyone here misunderstands what I am saying. As an example, ex-prisoners can get access after a month. So the CES is trying to give priorities to the very specially disadvantaged first, and I have referred to the main categories and after that at six months CES can assess the work history of anyone who is unemployed and can recommend a program if it is available or, if a person comes in with a place lined up, the CES can make a decision on whether that person's opportunities would be enhanced by doing the course. So, it is not a matter of a low priority. But it is a semantic argument, because I am acknowledging that I do believe that there will be sufficient courses for every person at the moment. I am acknowledging that. That is why it is not semantics when I say `can get access to'. I mean that they would be able to get access; it is just a question of whether or not a course is available for them.

—I refer the Minister to an earlier comment he made about not all people having access to courses. What percentage of people on Newstart does the Minister expect to be able to access courses? The Minister has mentioned that some people on JSA will be able to access courses. Roughly what percentage does he expect will be able to access these courses?
—I am advised that 30 per cent of those on Newstart in one year could get access to a course.

—Can I be clear on what happens to those who become unemployed? Is the Minister saying that if they fall within specially identified categories of disadvantage they will be eligible for labour market programs but that after six months everyone, at least in theory, will be eligible but we will then make judgments about whether assistance will be provided? In other words, is he saying that the Government may decide that someone is better off to keep looking for work?
—That is correct.
—Is that all built into administrative discretion or will that somehow be determined by way of guidelines or otherwise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When judgments are made on these programs in the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Social Security there will be guidelines, and that is well known. I have always been prepared to make those available to Senator Alston once prepared and will do so again. Even under guidelines, that still involves judgments being made by officers at the shopfront. That is unavoidable; that must always be done. But the guidelines give them a pretty clear idea of what can happen.

SPEECH.PARA: On that 30 per cent figure, it must be remembered-if I can add to the last answer-that many people involved in such programs finish up getting some employment and go off the list. It is not as though every person eligible for Newstart stays eligible all of the time. That has to be acknowledged. I do not for one second suggest that we do not have to look further at program places during the current Budget discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I go back to my earlier question. The Minister gave an answer of 30 per cent for Newstart. Roughly what percentage of people, after their six months on JSA, would be considered as eligible for the training courses?

—I cannot give a figure on that now; I shall get it for Senator Lees. The rule is that they are all eligible after six months. The problem is that it has to be established whether they are a priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment, I would argue, the priorities are in need of considerable overhaul in terms of need. Last night I read into my speech a case where someone, within one year of obtaining a PhD or with a masters degree was forced to do a six-week office skills course. I would be only too happy to pass that specific case on to the Minister; I have a number of others. People are presently being forced to undertake courses that are of no interest and no value to them when other people are queuing up, desperately wanting to access these very courses. How are the priorities worked out?

SPEECH.PARA: An incident having occurred in the gallery-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Applause from the gallery.
—I don't think it was for you.

—I did not think it was for me-I have not been getting much of it in this place when I stand up lately and I do not look forward to much in the future. Actually, I was clapped for the first time walking in here the other night, all from the Opposition-or that is what Opposition senators said.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall answer the serious question from Senator Lees about the setting of priorities. The first priority of the scheme, as the legislation sets out, for training courses undoubtedly is and has to be those in the Newstart program. But we will be looking to others after six months. They will have to establish that priority on the basis of individual circumstance. I do not see how we can give a blanket rule as to what priority a person is going to have, such as the person that Senator Walters referred to. The case of the person who is about to get a PhD being, to use Senator Lees's words, forced to do this six-week course in office skills, I find extraordinary. I cannot understand the circumstance under which that would occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has got his PhD.

—I thought she said `within a year of getting a PhD'. Anyway, that does not matter. Let us say he has a masters degree and forget about a PhD because a masters degree really puts him in front of most of the human race. So let us stick at that.
—That is your view.
—Let us not argue about it. I mean only in terms of qualification; not necessarily in terms of intelligence, initiative, brains and drive.
—A completely different matter.

—That is an entirely different matter. I do not find any reason why that can happen. I do not understand that at all and I shall seek an explanation from Minister Dawkins as to how it can happen. Obviously, when one is dealing with the numbers of unemployed that we have now, and there are hundreds of thousands of them, it will never be possible to guarantee that every case will be dealt with properly every single time. Provided there is a very small number of exceptions where an officer at a local level in either department might make a mistake we can be well satisfied.

SPEECH.PARA: The important thing to know here is that the system will not be managed in such a way as to place impossible or stupid burdens upon individuals. I can absolutely guarantee that we will not be placing impossible ones. The odd wrong decision does occur, and I have to try to make sure that the guidelines are tightened sufficiently to minimise their number. The cases to which Senator Lees and Senator Walters referred will assist me in that endeavour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters I want to clarify: first, under Job Search, the Minister has told us that everyone is eligible once he or she becomes unemployed to join a training scheme.
—I didn't say that.

—The Minister did not say that, so I have misunderstood him. With all the best intentions in the world, I thought the Minister said they were eligible but after six months there was a greater priority. I will get the Minister to clarify that.

SPEECH.PARA: Am I right in saying that after six months it is at the discretion of the CES officer concerned whether people are eligible to enter a course if that particular officer believes that it will be to that person's benefit-that, no matter what the unemployed person feels about it, if that officer does not think it is suitable he or she has no hope of joining a course? I know the Minister would agree with me that CES officers are under a lot of pressure and strain. Someone may kick up a bit of a fuss because he has not been allowed to go on one course. If he is denied access he may believe that he has been discriminated against because he has had a bit of a blow-in with one of the officers.

It is very difficult for people who are out of work and struggling to get on to a course. The moment their six months is up they want to get on a course but they are denied access because a CES officer believes it is not in his best interests, no matter how much they think it is in their best interests. How do we get over that feeling, whether it is true, of discrimination that that unemployed person is going to accuse the officers of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question asked me to repeat what I said before. I thought everyone understood it, but I will say it again. It is not the case that everyone is eligible for a training course immediately upon becoming unemployed; it is the case that after six months everyone is eligible. That is subject to availability; we have been through this. I have explained that after a month a number of--
—Six months of continuous unemployment.

—After 1 July it will be six months continuous unemployment. I did not specify that before because it was not that way before. After one month some special categories of people, which I have been through, become eligible. After six months everyone becomes eligible, subject to priorities.

SPEECH.PARA: Then Senator Walters moved on to the question of individual officers and the kinds of decisions they make in situations where they are under stress, as I think she put it. In both the CES and Social Security offices at the moment there are obviously thousands of people coming in who are under great stress, who have not been unemployed before and who, naturally enough, are finding times very difficult. That stress is communicated to staff. That is why I have so much admiration for the staff. We have beefed up training for staff to make sure that they are able to cope with these situations.

It is the case that staff at the CES are accustomed to people coming in with a burden, coming in angry, and are able to cope with it. Not every officer in the service will cope as well as the next. By and large, though, I think the evidence is that the CES copes very well indeed, and we will continue to train our staff on the best way to handle the more difficulty situations. I think we are doing that reasonably well. Sometimes it is worth the effort to go out into Department of Social Security or CES offices and to watch the system at work. Under difficult circumstances, I think we cope well.

I doubt very much that there will be officers who will simply give in to those who yell the loudest about their disadvantage or difficulty. Those officers have to work within the guidelines they are given, take those into account and then make a judgment. It will always come down to a judgment, but if the guidelines are written properly it will be possible to administer the system with some compassion. I doubt very much that we will be getting too many complaints that one person is unfairly treated as against another. There will always be the complaint that there is unfairness because many people will obviously feel that it is unfair that they are unemployed at all in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only one remaining question. What does the Minister mean when he says `six months continual unemployment'? Does that mean that someone who is unemployed for three months and takes a part time or casual job for just a few hours a week is still unemployed? What is unemployed? Is someone considered to be unemployed if he is on unemployment benefits for six months while in a part time job or casual employment, but not having a full time job?

—As I understand the situation, under the guidelines if a person works for any period less than six weeks he will not be counted as having been employed. He will still be in a category of continuous unemployment. So for those people who get a casual job, for example in a club on a Saturday night occasionally, we will not then say that they are ineligible. They will still be regarded as having been continuously unemployed.

—I wish to go back to the 30 per cent of people who will be able to access courses when they are on Newstart and to look at the difficulties of then prioritising and sorting out who goes where. I ask the Minister: has the Government considered opening up other possibilities of other courses, for example, part time technical and further education courses, part time university courses and, in particular, private courses. We have had a number of people write to us asking that they be permitted to do courses in the private sector; for example, people who have run a small business and who are seeking to do specific small business management courses. In one case, somebody who had been at middle management level wanted to do a specific course that was of only two weeks duration. Is the Minister considering those options?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that is yes. Under the new arrangements, they will all be considered. They will need to be considered. I also go back to what I said before. I think the Government still needs to address this question in the Budget context to see if we can do more as well. But, yes, those courses will be looked at.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator LEES (South Australia) (12.15 p.m.) Looking at the way in which the formal agreement will have to be set out, how many hours per week is the Minister looking at to ask a person to undertake the agreement for? In other words, are we looking at a 40-hour week for this agreement?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it certainly will not cover 40 hours a week.

—I am asking the following questions because we do not have before us, and apparently are not going to have before us, any specific regulations, and people will have to have some idea of how many hours a week study will be permitted under the Newstart scheme. Therefore, roughly how many hours a week is the Minister looking at permitting a person to study part time and still be able to take part in other Newstart schemes and be on unemployment benefit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not going to be a standard rule on this, and there cannot be. If a person is in remote parts of Australia and then moves to a smaller city or a bigger city, his needs will depend upon his occupation and the kinds of courses that he would be suitable for. We have to have the flexibility to deal with individuals; and we cannot do that if we start setting a rule which says that the limit will be X hours. I do not think that is possible or desirable.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to set the parameters broad enough so that people cannot be disadvantaged by this and so that unreasonable burdens cannot be placed upon them. That is the whole purpose of the exercise. If we start specifying the number of hours, it is going to be very difficult to maintain the flexibility to deal with people who are in very different situations around the country. We cannot have standard rules when there is no standard position around the country. The situation varies from place to place and person to person.

TALK.START.PARA: —My reason for asking this is not only in relation to courses that are available. The current situation is that people who undertake regular voluntary work are cut off from unemployment benefits frequently. If the Minister wants some evidence of that happening, he could go to the volunteer centre in Adelaide, which will give him plenty of documentary evidence. What people at the volunteer centre are asking, and also people wanting to do courses are asking, is if a person fulfils the requirements, or whatever is in the agreement, in perhaps five hours a day, can he therefore do maybe five hours every day of voluntary work or perhaps five hours of other part time study outside what is actually in the agreement?

—The situation is that we do not have a restriction on part time voluntary work. Rather, the restrictions come about in terms of obligations under the activity test. If the person can meet the obligations under that test, there is no restriction on the hours of part time voluntary work he can do. I do not think that is a change. That has been the case right through.

—I am sorry, but that certainly is not the way in which the Department has been operating. I do not wish to place any people on the front counters in DSS offices at risk, but they in fact have advised the unemployed not even to fill out that section of the form because so many were having difficulties when they honestly filled out the form and said that they were doing five or six hours a week of voluntary work. But I take the Minister's word on this now, and I look forward to the future under Newstart, when people will be able to do voluntary work as long as they fulfil other requirements. I understand that that is his position.

—That is the agreed position. The point to make here is that the only time that I have had complaints about this brought to me, they have been about full time voluntary work. Certainly, that is not permitted. There is no weakening of that position contained in this legislation. But, if the question is about part time voluntary work, the only restrictions are as I have just indicated.

—I will give the Minister one example before leaving this issue. I am advised that in Sydney someone's unemployment benefits were cut off because that person had been working a number of hours a week for meals on wheels. That is the way in which the rule has been interpreted in the past, and I am very pleased to note that in future under Newstart that will not be the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a question of talking about the way it has been interpreted in the past. You do not grab an exception and then claim it as the norm. Any suggestion that the norm is that the unemployment benefits of anyone who has done part time voluntary work were cut off is simply not right. The overwhelming weight of cases goes against that. That does not mean that there is not some dividing line at which an officer might have to look at what is part time and what is full time. It is not always the case that those who ring or write and complain to us or to welfare rights centres are necessarily totally truthful about every element of their being.

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say is that the complaints that have been raised with me in the past have always been about full time voluntary work, not about part time voluntary work. The system has never been operated in such a way as to penalise those who have been in part time voluntary work and it certainly will not be as a result of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures in the 1990-91 explanatory notes of the Department of Employment, Education and Training for program place allocations for the long term unemployed are listed as follows: Job Clubs and Job Search Training, 6,800; Jobtrain, 16,000; Jobstart, 15,000; and Skillshare, 44,000 which, on my reckoning, is 81,800 in total. In addition, a number of places are allocated to young people who have been unemployed for 12 months or longer which include Job Clubs and Job Search Training, 6,200; Jobtrain, 5,000; and Jobstart, 6,500 which comes to a total of 17,700, the grand total being 95,500 places for 180,000 long term unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: On an absolute base reckoning this is a 55 per cent place to long term demand ratio. That does not take into account the many long term unemployed people who would gain access to two or more of the government programs during a 12-month period, plus those that the Minister has just mentioned in special categories and those who have been unemployed for more than six months. For example, many people might undertake Job Search Training within a Job Club, then undertake a vocational training course through Jobtrain or Skillshare. It is not unreasonable to assume that such a person may then enter a subsidised employment position under the Jobstart program.

I guess I can understand how the Minister gets the 30 per cent figure, but I would be interested to know exactly how he gets it. Also, I would like to hear his response to the comments I made last night about the pig in the python. That means the unemployment increase which has occurred over the last six months and which, down the track in another six months time, will be a bulge of long term unemployed, will hit this program with a great force. What is going to happen then? What plans does the Government have to deal with that? Now that 30 per cent have access to those programs, what will it look like in three or four months time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I missed this pig in a python reference last night. I am sorry that I did-it is not bad. It is a good effort by Senator Patterson. In terms of what we will do about it, I can only turn to what I said before. We would be looking to address it in the Budget. Clearly, the previous Budget numbers on unemployment have been exceeded by a fair way. We were wrong. The Treasury predictions were wrong on unemployment. That is not the best kept secret in the world.
—It is not the only thing that you got wrong.
—When I am wrong, I admit it. If Senator Walters did that she would never stop the admissions.
—Harsh and unkind.

—Harsh and unkind, but not uncalled for. We will have to address the bulge, as Senator Patterson puts it, in the Budget. I would concede that the number of long term unemployed must increase. We could argue about how much it will increase, particularly given the statement I made earlier about the percentage of increase in unemployment as against the increase in long term unemployment. Nonetheless, it will increase, and we do need to do more in the Budget and we will. That is how it will be worked out.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Patterson should not forget that it is not only a matter of talking about who will get into what course. It is also worth looking at who will get what job. We are confident that during the second half of this year-the first half of the next financial year-the economy will begin to turn around.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 7, page 8, proposed subsection 518 (3), lines 13 to 21, omit the subsection.

This amendment relates to the sufficient reason clause which is being tightened significantly. The definition of sufficient reason involves the reduced employment prospects rule. The narrowing, as it is being done, would severely limit the grounds upon which persons could appeal a decision to deny them payment for moving residence. Other provisions within the Bill do not spell out what constitutes sufficient reason, and should be left wide enough, we argue, to enable people to move residence for a variety of reasons. I want to ask the Minister a few questions. Firstly, why is the Government doing this? What is the rationale behind limiting the definition of what constitutes sufficient reason for moving?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is a question of limiting the definition. Rather, it is making clear the way that we operated on this in any event in the past. All we are trying to do is give some clarity to people so that they know. As far as I am aware, this does not represent a tightening up. All we are talking about here is ensuring that people make reasonable efforts to find work. If they move to an area where that work is much harder to find and it is difficult for them to make reasonable efforts, it is then a matter of what the Commonwealth Employment Service is required to take into account, and I think the Senate now knows what that is. I just think this assists us in that endeavour rather than hinders us.

—I would argue that this considerably restricts it. Again I ask the Minister some specific questions. Would cases where one partner is forced to move because of domestic violence constitute sufficient reason in the future?
—Yes.

—Would cases of other forms of violence, particular community violence, where people are actually forced to leave their community-a most unfortunate circumstance but one that I understand does infrequently occur-be sufficient reason?

—There is no way that the Government is going to insist on people staying somewhere where their physical safety is called into question. There is nothing more important than one's safety and capacity to move around freely. I am not sure what Senator Lees means by danger of violence from the community. I could perhaps envisage some situations of it. They would be very rare but certainly they would be taken into account, and if there is any case to justify it we would not apply this sanction.

—At present, the situation in Adelaide is that young people have been counselled and supported on the streets and advised that they should no longer be within that culture, particularly where drugs are involved. They have moved to Whyalla where, firstly, housing is available and, secondly, there is a very strong, supportive youth network. Under the current rules that are not as tight as these new ones, those people have had to go to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal to get benefits. Their benefits have been cut off because these people have been caught under this rule. Is this going to be the case under the new rules? The concern of those people who have been involved in these cases-and there have been two of them-is that this further tightening will make an appeal on the grounds of moving young people out of cities for their own benefit impossible to win.

—We had the same problems before with housing. Senator Lees may remember that this whole argument came about when, from memory, I think the Victorian housing commission-or whatever it is called in Victoria; they tend not to call themselves housing commissions these days as it is an old-fashioned phrase--
—An old-fashioned Sydney term.
—I plead guilty.
—Being an old- fashioned Sydney girl, I knew it.

—I would not call Senator Patterson old-fashioned. We first got into this argument when the Victorian housing commission was offering housing to people which was outside the metropolitan area-I cannot remember where. We had to take that into account then. There is no way that we will be disadvantaging people who are trying to get their lives together in the way that the honourable senator has just explained. I give the honourable senator a guarantee that that will be covered in the guidelines when they come out.

—Does that guarantee that when the housing authority actually offers houses in Millicent, Renmark, Mount Gambier and Whyalla, where there are vacancies, to someone who has been on its waiting list for months-in some cases in South Australia for years-they will not be cut off benefits if they take up that offer of adequate accommodation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are concentrating too much on housing. That is one factor, but one factor only. The person's whole individual circumstances will be taken into account, and housing is but one. The other circumstances to which the honourable senator referred-drugs or some imminent danger to the person, whatever it might be-are taken into account as well and the circumstances that the honourable senator is talking about will outweigh the other factors.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 7, pages 8 to 10, proposed section 519, line 22, (page 8) to line 4 (page 10), omit the section.

This amendment looks at the liquid assets test for the Job Search allowance. We are particularly concerned about the continuing impact of the combination of this and long waiting periods for young people. I refer the Minister to an Age article where a spokesperson from the Minister's office said that the Minister was considering some changes. I ask the Minister: what changes is he considering and is there a possibility that we will see some changes to the liquid assets test?

TALK.START.PARA: —The liquid assets test was debated in the chamber some time back. There has been a modification to the arrangements that were announced in the Budget which were carried here in the chamber. I do not think there is much point in going over the ground which we traversed then. The reality is that the liquid assets test was introduced in order to prevent payments being made to those people who earned fairly high incomes over part of the year. I think the modifications which were made to the test are pretty reasonable in protecting families, in particular. I do not think it is unreasonable-nor apparently did the Senate-that those people who have sufficient liquid funds should maintain themselves for a short period. Therefore, we reject the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this is voted on, I wish to say that it has been recognised by a wide variety of welfare agencies-particularly I note some comments by the Brotherhood of Saint Lawrence-that this is causing hardship. Five thousand dollars is not a considerable sum of money and when a person then has to wait weeks before receiving a benefit that amount is eroded considerably. We are in a situation now where unemployment will not last for a month or two.
