For many young people it is lasting years and that small nest egg that they had when they originally went onto unemployment benefits becomes more and more important as time goes on.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. Clause 7, page 8, after proposed subsection 519(1), insert the following subsection:
`` `(1a) Where:
(a) a person disposed of liquid assets of the person within 3 months before lodging a claim for job search allowance; and
(b) the person received no consideration, or inadequate consideration, in money or money's worth; and
(c) apart from the disposition, this section would have applied to the person;
this section applies to the person as if the
disposition had not been made.'.''.

This amendment picks up a matter which was canvassed with the Government when the liquid assets test was introduced. It seemed to us at that time-and it still does-that there is an inconsistency of approach in saying that we ought to limit the ability of an applicant to dispose of certain liquid assets to spouse or children, but that we ought to turn a blind eye if the assets are disposed of elsewhere. Our amendment, therefore, simply seeks to broaden the ambit so that we uphold the principle which the Government espouses- that is, if we are to have a liquid assets test that is to be effective, we ought to ensure that people cannot simply bypass it by disposing of assets to friends, relatives or anyone other than spouses or children. We, therefore, move this amendment in the spirit of trying to assist the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —If my memory serves me correctly, we debated this matter once before, did we not?
—We debated it publicly and privately and I think your position was that there was some substance in what we were putting. It was a question of how far back one ought to go.

—I think I remember saying at the time that, judging from cases that I had read, it is not necessarily the case that one can always trust spouses and children, in any event. I think that makes life difficult for those people who are trying to subvert these things. I think three months makes it virtually impossible. Many people will have absolutely no idea today that they might be unemployed in three months' time. I do not understand how we can instil future knowledge into someone today. If we could do that it would be a much better world. But we cannot, and that is why the Government cannot agree to the amendment.
—But you do it with respect to spouses and children.
—Spouses and children are, for most of us, there every day and putting assets to them--
—Oh!

—They are not there every day when one is down here. But the giving of assets to them can occur all the time. People are always looking at doing that and have done so. The truth is that in trying to set a test like this one says to oneself, `Do I set the test so broadly as to catch everyone I want to catch and some others I never intended to, or do I set it narrowly?'. I think we are much better off opting for narrowness here. It would be grossly unfair to go further than we are going.

—I do not want to prolong this debate, but the logic in what the Minister says is that a person might quite honestly dispose of assets to his or her immediate family without having any intention of trying to defeat the intent of this legislation and without even being able to anticipate it. I would think that very few people are in the business of giving assets away, other than to spouses or children. To the extent that they do, surely they are much more likely to be lacking the bona fides. Therefore, it ought to apply to them at least, rather than the other way around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the problem here is that we are trying to catch people who see the Act referring to partners and children and who then seek to get around it. The difficulty is still the three-month period. I think it is too tough. We can debate it all day; I just think it is too tough.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5. Clause 7, page 10, proposed subsection 520 (2), line 18, omit ``12 months'', substitute ``9 months''.
This amendment simply changes 12 months to nine months in respect of registration with the Commonwealth Employment Service, which is consistent with our overall approach.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6. Clause 7, page 11, proposed paragraph 521(2) (c), line 15, omit ``12 months'', substitute ``9 months''.

Amendment No. 6 reduces the period for which a person needs to have previously been on the Job Search allowance from 12 months to nine months. It relates to eligibility for that allowance and exemptions, and makes reference to the normal 12-month Commonwealth Employment Service rule. We say that that rule ought to be a nine-month rule.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 7, page 12, proposed subsection 523 (1), line 35, omit ``not required'', substitute ``taken''.
(2) Clause 7, page 13, proposed subparagraph 523 (2) (a) (i), lines 9 and 10, omit ``remote area'' substitute ``an area described in subparagraph 522 (2) (a) (iii)''.

(3) Clause 7, page 13, proposed subsection 523 (2), line 26, omit ``the person is not required'', substitute ``then, unless the person has been notified of a requirement under subsection 522 (2) in relation to the period, the person is taken''.

The first of the three amendments omits the words `not required' and substitutes the word `taken' from proposed subsection 523(1). That has the effect of positively stating that a person is taken to have satisfied the activity test, where the conditions in the proposed subsection are met.

The second amendment refers to the concept of remote areas and remoteness. It is trying to bring in some symmetry between the reference in proposed section 522 to the activity test and to remoteness in proposed subsection 523 (2). We are trying to clarify this matter and refer to an area where there is no locally accessible labour market and no locally accessible vocational training. We are just giving ourselves some consistency.

The third amendment omits from proposed subsection 523 (2) the words `the person is not required' and substitutes the words `then, unless the person has been notified of a requirement under subsection 522 (2) in relation to the period, the person is taken'. That corrects an oversight in translating the equivalent provisions from one Act to the other. I do not think that it is necessary to explain that.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are tidying up amendments and we support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 7, page 13, proposed subsection 524 (1), lines 29 and 30, omit ``a person who has not turned 18''.
4. Clause 7, page 13, proposed paragraph 524 (1) (b), line 33, omit ``3'', substitute ``2''.
5. Clause 7, page 13, proposed paragraph 524 (2) (a), line 37, omit ``20'', substitute ``65''.

This goes back to the question of voluntary work. I will just explain again the way in which the current Act has been interpreted by the Department of Social Security. The 20 days has not been taken by the Department to mean 20 days in a block. It has been taken as written to mean 20 days in the same calendar year; in other words, less than half a day a week. Totals have been kept in some offices and therefore people have been at risk of losing their benefits once that total is accumulated.

Therefore, looking at the way in which the current Act is interpreted, the Australian Democrats are moving this amendment to increase the number of days from 20 to 65 and, in particular, to allow this option to people other than those under the age of 18. At the moment the Bill reads, `certain allowees under 18 engaged in voluntary work'. I ask the Minister: why has the Government limited this exemption to people under the age of 18 and over the age of 55?

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of persons under 18 being allowed 20 days in the year, that is just trying to recognise the difficulties that these young people face with no work experience. It is hoped that by allowing some voluntary work of this kind, they might in some way be more attractive to a prospective employer. I accept that that will be the case.
—I am asking the Minister why it is limited to under 18s. We agree totally that under 18s should have the opportunity to not just do 20 days but 65 days, but why is it limited to them?
—Persons over the age of 55 are able to undertake voluntary work. We are not just limiting it to just 18-year olds. I am not quite with Senator Lees on that point.
—Between the ages of 19 and 54.

—I see. I apologise to Senator Lees. I did not quite realise the import of what she was saying. If she is asking why it does not apply to a person who is, say, 19 or 20 years of age, I think it is a matter of looking at where the special disadvantage lies. If I were to set a limit at 20 years of age on this, I am sure that people would say, `Why not 24?', et cetera. It is very difficult. People cannot pass activity tests in particular if they are doing voluntary work all the time. If we say that all people can do voluntary work, the opportunities for training and for ensuring that people are looking for work will be lost. The whole purpose of this is to make sure that they are not.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly-

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate agree with his colleague Senator Walsh that the new Treasurer is too indecisive for the job? Will the new Treasurer be unable to resist pressures on the Government to spend its way out of trouble, thereby exacerbating our country's fundamental imbalances on the current account? Will the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will indeed take immediate measures to restore responsible fiscal policy following the dangerous relaxation that has occurred over the past three years under ex-Treasurer Keating?

—As to the first question about whether I agree with Senator Walsh in his comments about Mr Kerin, the answer is no. Of course, Senator Walsh and I agree on some issues and disagree on others, but the answer to the question is no. As to the question whether the Government will now endeavour to spend its way out of trouble, the answer is no. The answer to that question is no because we saw the precedent of the Fraser Government, which in 1982-83 sought to spend its way out of trouble and left this country with an enormous deficit, high unemployment and high inflation. We saw the dangers of all that in a sensible and moderate way, not like the current Opposition, which sees the dangers of the Fraser period as the dangers of a government that did not have the guts to do anything. It now goes around mouthing tough rhetoric out of the lips of the Dollar Sweets man, Mr Costello, and out of the mouths of Ian McLachlan and people like that. It is tough and not very understanding rhetoric. The crisis which the Opposition faces is whether it can screw its courage to the sticking place. Everybody in the community doubts whether this Opposition would actually do these things.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We have now had three minutes or so of an utterly irrelevant response to the question. I invite you to say that, when the Leader of the Government in the Senate is asked about current policy positions and Mr Kerin in particular, it is irrelevant for him to talk about what might have happened almost a decade ago and what particular view of the world might be held on this side of the chamber. If the Minister chooses not to address the question, he ought to do us all a favour and keep quiet.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Senator Alston is always keen that I do him a favour because, without pointers from us, he is nothing.

—Mr President, on the point of order: with respect, you have ruled on this point before. Indeed, the matter the Minister is dealing with is outside his portfolio responsibility. I ask you to uphold a ruling that you have made previously. I am sure that I can find the date of it if you would like me to.
—Order! There is no point of order. I will decide whether Senator Button is debating the issue. At the moment, I will allow him to continue.
—In the heat of political debate--
—It is not a debate; it is an answer to a question.

—I understand that, but Senator Hill wants the luxury of interjecting all the time and Senator Alston wants the luxury of taking points of order because he is made a bit uncomfortable by what I am saying. The third part of Senator Short's question related to whether we would restore fiscal policy and the Government's performance in terms of the size of the surplus and deficit which applied prior to the recession. That is the essential point which he is asking me.
—No, that is not right. I said three years ago, which was well prior to it.

—All right, three years ago. If we are going back in time, let us again look at fiscal policy when the Opposition was in government, which was an absolute disgrace. In terms of fiscal policy, even though there have been enormous impositions made on the Budget by unemployment benefits and lower corporate tax returns, et cetera, those are structural things. The structural surplus of this Government remains in place. In terms of departure from fiscal policy, there have really been two major items of expenditure-the tax cuts which applied from the beginning of this year and the--
—Unfunded.
—Senator Short says `unfunded'. He applies our criteria-excellent; that is very good.
—What are you talking about?

—Senator Short comes from a position where his Party's credibility in terms of fiscal policy is rock bottom as a political party. Those opposite then say to us that we should abide by the standards of three years ago-the standards set by this Government. I am saying to Senator Short that there have been impositions on the Budget as a result of the recession, which he is fully aware of; that there are some large expenditure outlay items in the Budget, such as the tax cuts and the support for the wool industry; and that, apart from that, there is very little change to the fiscal policy adopted by the Government except in so far as it is affected by outside circumstances.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. In light of that non-answer and the statements made, and in view of Senator Button's belief, which very sadly he stated in the Senate yesterday, that `politics is not a fine art in which the truth is always paramount', can the Senate any longer have any confidence that what the Minister has said deserves any more credibility than the example that has been set by his Prime Minister and ex-Treasurer?

—Senator Short is having fantasies. He asks: can the Senate have any confidence?. What a question to ask me! That is not a supplementary question; it is just a grubby little political point, which I will come to later in Question Time.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Japan, led by Mr Kiichi Murayama, the Vice-Speaker of the House of Representatives. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take pleasure in welcoming members of the delegation to the Senate. I trust that their time in Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

—Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support comment upon press reports about claims by the Tasmanian Liberal shadow Minister for transport, Mr Rundle, that the Federal Government offer at the recent Premiers Conference included a proposal to reduce the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The claims by Mr Rundle are hysterical nonsense, with no basis in fact at all. I do not know where he dragged that story from. Over the past 18 months I have received continual representations from all the Labor Tasmanian senators, including, I might add, my ministerial colleague Senator Tate, on the issue of the freight equalisation scheme. The Federal Government remains fully committed to it.

ANSWER.PARA: The scheme provides essential assistance to Tasmanian industry and $36.5m was provided under this scheme in the last financial year to assist in the equalisation of freight rates for Tasmanian industry. No consideration whatsoever is being given by the Federal Government to reducing the assistance provided under this scheme.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR SOCIAL SECURITY: OVERSEAS VISIT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Would the Minister please explain to the Senate what aspects of his portfolio responsibilities took him to Avellino and Salerno, Italy, earlier this year? Was it in response to any official invitations?
—The swallows.

—No, that was Capestrano. Will the Minister table any such documents? Is it a fact that the Minister was not the first Minister by a long shot to be attracted to Salerno to see the results of Australian assistance? Is it a fact that the stated purpose of the trip was to receive the grateful thanks of local residents for Australian aid as a result of an earthquake which occurred well over a decade ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the earthquake was quite a while ago. I cannot remember exactly when. But if one drives through Avellino the staggering thing is that the effects of it are still everywhere to be seen. That community was totally devastated by it. It was obviously an event of mammoth proportion in Italy. My understanding is that the hospital at Avellino had previously been visited by Senator Grimes once and by Mrs Hawke.

ANSWER.PARA: I would imagine that every few years, for a while yet, the Italian community and the people of Avellino would be expecting the odd visit from an Australian Minister and they got one. So far as Salerno is concerned, I will tell the honourable senator what I did in Salerno. I arrived when it was dark and left early in the morning. All I did was sleep there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question: I was not particularly interested in Senator Richardson's sleeping habits.
—Why did you ask it then?

—Just a moment and I will tell the Senate. What we are much more interested in is why was there a need to travel to the south of Italy at all? Was it in response to any official invitation? Will the Minister please come clean about the real reason for going down there to visit a place which is absolutely ancient history and which has been done to death by others with more responsibility than his own? In other words, did the Minister have any official duty to perform or was it just another junket?
—I have not heard of either Avellino or Benevento being high on the list of junketeers. These are not the garden spots of Italy!
—Why did you go there?
—I went to Avellino to visit a hospital and I went to Benevento to visit an old people's home-
—Funded by the Australian taxpayers.
—Yes, as Senator Tate said, they were funded by the Australian taxpayers. It is that simple.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Has the Government any plans to bring forward elements of its future capital works program to help ameliorate the effects of the recession by boosting the construction industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the size and composition of the Government's capital works program is a matter which will be considered by the Government in formulating the 1991-92 Budget. The Government does not see a general case for increasing government spending as a way out of the current recession. In formulating the coming Budget, the Government will be guided by the need to maintain budgetary policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Any further loosening may provide a temporary stimulus to activity but this is likely to have its major impact at the same time as the economy is recovering and therefore jeopardising the goal of a sustainable recovery. The Government has indicated its commitment to preserving the structural integrity of the Budget during this recession while not attempting to offset the cyclical fiscal deterioration. The Government is not inclined to proposals which would undermine this principle. In any case, new capital works are only considered by the Government if they are economically justified; that is, if they will provide a satisfactory rate of return.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health to an article on page 3 of today's Australian entitled `Unofficial AIDS drugs to be imported privately'. The article reports that exasperation with the nation's inappropriate drug approval system has prompted the AIDS Council of New South Wales to establish a system to make it easier for AIDS sufferers to import the AIDS-fighting drugs DDC and DDI which are currently not available in this country. I ask the Minister: first, does the Minister consider it a desirable state of affairs that a system which promotes the precedent of patients having to pay for HIV and AIDS drugs is being established? Secondly, can the Minister understand how the frustrations and anger of HIV-AIDS sufferers, their families and supporters have led to such a move? Finally, if, as is expected, the drugs DDC and DDI are approved in the United States of America within the next eight weeks, can the Minister give Australian HIV and AIDS sufferers a guarantee that they will not have to wait the 2 1/2 years that they had to wait in the case of AZT for the drugs to be approved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Brian Howe, does understand the frustration experienced by those who are suffering by either carrying the HIV virus or actually having contracted fullblown AIDS. No doubt, their families, supporters and friends-the networks which are built around those who are suffering this particular disease-would also be likely to experience that sense of frustration because of the possibility of not having drugs which can assist, as much as they would wish, in combating the AIDS virus.

ANSWER.PARA: I do believe that the Australian Government, and the whole of the Australian Parliament, has been very supportive in the management of the HIV virus in Australia. In Australia, we do have an excellent record of care for people suffering in this particular way. This is not least, of course, because Medicare itself provides free and comprehensive care for such people; unlike countries such as the United States which is put up by some lobby groups as apparently some sort of model that we should follow in relation to the care of those who suffer from HIV or AIDS.

There is no doubt that there is a sense of urgency amongst those sufferers and their supporters about the need for access to any drug which might assist them. It is important to emphasise that there is only one treatment presently approved in the United States specifically to act on the virus HIV and that is zidovudine or AZT. This treatment is also approved in Australia with a government subsidy. In the United States, most people must pay to access the drug or go without. That is something which has to be emphasised to those who are sufferers from this disease.

It has also been suggested, not by Senator Lees but by some of the lobby groups, that around 100 drugs are available in the United States compared with only seven in Australia. That is also misleading as most of these are treatments for opportunistic infections associated with HIV. Again, many of these are available in Australia through a variety of measures to those patients who need them.

Statements which imply that the AIDS drugs have been approved in the United States but not in Australia are misleading. Once again, Senator Lees has not said so, but some have claimed that DDI and DDC, for example, are available. But they are not yet approved for marketing in the United States, as Senator Lees indicated in her question. Issues relating to the situation are being looked at by former Senator Peter Baume in his review which is expected to report to the Minister on 1 July. I believe that may be a very helpful review as far as getting access to these drugs is concerned.

Senator Lees will be aware that an application by a drug company to trial DDC in Australia was agreed to by the Federal Government in January this year but this did not proceed because there were not enough patients in the right circumstances to contribute to the trial. I am sure that both Mr Howe and the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Staples, are concerned that Australians should have early access to creditable treatments. They have made considerable changes in the interests of early access to those treatments. When one combines the fact that Australia does subsidise drugs that are approved for marketing, with changes recently made to import regulations to enable individuals to have access to drugs not approved for marketing-and, of course, they have to pay-one sees that the Government is most concerned to alleviate the suffering of those who have contracted the virus, and that it will continue to try to ensure that sufferers have early access to any drug that can help in fighting this terrible disease.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services been drawn to correspondence from the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works (PWC), to which was attached a report from Australian Construction Services on the use of energy efficient light globes in government buildings? Does the Minister agree with the view expressed in the report that if all government buildings were to be fitted with energy efficient light globes it would be detrimental to the future of Australia's only globe manufacturing industry in Newcastle? Is the Minister therefore prepared to initiate discussions with the various levels of government and the manufacturing company concerned with a view to securing all governments agreeing to guarantee that all buildings will include energy efficient light globes, provided that the company agrees to expand its activities to manufacturing these globes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Works Committee has written to me raising some concerns over the future viability of the Australian lamp manufacturing industry unless, as it has expressed to me, it is encouraged to invest in additional plant to broaden its productive scope. In its correspondence, the PWC asked that I consider using the Government's public purchasing policy in conjunction with the Government's so-called green team to provide an incentive to the local lamp industry. The particular concern that the Committee has is that energy efficient globes can be imported to replace the globes manufactured in Australia. As Senator Devereux has indicated, such action would place in jeopardy the Australian lamp manufacturing industry, particularly since energy efficient globes are not produced here.

ANSWER.PARA: The two globes that can be used-the compact fluorescent lamp (CFL) and the high technology fluorescent lamp-are produced overseas. The compact fluorescent lamp is a suitable substitute for the domestic incandescent or tungsten filament lamp. Although the CFL is expensive-it costs about $20, compared with 75c for a regular globe-it uses something like one-fifth the energy of and lasts something like six times longer than a normal globe.

The other lamp which has been suggested to me, the high technology fluorescent lamp, has been developed to provide a marginal energy reduction. It is also three or four times the price of the Australian standard product. The higher costs are, of course, attributable to the advanced technology used in their manufacture. I am also advised by my Department that they are imported because the Australian lamp industry does not have the technology or the market to justify the establishment of facilities in Australia to manufacture these energy efficient lamps. It should be recognised in this instance that it is the practice of most Australian companies and government to use Australian manufactured fluorescent lamps. Commercial office buildings, as well as government buildings, have used those lamps.

It should also be noted that a number of principal initiatives have already been employed to contribute to energy efficient lighting in government-owned and private sector buildings. The three main features in this endeavour to cut back on energy consumption are: firstly, the design of light fixtures has been modified to direct, distribute and use light efficiently; secondly, there has been a move towards the placement of switches to allow easier local control to save energy and, thirdly, there has been the installation of automatic controls. In fact, some of these experiments have been so successful that they have been applied by Australian Construction Services in buildings recently. Savings accruing from such modifications, in terms of energy costs, are as much as 50 per cent.

Senator Devereux mentioned the Public Works Committee's suggestions. In response to the Committee's correspondence, I have asked the Environmental Futures Group-the so-called green team-to investigate the scope of enhancing the viability of the local lighting manufacturing industry in the context of the production of energy efficient lighting. This reference from me sits very well within the green team's proposal to conduct an energy audit into office buildings with lighting being, of course, a major factor of that audit. Following the report from the Environmental Futures Group, it would be my intention to raise this matter with State and local governments to ensure that we can meet the twin objectives that have been expressed by the Public Works Committee-that of providing lighting and also ensuring the continuing viability of local manufacturing.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR SOCIAL SECURITY: OVERSEAS VISIT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware that, even after he has made the most of his opportunity to correct what he described as Senator Alston's failure to tell the whole truth about his $130,000 overseas trip, the public remains so unconvinced by his explanation that yesterday the Adelaide Advertiser had to devote a special section of its `Letters to the Editor' column to the many letters it has received expressing outrage at his behaviour? Those letters used terms such as `exorbitant', `lost touch', `abuse of position', `disgust' and many more. Will the Minister now eat humble pie and admit that, notwithstanding any claimed benefit to Australia from his trips, a more frugal travel budget should have been adopted, especially by a Minister for Social Security? Will he apologise to the Australian people for his self-indulgent, unnecessary extravagance?

—I think that we are talking about yesterday's news; but I do not mind saying it again: I went on those trips for the purposes of signing agreements and conducting negotiations that will save Australia millions of dollars. I will continue to do so whenever it is necessary.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BIRD HAZARD INVESTIGATION UNIT OF CIVIL AVIATION AUTHORITY

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to the announcement last Friday of major job losses in the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). Can the Minister confirm that the Bird Hazard Investigation Unit is to be disbanded? Is this disbandment a result of the unit's consistent professional advice that the area between the existing and proposed runway at Sydney Airport must be filled to minimise the risk of bird strike-advice that the pro-third runway CAA board virtually disowned in its submission on the draft environmental impact statement on the proposed third runway? Who will now perform the assessment and advice functions, as distinct from the monitoring and recording functions, at present carried out by the Bird Hazard Investigation Unit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I cannot confirm that. What is happening at the moment, as I have advised the Senate previously, is that the CAA has undergone an exhaustive and complete evaluation of all of its operations. At the end of last month, it produced a comprehensive and detailed report covering every single aspect of its activities across Australia. The organisation is currently going through the very difficult process of implementing those recommendations.

ANSWER.PARA: Only this morning, in this building, I addressed a seminar of industry groups involved in the aviation industry. A significant number of senior figures in the aviation industry expressed, only this morning, their full support for the operation that the CAA is currently engaged in. There has been no specific or particular attention paid to the singling out of this particular unit for special attention. No final decision has been taken on what will happen to it or, indeed, any of the other sections of the operations of the CAA that have been evaluated in precisely the same way. The negotiations that are going on now, as to how the implementation will actually occur, I would think, will take at least several months to complete. No final decision will be made until those consultations are concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. The Prime Minister has confessed that he believes it was acceptable for him to mislead the people of Australia at the last election--
—No prompting, Johnny Button.
—Senator Button does not have to prompt him; the Minister is quite capable of answering the question.
—Order! Senator Lewis, ask your question.

—The Prime Minister has confessed that he believes it was acceptable for him to mislead the people of Australia at the last election about his leadership deal with Mr Keating, otherwise `we would not have won the election'. I ask Senator Tate, as the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, whether he believes that it is acceptable for a Prime Minister of Australia deliberately to mislead people about a matter which the Prime Minister of Australia considers of such importance that it would or could cause him to lose an election if the people knew the truth.
—Order! I do not really see how that applies to the Minister's portfolio. If the Minister wishes to answer it, the Minister can answer it.

—I believe that the Prime Minister has already indicated his own assessment of the situation when he expressed regret. I believe that I cannot usefully add anything to his expression of his sentiment concerning that incident.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has not answered the question. The Minister said something about what the Prime Minister may or may not have done. I now ask the Minister, arising out of his evasion of the question: does he, the Minister for Justice, accept that in politics in Australia the end justifies the means and in an election--
—Talk to Jeff Kennett, why don't you?
—We understand that you accept that, because you have already said that, Senator Ray. I am asking Senator Tate--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I understand that one has to take a cut and thrust approach here; but I did not interject. Senator Lewis pointed a finger at me and he said that he understood that I accept the statement. I did not interject.
—There is no point of order. Senator Lewis, ask the supplementary question.
—I was pointing to Senator Ray, who has already made his position clear on this matter, not Senator Button, who has also made his position clear.
—Order! Ask the supplementary question.

—That is why I am asking Senator Tate to make his position clear on the matter. Does he accept that the end justifies the means and that in an election whatever a Prime Minister of Australia says should be taken as equivocal?
—I do not believe that the end justifies the means; I never have.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I appreciate the acclamation, Mr President, for my third question this week.

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators clapping--

TALK.START.PARA: —As today is World Environment Day, can the Minister inform the Senate of the environmental initiatives undertaken by the Department of Administrative Services (DAS)? Can the Minister inform the Senate how he sees the role of DAS in relation to Government policy in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must agree with my colleagues who have indicated that this is a good question, a timely one and one which is quite appropriate. In asking this question, Senator Childs does recognise-I am getting a lot of assistance from behind me in answering this question-as I do, that the Department of Administrative Services does have a critical role in ensuring that the goods and services used by government do conform with the wider government policy. For instance, in respect of that broad objective, on a number of previous occasions I have outlined the way in which my Department integrates its purchasing policy with the industry policy of my colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button.

ANSWER.PARA: In a similar way, DAS has an important role in ensuring that the goods and services provided by it conform to this Government's environmental objectives. It is best placed to perform that role because of the central role that DAS has as a provider of basic services. As a consequence of such a role, DAS also has an enormous potential to influence positively the operations of other public sector departments and agencies and also to develop domestic industries which can meet such demands.

We have already used our position to encourage environmentally sensitive practices and the Department will continue to develop this potential in order to make a positive contribution to the Government's environmental objectives. The Department of Administrative Services is not a newcomer to environmental issues. Over a number of years, we have been promoting environmentally sensitive practices throughout the public sector. Many of DAS's divisions continue to work on environmental issues.

In fact, yesterday in Question Time in response to a question from Senator Bell, I informed the Senate of DAS's initiatives in the area of recycled paper and products and made reference to the Environmental Futures Group, a group which has the role of making recommendations and examining ways in which DAS can develop environmentally responsible workplaces. It has the role of making recommendations on the promotion of the use of suitable goods and services and, of course, it has a role in making recommendations on how DAS can contribute to the Government's environmental objectives.
Another recent ground-breaking initiative of the Department is DASCEM, the DAS Centre for Environmental Management. Three divisions of DAS are partners in DASCEM.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is Negus, one of your mates.

—I am sure that Senator Parer knows about this. DASCEM offers a complete appraisal and management service for built environments and contaminated sites. There are also a number of other initiatives within DAS. The scientific services laboratory is currently working on a project to alleviate the threat to the ozone layer with its ground-breaking research into a better, safer alternative to the firefighting gas halon 1301. The Australian Government Analytical Laboratories is working on environmental hazards including asbestos in buildings. A part of the Department which does have a fundamental role in this area is Australian Construction Services (ACS), which has undertaken studies into the use of rainforest timbers in construction and also energy conservation in buildings, a factor which I mentioned in response to a previous question from Senator Devereux. In fact, energy audits in government buildings undertaken by ACS have saved already not only millions of dollars but also scarce resources. I should also indicate that another section of DAS organises ecologically sound recycling or disposal of petrol, oil, tyres and other waste products, such as paper and printing offsets.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, DAS does have a central role in realising the Government's broader policy objectives. As I have indicated, it does so on the industry front. It also has a central role, not only in terms of being a leader within the public sector, as I indicated, to other government departments but also in supporting local initiatives by industry. Those roles dovetail pretty well to ensure that, as a department, we do play an environmentally sensitive role.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to his widely reported statement in defence of the Prime Minister at the weekend in which he said, `No absolute promise in politics is absolute'. How does the Minister reconcile this statement when, during the adjournment debate in this place on 29 November 1990, in reply to my colleague Senator Tambling, the Minister also said, `When Ministers genuinely promise, they should deliver'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other night I said that there was no absolute promise in politics, and that is right. I did not say that some people who give absolute promises in politics do not keep them. I am certain that that applies to very many people; they do keep their promises in politics. But it is not an absolute law of politics.
—Should they?
—Senator Alston interjects, `Should they?'. Just to put this into context, seeing that both Senator Alston and I represent the great State of Victoria--
—The once great State.
—No, not once great; still great State.
—The Albania of the south, you called it.

—That is a reference to its foreign policy. I will just remind honourable senators of what has happened in the past two weeks in terms of the credibility of the Liberal Party of Australia. No-one is arguing that the credibility of the Australian Labor Party is travelling well on this other issue. No-one is arguing that. We have the new leader of the Liberal Party in Victoria who ambushed Alan Brown and defeated him for the leadership. These things happen on both sides of politics.
—It is about Ministers.
—It is just about Ministers; laws apply only to Ministers according to Senator Alston.
—That is what you were asked.

—I will answer the question in my own way, without Senator Alston's assistance. The situation there, as Mr Kennett said, is that he would invoke his fourth step and would make sure that no defeated or retiring Labor member would have his or her superannuation granted.
—He is mad.
—Order!

—But not only did that flow against the whole promise of the Liberal Party never to support retrospective legislation-leaving that aside-but when challenged he went on air and said, `If I ever resile from this I will resign'. One would have thought that overnight he might think that through and later retract it. But he repeated it in another interview he did the next day. `Just to show I am serious', said Mr Kennett, `I will resign if this legislation--'

—On a point of order, Mr President. I understand the Minister's concern to mount a political argument, but I ask you, Sir, to ask the Minister whether it is not the fact that what Mr Kennett said was, `If I get into government and do not legislate to remove those entitlements, I will resign'. He said nothing else.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I will deal with the point of order, Mr President, because it is a reasonably interesting point that Senator Alston has raised. I will not take too much time but, because Senator Alston has interrupted the flow, let me go back to what occurred. Mr Kennett said, `If I don't legislate I will resign'. However, now Mr Kennett has come out and said that he will not legislate. Therefore, which of the promises is to be believed? He cannot win because, if he withdraws the threat, he cannot in fact carry it out. The implication of what Senator Alston is saying is that the withdrawal of the threat is not going to be honoured and, when Mr Kennett gets in, he will pass that sort of legislation. No senator opposite in all this period got up here and properly dissociated himself or herself from one of the most sleazy acts of political blackmail in the history of politics in Australia.
—Should he withdraw it?

—He should have been reprimanded. Senators opposite have sat in here and passed superannuation legislation. They have agreed that that legislation should not be discriminatory. They have passed regulations and legislation in this place about non-discriminatory superannuation. But the moment political opportunism and party discipline come to the fore they all shut up and principle goes out the window. Someone can come into the Victorian Parliament and retrospectively legislate on superannuation and senators opposite support that retrospectivity there, but they never did it in regard to the tax bludgers and dodgers.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is whipping himself into a lather over Victoria. We are happy to debate matters concerning Victoria at any time, but the question that was put to the Minister was whether the Prime Minister lied during the last election campaign and should he apologise. I ask you, Sir, to make sure that the Minister answers that matter.
—Order!

—Mr President, I was not asked that question. It was a question about a comment I made the other night, and a comment in the Senate. We are not referring to Federal or State or any other politics; we are talking about politics as a whole. Senator Calvert asked me, `Are there any absolute promises in politics?', and I have said no, but I have also said that some people who make absolute promises in politics always will keep their word in that regard. There is no inconsistency in the two statements.

ANSWER.PARA: The inconsistency lies with the hypocrites opposite, not willing to dissociate themselves from one of the most gross distortions in Victorian political history, where Mr Kennett said that he would retrospectively take superannuation from the defeated members of parliament-not the successful ones but the defeated ones. He then said absolutely, `Take my word, I will resign if I don't legislate' and then, like a sleazy cur dog, later on he slips into the press and says a la Nixon `That is no longer operative'.

What do senators opposite say about that? They have never been quoted publicly about it. They have never asked questions about absolute promises in politics in relation to Mr Kennett and many others. What all this is about is where is the consistency in the Opposition's position in the questions that they seek to ask here? I can assure Senator Calvert of one thing: there is no inconsistency in my two statements, that is, that there is no such thing as an absolute promise in politics, which Mr Kennett and many others have proved, but some people who make absolute promises can always be relied on to keep them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer and I also thank him for enlightening us on the situation in Victoria. But in the light of the last comment that Senator Ray made, I ask whether he believes that the Prime Minister's promise to the former Treasurer was genuine.

—As I said the other night, it is always the case that circumstances change and that led me on to make the point that there are no absolute promises in politics. That is why it is very unwise for anyone to make an absolute promise in those particular terms. There are a couple of senators sitting on the front bench opposite as a result of promises. During the Howard-Peacock thing it was very interesting sitting on this side and watching who moved from the front bench to the back bench straight afterwards, and who came down. But no promises were made, were they? Were any promises made? Does any senator opposite want to deny that? Do some of those who went over to the Peacock camp want to say that no promises were made to induce them to vote? I start to believe most people within my peripheral vision here on that, but not some others. So what were the promises made down at Dolce Vita by the plotters? What were they? Come clean on them. Who got dudded and who did not get dudded?
—On a point of order, Mr President: the question had nothing to do with promises; it had to do with lies.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I was about to wind up but Senator Walters is trying to wind me up again. I am simply asking: during the Howard-Peacock thing what promises were made? Were they all kept? Who crossed sides because of those promises and who got dudded? That is a story that we will read in some of the memoirs of senators opposite in a few years' time.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, and I suggest that it is time the Senate turned its attention to the unemployed people out there after this selective morality mud slinging. I refer the Minister to press reports describing the new Treasurer as one who is more inclined to manage the economy out of trouble rather than leave it to the `do nothing' level playing field. I ask the Minister: can we now expect the Government to make employment its top economic priority by using specific targeted measures, in particular the phasing out of payroll tax, which is a tax on employment, and placing banks under the Prices Surveillance Authority to achieve lower interest rates? Secondly, can the Minister advise which other measures the Government is planning to use to reduce unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Senator Spindler's question, he has been quite specific about two points. I point out to Senator Spindler that payroll tax is a tax on employment, but it is a tax raised by the States. Without some extraordinary measures being taken by the Commonwealth Government in terms of raising alternative tax revenue, there could be no measures to totally wipe out payroll tax which, I think, in some States amounts to one-third of their budgeted revenue. So, it is not a matter that is susceptible to easy solution.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the question of placing the banks under the aegis of the Prices Surveillance Authority, I answered a question about this from Senator Spindler last week. It is the role of the Reserve Bank to ensure that the operation of the banking system is sound, and I do not think that the new Treasurer would have anything to add to that.

. As far as the importance of reducing unemployment is concerned, I remind Senator Spindler that interest rates have come down 7 1/2 per cent, inflation is down, wage growth has been held in check, structural reforms are continuing and all those measures will begin to take effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Waterfront reform is falling down.

—No, that was a silly interjection; that was not necessary. Whether there are any supplementary measures of a marginal nature which might be taken is a matter for the Government to consider in the Budget context.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I appreciate what the Minister is saying, that certainly effects are being felt and that the inflation rate is down. However, it is quite clear that the unemployment rate is not down; it is close to one million. When we get the figures tomorrow, I suspect that that figure will be up again. The question remains: is the Government prepared to make the unemployed people pay for its failed economic policy?

—I have answered that question on numerous occasions here. The Government deeply regrets the current level of unemployment which is due to misjudgment in respect of the onset of the recession, which is due to the rural crisis, which is due to the behaviour of the banks and a variety of other matters.
—Is it anything to do with Government policy?
—I do not know whether Senator Short has wax in his ears or what. I just said, in answering the question--
—You buried it.

—I buried it, did I? No, it is Senator Short that I am going to bury. It will take a while but it is Senator Short whom I am going to bury. I did not bury that; it was the first point I made in the answer to the question. In so far as Senator Spindler's question relates to concern about unemployment, that is shared. At this point I cannot add anything to the answer which I originally gave.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Does the Government recognise the importance, both environmental and agricultural, of the Great Artesian Basin, which covers areas in three different States? Is the Government aware of a proposal by the Queensland Government to put a toxic waste dump on top of the Great Artesian Basin at Miles and does the Government recognise an environmental risk if this proposal goes ahead?

—I do not know of the waste dump proposal. I do not know whether Minister Kelly knows of the proposal; I shall ask her. Obviously with any toxic dump there is an environmental risk of some dimension. Whether that risk is acceptable would depend upon the kind of dump planned and how the risk was going to be minimised. So I will try to find out the answer. Is the basin important? Of course it is important; no-one is going to argue that. No-one would want to see its environment despoiled. But I shall make inquiries of Minister Kelly.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Because of the many problems facing people living in isolated areas, particularly in Queensland, and the provision of health services, what action is the Government planning to improve the conditions of people living in rural areas, particularly in relation to health services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Jones has had a longstanding interest-I think he asked a question on this subject earlier this year-about the provision of health services in outback Queensland. The Federal Government is very well aware of the difficulty of people in those provincial and outback areas obtaining access to health services, and there are problems for the health professionals in those areas, whether one is talking about doctors, general practitioners or nurses. Quite often they have to operate with limited support services and provide a range of practice in fields that cover many more areas than would be the case with their city colleagues. I believe they ought to have that professional support and access to continuing education to enable them to undertake those wider fields of practice.

ANSWER.PARA: There are particular problems faced by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, who comprise a substantial proportion of the population in some of the more remote areas of Australia. Their health concerns are a matter of some concern to the Federal Government. Therefore, the Government is attempting to redress some of the problems faced by country people through a number of different mechanisms. Senator Jones will know that funding was provided for the Rural Doctors Association of Australia to organise the first national rural health conference, which was held in Toowoomba last February. The conference was attended by over 400 people, representing wide-ranging interests and health professionals from rural and remote areas of Australia.

A national health strategy endorsed by the conference has been accepted by the Australian Health Ministers Conference as a guide for future action. In addition, special support has been given through funding of initiatives designed to improve the education and training of health workers in country regions. For example, the Department of Community Services and Health has established the rural and remote areas unit located in Darwin, which after consultation with local communities will develop arrangements to improve access by rural and remote people to services provided by the Department. The Department is also setting up a pilot scheme in Queensland, which will be of great interest to Senator Jones, to examine options for regionalising its programs and services.

I am confident that real improvements can be achieved in improving the quality of health services to those people living in country Australia. I am sure that, with Senator Jones and other honourable senators keeping the pressure on governments at the Federal, State and local levels, there can, with consultation and cooperation, be a great improvement in health care for those in country Australia and in the circumstances of health professionals practising in those areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has indicated on a number of occasions that his proposed ad ban is designed to maintain public order by protecting the free and proper conduct of elections, which he says are at risk of corruption because of the high cost of advertising. I ask the Minister, firstly, whether he has concerned himself with the effect of blatant and outright lies by politicians, repeated again and again on news reports and in current affairs programs, on the conduct of free and proper elections in this country? Secondly, has the Minister indicated to the Prime Minister any concern over his having said to the Australian public that he would serve a full term when he knew that not to be true? Thirdly, what hope is there for the conduct of free and proper elections if the Prime Minister and other Ministers are prepared to lie to Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two legs to this question.
—Aren't you the Minister for public conscience?
—A few weeks ago someone called Senator Hill the fool on the hill and that is an appropriate tag.
—That was pretty weak.

—If Senator Hill wants an answer, I will give him one but I ask him to stop interjecting. If Opposition senators hold on for one second they will get an answer. In response to Senator Vanstone's question, she knows full well that the Government's initiatives in the area of broadcasting and disclosure of campaign expenditure go to the heart of the democratic process. I have stated consistently that we are about ensuring that the community knows precisely where the money comes from. We are also about ensuring that that close link, one that has been growing exponentially in Australia over recent years and one that has blossomed in other countries such as the United States, that growing dependence of political parties on corporate dollars, is broken.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been very much the concern of this Parliament, as has been instanced in a parliamentary report some two years ago, that government address that particular issue. That is the primary issue. It is one that we have pursued as the underlying basis for our initiatives in the broadcasting area.

Senator Vanstone asked whether I have or have not indicated something to the Prime Minister and what hope do we all have on the basis of the question she has asked. I think the best response that I can make to that is to refer to something Senator Spindler said a while ago. What members of the public are concerned about now, what they will be concerned about by the end of this week and next week and what they will be even more concerned about by the time we go to the next election is not what the Prime Minister did in 1988. What they are concerned about now and what they were concerned about-as they were in 1990-is what we as a government will present to them as our policy and as our objectives for the future.

We won the 1990 election because the public knew that we were better than the Opposition. When it comes to the next election, for so long as the Opposition keeps on dwelling in this little cesspool, for so long as its vision is retrospective rather than prospective, we will do the Opposition again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has indicated on many occasions that the reason for his proposed advertisement ban is to maintain public order by ensuring the proper conduct of free and fair elections. He has not been asked to say what he said to the Prime Minister about something but, quite specifically, what he said to the Prime Minister over his having told the Australian public one thing when he knew the other to be the case. The Minister has been asked what hope he holds for the conduct of free and proper elections, especially under his advertisement ban, if Ministers and the Prime Minister will lie to the media-and that will be repeated again and again on news and current affairs programs. That is what he has been asked and that is what the chamber wants an answer to.
—What I will say to the Opposition is that--
—The Opposition does not want an answer; I will just sit down.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during Question Time Senator Lewis asked me a question, the essential point of which was whether in an election the end justified the means. My response to that question was as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Without referring to the original question which Senator Lewis asked me, let me say that, in the context of an election, politics is not a fine art in which the truth is always paramount.
Opposition senators interjected saying, `Oh!', so Hansard records. I went on:

Just a minute! There are stacks of examples in Australian political life of people making misleading statements in the course of an election campaign. That has been apparent in each of the recent elections with which I have been associated and remains so.

I do not retreat from that answer, and I regret that it has been misinterpreted in a number of papers-not in all. I refer to some examples of what I meant by misleading statements in elections. Firstly, there was the massive deception by the Fraser Government in the 1983 election campaign as to the true state of the Australian economy. Secondly, there were the attempts in both 1983 and 1990 by the coalition to mislead in relation to the cost of its Medicare program. There are a number of other examples which I will give in the course of the forthcoming debate.

If Senator Lewis had phrased his question more precisely-for example, asking whether I believed that deliberate lying is an appropriate standard in Australian public life or whether in public life the end justifies the means-my answer to both those questions would have been no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Lewis on 4 June, relating to the Hawke Government.
For the sake of the Senate, let me repeat the opening paragraph of the question to Senator Button yesterday, in which I said:

The Prime Minister has confessed that he believed it was acceptable for him to mislead the people of Australia about his leadership deal with Mr Keating otherwise, according to the Prime Minister, `We would not have won the election'.

This goes to the kernel of democracy in this country. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was saying that this was not a minor lie; this was not even a major lie: this was a lie of such magnitude that, had the people known the truth, the Australian Labor Party would have lost the election. That is how big a lie it was. It was an absolute fraud on the people of Australia.

Senator Button is saying that he did not understand what I was saying. The Prime Minister himself had confessed, saying, `Look, if I had told the truth about this matter, the people of Australia would not have voted for us. We would have lost the election, so I had to lie'. Is that the basis of politics in this country? Is that the standard the Labor Party has set for this nation, this democratic nation with a famous tradition and history of democracy. Is that what those in the left wing and right wing of the Labor Party are saying? Is the state of affairs, the state of democracy, in this country such that we are pushed into the situation where a Prime Minister says, `Look, there is a fundamental matter here. I have to tell an absolute lie to the people of this nation. Otherwise, we won't get elected-and it is all right for me to do that because we do not want the other side to win.'? Is that the standard that the Government has set? Let me assure the Government that it is not the standard on our side of politics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support what Senator Lewis said. There are many broken promises of this Government. One reflects upon such statements as: there will be no gold tax; there will be no wine tax; there will be no capital gains tax; no child shall live in poverty; and so on. There have been many breaches of promise, but there is a distinction between those and what has occurred on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: In each instance the Prime Minister has said, `I did not lie to you when I made the statement. What has happened is that subsequently the circumstances have changed and, as a result of the changed circumstances, we have had to change our policy'. This is different. This is a circumstance in which the deal was made and, at the time of making the deal, the Prime Minister knew that he would be going to the Australian people and subsequently lying-and that is what happened.

The other distinction is that in this instance the Prime Minister has admitted that he lied, but he said that the end justified the means. He had the gall to stand up in the other place and say, `Yes, I lied to the Australian people because it was in their best interests. Had they known the truth, they may not have voted for me, so I admit I had to lie to them.' He does not even have the courage to say that he now apologises to the Australian people for that lie. He still stands by it. He says that it is justifiable and in their own interests. I suggest that there is something slightly frightening about a person who adopts that attitude, this demagogue who in some way puts himself above the rational interests of the Australian people, who enters into this pact with the former Treasurer to deceive the Australian people about what was to occur after the election. He so deceived them, and he now acknowledges that he deceived them. That is why Senator Lewis distinguishes this fraud from the previous many broken promises of this Prime Minister.

When Senator Button gets up to justify what he said or to try to explain away what he said yesterday, he selectively quotes from the last part of his answer. He does not quote from the former part. I will quote from the former part. Senator Button might refer to this when he participates in the debate today. As Senator Lewis said, he asked about the deliberate lie of the Prime Minister. What was the answer of Senator Button to that question? Trying to explain away the situation, he said:
With the wisdom of hindsight, I see the situation as understandable on the basis of the information which I currently have from reading newspapers and things of that kind.

So he is linking himself with the Prime Minister's lie. He is saying that in the circumstances which the Prime Minister put to us-that it was in the people's interest that they be deceived-he could understand what the Prime Minister had done. Later on, in answer to the supplementary question, Senator Button said:
. . . in the context of an election, politics is not a fine art in which the truth is always paramount.
That in itself is of great concern, but I draw attention to what he said earlier where, specifically in answer to the question about the fraud of the Prime Minister, he said:
With the wisdom of hindsight, I see the situation as understandable--

That is what I think is appalling. That is why I got up in the Senate this morning and gave notice of a motion calling upon the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button)-someone we have always regarded with some respect, I might say-to dissociate himself from what the Prime Minister has done, and to say that it is not too late to invite the Prime Minister himself to apologise to the Australian people for the deceit that he has performed and at least start trying to clean up his act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add some brief comments to what has been said about Senator Button's answer during Question Time yesterday. The supplementary question that was asked of Senator Button by Senator Lewis was quite clear: does the end justify the means? It was the answer to that supplementary question that Senator Button got dreadfully wrong yesterday. I have to say that when I listened to Senator Button today, I rather hoped that he had seen the light and had seen what terribly low standards he had pitched on his Government by that answer yesterday. Then I re-read what he said.

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed that Senator Button's final comment was that misleading of people had been apparent `in each of the recent elections with which I have been associated and remain so'. He was referring to the elections since 1983. I regret to say that through this exercise that Senator Button has embarked upon today to try to fix up the record, in some senses, he has made it even more grubby. What he referred to yesterday, of course, was the misleading statements and lies that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made successively in all elections since 1983; Senator Button yesterday was not referring to elections in the 1970s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Button speaks to the motion that Senator Lewis has moved that the Senate take note of Senator Button's answer-this deplorable situation in which the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has tried to tidy up a gross statement that he made in answer to Senator Lewis's question yesterday-I wish to add a few remarks about the sequence of events that we have seen this week and the sequence of statements that have been made this week.

SPEECH.PARA: I was present in the House of Representatives on Monday, 2 June 1991 when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) faced Question Time. I heard him confess to lying on a significant issue during the last election campaign. No-one could deny that in answer to questions from the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, the Prime Minister acknowledged that he had lied to the Australian public in the last election campaign; that it was a significant lie; that it was, in fact, the difference between his winning and losing that election; and he did not go on to make any apology.

Secondly, the former Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is on the public record as saying that he finds that lie acceptable behaviour. So we have both Mr Hawke and Mr Keating saying that it is acceptable for the Labor Government part of the Parliament, if not for all politicians, to lie in election campaigns. That is not the view of the Opposition. It is not the view of the public at large. I have never, in my time in Parliament, heard any politicians make any kind of admission of, or give any justification for, lying whether as a Minister of the Government or in an election campaign.

To top that off, today we have heard the only clear answer given by one Minister of this Government and that was by Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. He was asked to give a very clear statement as to whether the end justifies the means and he said, `I never believe that the end justifies the means'. It is only after Senator Tate's clear and applaudable statement that Senator Button comes in now to jump off the coalition he has been involved in up to this point with Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. Senator Richardson is in the chamber. On John Laws's radio program today he made this statement:

In my view, when you're putting the nation first, as (Mr Hawke) believes he has, then I don't know if you want to put it as `the end justifies the means'- all I know is that the betterment of Australia will justify almost anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.
—It is disgraceful, and I agree with Opposition senators who have interjected.
—Who said that?

—Senator Richardson, on the radio today, made that limp, dishonest and disgraceful remark about his own behaviour, his own Government's behaviour and what he thinks is acceptable to this Parliament. Senator Button may have heard that admission and might have started to see in clearer focus the kind of company he was keeping with the answer that he gave yesterday. I agree with Senator Lewis and Senator Hill. I say to Senator Button that he has not justified creeping in here at the end of Question Time today to try to hide or run away from the statement that he made-not just once, but twice-in his answer yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the most significant departure from an acceptable standard that we have seen by any government to my knowledge in the whole of Australian history. I want it to be understood that the Opposition does not accept that standard and does expect that truthful undertakings will be given by politicians during election campaigns, and by Ministers at all times in this Parliament and before the Australian public.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! A remark was just made about an applaudable statement and I wish to refer to the outbreak of clapping that occurred on both sides of the chamber during Question Time today. It started with the Opposition senators and was continued by the Government side. Clapping is not in order in the Senate. It is highly disorderly and disruptive of proceedings. I deplore it. If it were to become part of the practice of the Senate our debates would be very much poorer, and I believe the reputation of this chamber would suffer. I ask all honourable senators to refrain from the practice in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In drawing even further attention to the answer Senator Button has enabled people to make the distinction between this particular lie that has now become part of the history of Australia, and the attempt that is being made to try to fudge this lie with the general question of promises made in election campaigns. It is most important that we look at precisely what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in answer to the question from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) on Monday, 2 June 1991. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I assume that the Leader of the Opposition wants a full answer to his question . . . The election was already being run in terms of `A vote for Hawke is a vote for Keating'. It was accepted as politically suicidal if that was the case. It was agreed at the meeting at Kirribilli that no reference would be made to this fact, and for that obvious reason, I have said-and I repeat in this House-that it was a matter of deep regret to me that those political realities forced me into that situation.

He is saying that it was acceptable to lie to try to refute an argument that was being put to the Australian people and put, I might say, in paid advertising. If we knew of that lie at the next election-after the Government's broadcasting legislation has been passed-we would be unable to put it in paid advertising and tell the Australian people about it because the Australian Labor Party would have gagged free speech. That is the salient lesson of this example. That is why we must have the right to put paid advertising to air.

The fact of the matter is that the only statements that would be made about these matters would be how the press would let statements by people be interpreted. There is no way, if the banning of paid political advertising through television and radio comes into force, that the truth to refute a lie will be able to be given in this country again until that legislation is repealed. If we ever wanted an underlining of the perfidy of the statements that lie behind the introduction of the banning of free speech by this Government, the words of the Prime Minister give it forever:
The election was already being run in terms of `A vote for Hawke is a vote for Keating'.

In terms of their secret agreement it was. In the terms of their secret agreement we were not allowed to know about the fact that what we were saying had been proven and underwritten by an agreement given in a secret place.

TALK.START.PARA: —And witnessed.

—And witnessed. So, indeed, it is a time for the Australian Democrats to rethink their position on this issue and not become involved in the complicity of a staged denial of the right to speak out and the right to have proper debate in the public arena. The bottom line is that the Australian people were fooled and the Government won an election on the basis of a lie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should say something about this matter and remind honourable senators of what I said. Senator Lewis-overcome by the occasion perhaps-introduced in an emotional way a motion that the Senate take note of the answer which I gave.
—We feel strongly about standards on this side.

—I am delighted to hear it. I have followed through the debate which has been argued by several honourable senators on the Opposition side. It is pretty sad stuff. Most of those opposite could not get a job prosecuting drunks in Kings Cross court, in my view.
—That does not add to your debating skills at all. That was a very grubby comment.
—If Senator Crichton-Browne hands it out he must not pale at having to take it occasionally.
—It all depends on what you are handing out-if it is garbage it is smelly.

—I understand Senator Baume's concern; those opposite have taken up a lot of his time. He talks about garbage. No doubt there will be recycling in a minute when Senator Baume gets onto his matter of public importance. I will go through what I said again. I gave an answer yesterday. I do not retreat from that answer and I regret that it has been misinterpreted-and the answer which I gave yesterday has been misinterpreted. I said today:

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Lewis had phrased his question more precisely-
I even suggested how he might have done it-
. . . my answer to both those questions would have been no.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't say that yesterday. You said that today.

—Yes, I said that today. Senator Lewis should have rephrased his question and asked it in a direct and sensible way, instead of referring to discussions in the House of Representatives. I did not know what was going on in the House of Representatives. In his questions Senator Lewis referred to things that were going on there.
