When Opposition senators rose to support Senator Lewis today in response to my claim that there had been misinterpretation of what I said yesterday, all of them went to different points. There is no agreement amongst Opposition senators, as usual.
—Not one on your side got up to defend you.
—I asked them not to because I can look after myself.
—Order! The interjections on my left will cease.

—There were six Opposition senators, but each of them said something different. Senator Hill referred to the first part of the question which Senator Lewis did not regard as being important in his speech. He referred to the supplementary question. Senator Kemp referred to the second part of the question-`This is the real gravamen of Senator Button's sins'. Says Senator Kemp, `Look at this supplementary question and his answer to the supplementary question'. `That is the problem', says Senator Kemp. Other honourable senators say different things altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston, I have asked for silence and I will receive it. You too, Senator Crane.

—Senator Teague and Senator Bishop used the occasion for a little bit of an attack on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with no real relevance to my claim of misinterpretation. I am not backing away from what I said yesterday-I mean it. But it was misinterpreted.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to illustrate the misinterpretation, I said that if Senator Lewis was really after the answers to these two questions they are the answers I would give.

TALK.START.PARA: —To which two questions are you saying no? Make a statement.

—I have made it, but I will do it again for Senator Lewis, just to refresh his memory. Senator Lewis should have phrased his questions more precisely. For example, if he had said, `Does the Minister think deliberate lying is an appropriate standard in public life?', or, `Does the end justify the means in public life?', my answer to those questions would have been no.
—Do you think the Prime Minister should resign?

—Senator Lewis wants another bite of the cherry. He asks do I think that the Prime Minister did this or this or that. Not one of the six Opposition senators got up to make that connection. Not one of them.
—I will ask you tomorrow: do you think the Prime Minister should resign? I will give you 24 hours.

—Poor old Senator Lewis. He has had one go, he has had five colleagues support him and he has not established the point. I reiterate my point about misinterpretation. While I am on my feet and talking about Question Time yesterday--
—Do you have a point of order, Senator Walters?
—Mr Deputy President, when Senator Button--
—The Minister is on his feet.

—I am asking a question-a point of clarification. The Minister said `while I am on my feet' as though he was going to go to other points in Question Time yesterday. I thought he may think that the debate has closed but I intend to speak to this motion.
—The Minister has the call.
—Senator Lewis moved that the Senate take note of the question.
—And I will close the debate in due course.

—Nobody else rose to speak. Senator Walters gets up and says that she wants to seek a point of clarification-she says she wants to ask a question. She is like every one of the other six senators who got up: she does not know what she wants. Mr Deputy President, while I am on my feet I will deal with a matter which arose during Question Time. Yesterday I referred to the Leader of the Opposition in the Victorian Parliament as `boofhead' and somebody objected to that. Mr Kennett himself telephoned me last night and took objection to my describing him as boofhead--
—A recycled boofhead.

—A recycled boofhead. I do not want to make an issue of this, but he did threaten me-he threatened to write me a letter about this. It is getting pretty close to a breach of parliamentary privilege when one gets that sort of threat.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator McMullan) put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek clarification of a matter of practice. It relates to the order of call of speakers. In this last debate, as I understand it, the normal practice would have been for you, Mr President, or the Deputy President, to call speakers from either side. The last speaker was Senator Button on the Labor side. Senator Walters had clearly indicated her desire to speak, yet the Deputy President called another speaker on the Labor side, Senator McMullan. Is that in accordance with the normal practice or, if the practice has changed, would you advise the Senate what is now the practice? If you need to confer with the Deputy President as to why he took this most unusual course of action in this instance, would you do so? Can I respectfully request that you report to the Senate?

—In reply to the question that has been raised by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, I was in the chair for the majority of the time and I called Senator Lewis, Senator Hill, Senator Kemp and Senator Teague. When the Deputy President was in the chair, he called Senator Bishop and Senator Button. Then I believe that the Parliamentary Secretary stood and was given the call. I will consult the Deputy President to find out whether that is what happened. If there are any further explanations needed, I will give them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to further answer a question asked of me yesterday by Senator Baume in relation to former Senator Morris and some colleagues from the Liquor Trades Union. Honourable senators will recall that Senator Baume has raised in the Senate in the past the matter of internal disputes in the Liquor Trades Union. On this occasion, I understand that the charge laid against each of the persons referred to relates to an event alleged to have occurred in August 1984. That was some time before former Senator Morris was elected to the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that no brief of evidence will be provided until the end of July, but the allegations do not concern union funds. I am covering some of the points that Senator Baume raised in the question. Peter James was appointed by me as a board member of the Australian Tourist Commission in May 1988. No approach was made to me by former Senator Morris concerning his appointment.

The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) has advised me that the Australian Tourist Commission Act provides that the Minister may terminate an appointment for misbehaviour. Since there has been no finding against Mr James arising out of these charges, there are no grounds for requiring Mr James to stand down from the board of the Australian Tourist Commission. The Government is considering the question of Mr James's reappointment when his term of office expires on 30 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Michael Baume on 4 June 1991, relating to the Australian Tourist Commission.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have spoken to the President and suggested to him that I should make a statement in relation to the matter that was raised by Senator Hill. In relation to the call in the recent brief debate, I noticed that several speakers from my left had spoken in succession. Senator Button then spoke. After Senator Button spoke, Senator McMullan rose.

INTERJECT.PARA: It is my practice that, if a Minister rises, the Minister receives the call. Senator McMullan is a Parliamentary Secretary and the Manager of Government Business in the Senate. Under those circumstances he has the same procedural status, in my mind, as a Minister. Therefore, I gave him the call. Those are the circumstances surrounding the manner in which I gave the call on that occasion. If there had not been several speakers in succession on my left, I may have called differently.

Senator Alston-I want to clarify one matter, Mr Deputy President. It is my recollection that Senator McMullan approached the Chair prior to rising in his place. I therefore ask whether he indicated to you that he was proposing to close the debate and whether you called him on that basis.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan did approach the Chair. He did indicate what his intentions were, but it did not make any difference to the way I decided upon whom to call. Because he stood and because I regard him as having the status of a Minister in the chamber, I gave him the call.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Alston-Mr Deputy President, I do not think that anyone on this side is quarrelling with your recognising anyone on the other side, for that matter. It is really that you were recognising someone whom you knew was intending to close the debate when it had also been made apparent that others wished to participate. That is the matter upon which Senator Hill was seeking a ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, but it is not unusual for honourable senators to approach the Chair and indicate what their intentions are. I understand what Senator Alston is saying. I just trust that those on my left do not regard me as having had ill intentions in the way that I called. Judging by the number of honourable senators standing, they apparently do not. I do not really think that this requires debate.
—I seek leave to move a motion.
—What is the motion?

—It is a motion in relation to the order of calling people from the floor. I have indicated to the Minister that I propose to move that the Procedure Committee examine the question of whether the Deputy President's view-that in all circumstances a Minister who rises will get the call, even if he follows another Minister, rather than the call going to the other side of the chamber-should be the procedure of this place. It is clearly an absurd proposition. It is one that is grossly unfair to the Opposition and one which we simply will not tolerate. As a result, I seek leave to move a motion that this matter be referred to the Procedure Committee.

—I can probably expedite the whole matter by saying that I will refer it myself. The Procedure Committee might be becoming a little tired of receiving correspondence from me recently, but I shall do that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like you to make a point of clarification, Mr Deputy President. I was concerned by your statement that you regarded a Parliamentary Secretary as equal in status to and the same as a Minister. Yesterday, I shared a platform at the Australian National University with Senator McMullan, who explained very succinctly during the process of his address that he did not have the status of a Minister. He explained very specifically to a group of senior public servants precisely what that role entailed, including the fact that he was unable to answer questions at Question Time.

INTERJECT.PARA: I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to examine that ruling and perhaps qualify it in some sense because, from the way in which the Government has structured itself, I put it to you that it is really not possible to regard him as `the same as', `equal to in status', or other such phrases, as a Minister, which he clearly is not.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on Senator Bishop's point: I think that there would be general agreement on this side. With respect, Mr Deputy President, I think you should take on board the point Senator Bishop has made as being generally right. There was a statement made in the House of Representatives a year and a half ago on the duties and roles of Parliamentary Secretaries, but I do not know whether we dealt with it here. That may have been an oversight.

INTERJECT.PARA: As for the general running of this place, people accept that Parliamentary Secretaries can be very good for any future government because of the chamber duty business and the rest of it. I very much appreciate the attitude of the Opposition to this-not so much in the licence given to us to operate this place in the way we have. I very much want it reinforced that, whilst we may not have defined the role of the Parliamentary Secretary as precisely as we should have, by practice we have. That practice is that a Parliamentary Secretary is not equivalent to a Minister. Whether that is good or bad, I am not to comment.

I also say, Mr Deputy President, that you have been placed in a difficult position in the call because when leave is given, as it was in this case, and there are six speakers in one direction, the question of fairness comes in. Further, as was accurately pointed out by Senator Baume, the question of tradition in here is that it is one side to the other. I think the Procedure Committee should look at that as much as possible. People were not taking their full time in these circumstances, so that also could have been a factor that we would try to use in this matter. I do not think there was much malevolence on the other side in regard to the tactics in this regard. We should be able to sort it out and lay it down for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —This discussion could go on all afternoon, but I call the Leader of the Opposition.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Hill

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be long, Mr Deputy President. For a start, there is no suggestion of ill will. The next point is that you have made a ruling and rulings are important. Irrespective of whether this matter goes to the Procedure Committee, rulings are important because they create a precedent. Part of your ruling, Mr Deputy President, was that when a Minister or a Parliamentary Secretary-and let us forget the distinction for a movement-is on his feet, that person will get precedence. To me, that is inconsistent with the practice of this place if we are in the middle of a debate. In other words, the normal practice, as I understand it, is that you would call from one side of the chamber and then the next, irrespective of whether a Minister wants to participate in the debate. I ask whether you would be prepared to reflect on that and, upon reflection, advise the Senate whether you wish the ruling you have made to stand. If you do, there may be other action that we would think should be taken as a result of that. As it is a ruling that has not been made, with the opportunity for careful thought, I invite you to reconsider that.

INTERJECT.PARA: The last point I want to make relates to the fact that there were six speakers in a row, or whatever number, on this side. The only reason there were six speakers in a row on this side is that nobody was rising on the other side. I respectfully suggest to you, Mr Deputy President, that that does not mean that, if six people walk in on the other side, you should automatically call them. I do not think it is the correct procedure either and I do not think it is the practice that has been adopted in the past. The practice is that, nevertheless, the occupant of the chair would go back to the normal procedure if speakers were rising on both sides of the chamber. I ask you to consider that as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall consider it. After consideration, I will come back to the chamber with my decision. Do we really have to continue with the matter? I expected that if the motion were carried the mover of the motion would reply. I was quite surprised when he did not. I did anticipate that there would be one more Opposition speaker.

—There is one further point I wish to add in support of Senator Bishop's statement. It is accepted by the Senate that Parliamentary Secretaries are not Ministers and therefore do not have the entitlement to precedence of the call that Senator Hill referred to. But there is a further point: the reason for giving the call to Senator McMullan apparently is that he is the Manager of Government Business. Our Standing Orders and other orders do not recognise the Manager of Government Business. The reason why the Manager of Government Business has had the call in the past has turned on the fact that it has always, in my experience, been a Minister of the Labor Government. We are taken down a path where we are undone because we now have a Parliamentary Secretary who simply is not a Minister. I do not see that on those grounds you, Mr Deputy President, can treat him with any precedence over any other senator.

—I did not say that I regarded the Parliamentary Secretary as having the status of a Minister because he was Manager of Government Business in the Senate. It was because of both roles. I believe that the Opposition has tacitly accepted that from time to time. I have noticed that Senator McMullan has moved for the adjournment of the Senate and nobody has complained about it. Technically, not being a Minister, he is unable to do that and he would have to seek leave to do so. I do not consider I am the first to regard him as having the same procedural status as a Minister. I know that what Senator Bishop said is correct but I am talking about the practice of the Senate.

—Mr Deputy President, I would also seek a clarification from you. In your comments a moment ago, you made the point that at the conclusion of the debate you would have expected to have seen and you would have anticipated that the mover of the motion would have exercised his right of reply. In light of the fact that the gag had been moved by Senator McMullan and the process was in train to implement that, I would not have thought that it was the appropriate place of the Senate to have allowed any right of reply. How would you have enabled Senator Lewis to be, in effect, given a right of reply?

—My mistake. I just want to make a comment in relation to Senator MacGibbon's comment about the fact that there is nothing in the Standing Orders to say that a Parliamentary Secretary as the Manager of Government Business can receive the call. If we have a look at the Standing Orders in regard to the call to speak--
—Page what?
—No, I will leave the matter of the call for the moment. I agree with you, Senator Tambling.

—But the point, Mr Deputy President, that I do not feel you clarified was the fact that you had prior notice from Senator McMullan that he intended to move the gag. Therefore, you should have been aware that there would have been absolutely no right of reply for Senator Lewis.
—My concern naturally is that I did indicate to you, when I thought Senator Button was attempting to close the debate by getting onto other aspects of Question Time--
—Senator Button could not close the debate because he had not moved the motion.

—I understand that, but I thought that Senator Button was attempting to do so because he was getting onto other subjects of Question Time. It was then that I rose and sought clarification from you that I would be entitled to follow him in the debate of the motion. I really did expect you to call me and was surprised and concerned when you did not, because I had already indicated to you that I had intended to follow Senator Button.
—Finally, could I say that I will follow up those matters raised. There was certainly no malevolence on my part in what I did.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Michael Baume proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The desperate need for leadership with integrity in Australia in order to restore the trust in government that has been destroyed by Labor's state and federal deal-doers, secret negotiators, king-makers, numbers men and `mates'.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The little debate we have had here earlier this afternoon underlines the desperate need for leadership with integrity in Australia and certainly leadership with some integrity within the Government in this chamber-

SPEECH.PARA: in order to restore the trust in government that has been destroyed by Labor's state and federal deal-doers, secret negotiators, king-makers, numbers men and `mates'.
I want to quote from a speech two years ago:

This motion is about standards; it is about truthfulness; it is about trustworthiness; it is about the quality of Australian public life; it is about fitness for office; and it is about leadership. These matters are decidedly the people's affair, the people's concern, the people's business and, therefore, very properly the business of this Parliament.

. . . we are all in a position of service, responsibility and duty to the nation where there is a fundamental requirement for integrity, probity, the ordinary decencies of public life and honourable conduct. It is a special responsibility of the leadership on both sides to protect those values by setting standards and by enforcing them.

Who said that? That was the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke) in one of his more exquisitely hypocritical efforts. The ultimate hypocrisy of this Prime Minister was evidenced in that statement, although I must say there is something prophetic about one of the following sentences where he said:
This is already a tawdry, tarnished and, indeed, temporary leadership.
If ever a man could identify his own problem, that is the man.

Under this Prime Minister, we have had eight years of deals and deception. He began with a deal to dump Hayden. Then he had a deal with big unions, big business and big government, which was called the accord. It is ending now in a deal in which Mr Hawke and Mr Keating deceived each other; witnessed by the way, of course, by representatives of big business and big unions in a big lie.

This is not just a question of broken promises, as has been raised here earlier today, although they are bad enough. But there is a legion of broken promises which we learn to expect from this record breaker of promises. We all remember `there will be no capital gains tax' and we remember that he said that `in words that the Opposition could understand'. We watched his lips. We saw them curl into the usual sneer and then we heard the lie. There is a whole host of lies of this order, but the key lie is the lie which goes to the heart of this Prime Minister's integrity. He is obsessive about the words `lie' and `integrity'. Honourable senators might remember his first significant speech, or his first significant eruption in the House of Representatives, which was to call across the chamber, `He lies and he knows he lies'.

Looking at answers to questions, one finds that on 72 occasions in two years the Prime Minister has used the word `integrity' when referring to himself. The fact is that the Prime Minister has paraded his so-called integrity; he has relied on it; he has used it as currency to buy support. We now find that currency is totally counterfeit. Let us look at the quotes of the Prime Minister over time which, I might say, are fascinating. In 1984, he said:

I am proud of my reputation. I will fight to the utmost to defend my integrity against slurs and smears . . . But beyond that, those of us who hold high office have even higher obligations. While we have a right to protect ourselves, we have a duty, a trust placed in us by the people, to protect the office.
There is no doubt that Mr Hawke has done lots of things to protect his office; he has lied to protect it. This is the man who dares to use the word `integrity'. In 1983, the Prime Minister said:

I remarked earlier on the right of the public to have confidence in the integrity of its elected representatives. While that confidence demands particularly high standards in Government Ministers it also demands certain standards of each and every member of this House and each and every member of the Senate.
This is the man who lied because he knew that if he did not lie he would not win an election.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he got caught.
—He got caught out. In 1989, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we have had the competence, the wit, the intelligence and integrity to work out relevant policies and, secondly and importantly, we have had the capacity to work with the great Australian trade union movement.

In other words, the great Australian trade union movement is one of the groups that the Prime Minister has done deals with. Its representative was one of the people who witnessed the big lie. In 1988, the Prime Minister said:
My Government still stands . . . as a government of stability and integrity.

I do not know which is the more ludicrous of those two statements. Stability? We have the revolving door out of which the former Treasurer has, presumably, temporarily exited before returning and, no doubt, replacing the Prime Minister. Here we have the Prime Minister saying, `A government of integrity'. He went on:
The standards, integrity, and competence of the ministries that I have had the pleasure, pride, and privilege to lead compare more than favourably with any Government in the history of this country.

If those are the standards he is setting, what does that say for every other government in this country? If he is the best, God help us from the worst. The fact is that the Prime Minister has grabbed the word `integrity' to wrap around his otherwise clothesless body. This man is like the emperor with no clothes. He claims that he has integrity surrounding him and protecting him. That integrity has been totally wiped away.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many are over there?

—No members of the Labor Party-apart from the Deputy Whip and the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button)-have any interest in the concept of integrity. They do not understand it. They have all, in fact, defended the Prime Minister in his lie. Not one of them-with the possible exception of Senator Tate, I suppose, who today indicated that he was not in favour of that kind of behaviour-has come out strongly, clearly and unequivocally against the Prime Minister. We certainly cannot count Senator Button's quaint comments today as any unequivocal rejection. Not one of them has come out and done so. In 1991, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Only this remains to be said: much of what has been insinuated by the Opposition has sought to question my personal integrity and reputation and to impugn my conduct as the Prime Minister of this nation.

Here we have the word `integrity'. If we want to play that game, let us go back to the Blanche d'Alpuget biography and see whether we are all still surprised. Let us see whether the leopard has really changed its spots. The fact is that the biography revealed the real Bob Hawke. We are now seeing in the Parliament the real Bob Hawke-the man who will lie in order to win an election because he knows that the truth would defeat him. It is because of this continual appeal to integrity, this continual claim to have integrity, that the hypocrisy that is involved in that man's claim is exposed dramatically by what has happened here. I must say that when Mr Hawke said, `People are cynical about parliamentarians-and with good cause in some instances', I can understand his awareness of that fact because his leading Ministers-for example, Senator Richardson today-are saying that the betterment of Australia will justify almost anything. It reminds me of `what is good for General Bullmoose is good for America'. They are the ones who are to judge this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whom did he support?

—Yes, of course; he supported getting rid of Mr Hawke. The arrogance of anyone daring to get up and say, `I have the right to lie because it will be in your best interests if I lie to you, if I mislead you, if I deceive you'. I suppose we could paraphrase Hamlet: `To lie, or not to lie; that is the question'. We know Mr Hawke's answer to that question. We know that he will lie to protect his mates. We have seen the quaint conflict of evidence emerging out of the gold lunch fiasco in Western Australia and we have seen the whole question of mates. We saw Laurie Connell appointed by Mr Hawke to the Board of the Australian National Gallery; Senator John Morris's sidekick on the Board of the Australian Tourist Commission; mates like Burke and the gold lunch; mates in gaol; mates on fraud charges. Now, with the King Hawke, it is almost checkmate-and it will be quite soon.

SPEECH.PARA: This Canberra Labor sleaze and lack of integrity simply reflects what has been happening around the whole of Australia: the sleaze of WA Inc.; the collapse of Victoria; the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales, where a Minister was thrown in the clink. While Mr Hawke remains as Prime Minister, he is a hostage of the Left. His promises are subject to its approval because that is all that keeps him in power. He can deliver no longer, so he can promise no longer. What we do know is that we need something better than this perpetual lack of integrity. What we need, of course, is John Hewson as Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, with the concurrence of the Senate, the following times shall be the times for this discussion: Senator Button, 10 minutes; Senator Coulter, 10 minutes; Senator Crichton-Browne, seven minutes; Senator Faulkner, seven minutes; Senator Lewis, seven minutes; and Senator Loosley, seven minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Baume on the research which he put into his speech. It was very thorough. But one can do that with many people involved in politics and come up with the same--
—He made a few good points, too.

—Just a minute. One can do that with many people involved in politics and come up with the same sorts of quotations which Senator Baume gave from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) over a period of time. Taking any Prime Minister or any leading politician we could probably find the same sorts of quotes. If we had the time to do the research on Senator Alston's silly interjections, we could make a case which would be extremely damning to Senator Alston's continuing tenure on the front bench. Senator Baume said that Laurie Connell was appointed to the Australian National Gallery by the Government and that became a sin. After that, Laurie Connell was good enough for the Liberal Party to bot $50,000 off for its election campaign. So let us not be too pious about that sort of thing.

SPEECH.PARA: If the appointment to the Gallery was such a terrible thing for a government to do, one would have thought that it would have been known that it was a bad thing to send a former Senate leader to bot money from Laurie Connell. Of course, that is what happened. Senator Baume should not start this debate on high moral ground and sink too quickly into the gutter, because that is a mistake. I am talking about Senator Baume's speech which, of course, has been very interesting. Let us look at this matter of public importance which states:
The desperate need for leadership with integrity in Australia . . .

I do not think that anybody could disagree with that in political life. Wherever it is, there is always a need for leadership with integrity. There is always a need, irrespective of political parties, for trust in government. Senator Baume went on to make his point saying that this has all been destroyed by Labor's State and Federal deal doers, secret negotiators, king-makers, numbers men and mates; no mention of a Prime Minister, about which Senator Baume devoted the whole of his speech. They are the words that Senator Baume put forward and he just ignored every one of those issues. Senator Baume refers to the deals being done by these various people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was in the Keating secret deal.
—Senator Baume did not mention that in his remarks.
—That was the secret lie.
—The point I am seeking to make here is that Senator Baume is hopeless.
—I hope you never defend me on a matter.
—There is no danger of that; I have my professional reputation to think about.
—Just say you agree with him and sit down.

—I cannot disagree with Senator Baume's collection of quotations. Senator Baume has a most fulsome collection of quotations. After all, anyone who has pored over Hansard for several years in order to collect 72 uses of the word `integrity' is a diligent chap, a diligent senator, if nothing else. So I cannot disagree with Senator Baume's quotations or his diligence. I disagree with his conclusions and I disagree with the vehicle he uses to arrive at his conclusions. Senator Baume wants to use this matter of public importance which was circulated to honourable senators for an attack on the Prime Minister. I just want to deal with some of the things that are in this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume refers to governments around the country, to leadership with integrity and so on. Let me go through some of those governments. Is Senator Baume alleging a lack of integrity or leadership by the Government of Queensland?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—Senator Kemp should read what Senator Baume says. Is Senator Baume alleging a lack of integrity or leadership by the Government of Queensland?
—Yes.
—Is Senator Baume suggesting a lack of integrity by the Government of Victoria?
—I wonder what happened.
—They are Senator Baume's words. He is not alleging a lack of integrity. In all of the opportunities that the Opposition has had in the State of Victoria--
—I would agree.

—Senator Kemp agrees with me. In all of the opportunities that the Opposition has had in the State of Victoria, it has not made one allegation, to its credit, that a quid passed to a politician in the State of Victoria.
—What sort of duty of care did Jolly have?

—There is no question about the integrity of the Victorian Government; none at all. If Senator Baume wants to have a debate about duty of care, he should put forward a matter of public importance about duty of care. He should not come in here waffling and windbagging about integrity and making allegations against the Victorian Government under the umbrella of integrity.
—Their incompetence exceeds their lack of integrity.
—Senator Baume shifts his ground all over the place. He talks about--
—Order! Senator Baume, this is not a conversation.

—Senator Baume talks about standards. He is the most slippery interjector in the place. He had the carriage of this matter of public importance. He had the chance to think about it for days on end. He had a chance to collect 72 uses of the word `integrity' and he comes in here and slips all over the place when I tackle him about his arguments. I do not doubt his capacity as a collector of quotations; it is his arguments that I am concerned about. Is there any suggestion about deals or lack of integrity in respect of the Government of Tasmania?
—There are suggestions.
—Yes, there are suggestions about--

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Button has asked us a question. The Premier of Tasmania has done a deal with the Greens that he promised the Government would not have before the election.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I would not think that Senator Walters should get up here with her friend Edmund Rouse popping out of the pokey to give evidence to a royal commission. I would not think she would want to talk about that.
—What's that?

—I said that there is no suggestion of lack of integrity in Tasmania. If the Opposition wants me to talk about it, I will. In so far as South Australia is concerned, is there any suggestion of lack of integrity in respect of the Government? In the case of Western Australia, I concede that it can be argued that the jury is still out-but in only that case. Senator Baume seeks to spread his sleaze across the Commonwealth, across the Federation, by arguing that there is a lack of integrity and a destruction of trust by Labor Governments, State and Federal, by these means of secret negotiations, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to make the point that in all these issues, Michael Baume has really been concerned-I understand this-to attempt to attack the integrity of the Prime Minister. In Question Time today and yesterday there was another attempt at that. As Andrew Peacock says in relation to these matters, it is important to distinguish between the standard of political debate and the absolute truth which is required of people in public life. As Andrew Peacock said quite recently in a letter, referring to the Democrats:
The Democrat proposals to introduce `truth in advertising' are absolute nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was Senator Baume's position on Andrew Peacock vis-a-vis John Howard?

—I do not want to go into all that. Whatever anybody's position was, as Wilson Tuckey said: We lied; we lied; we lied. That is how Andrew Peacock got there. That was the route to the Peacock throne-lying.
—He was sacked from the front bench for it.
—Was he sacked for lying or because he caused embarrassment talking about it; that is the point.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be, as Senator Button said, that the wording of this particular matter of public importance is somewhat loose; nonetheless, it does raise a very important issue. It goes well beyond the integrity of the leadership; it goes to the very heart of the integrity of the political process. One only needs to go outside this place for a few moments to witness the cynicism and the disillusionment with which the Australian public currently holds the whole political process, not only here but in virtually every State in the Commonwealth. The lack of integrity, to which the discussion refers, is right across the board and is particularly evident in both of the old parties. Both of the old parties have damaged the trust which the public should be able to have in the political process.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, this morning Senator Baden Teague called for a conscience vote when we were dealing with the immigration regulations. I note that in doing so he clearly and tacitly admitted that in most instances, because of the party solidarity principle, many members in the old parties vote against their conscience. Indeed, immediately after that vote was taken I was out in the front foyer and I heard a former Minister in the present Government say, `Do you know what we just voted for? We voted to allow poofters to bring their boyfriends into this country'. That former Minister voted for those regulations and, clearly, voted against his conscience. That is what is going on in both the old parties, and that is one of the things that have brought the political process into disrepute.

I now refer to Mr Hawke's promise to Mr Keating. It has been clearly established that Mr Hawke and Mr Keating entered into an arrangement that was witnessed by Sir Peter Abeles and by a person from the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) on behalf of Mr Keating. We now know that, while that undertaking was given in 1988, Mr Hawke went to the public in 1990 stating that he would stay for the full term of the incoming government, should he win government. It has now been admitted-and I think it is common among all parties in this place-that that lie was significant and was accepted as a significant element in whether or not the Government could win the election, in a prospective sense, and whether in fact the Government did actually win the election, in a retrospective sense.

Quite clearly, the Government and many Ministers who have defended that lie have argued here that the end indeed does justify the means. Of course, that is an incredibly slippery road on which to embark, and raises the question: what size lie is justified in terms of what the end might be? It reminds me that a few weeks ago a story was circulating in this Parliament House to the effect that God appeared before Mr Hawke and that God said to him that the world would end in 30 days. Mr Hawke then went on television and said to the Australian public, `I have two pieces of news for you, one is that God exists and the second is that no child will be living in poverty more than a month from today'. Having embarked on that slippery road that the ends justify the means, it raises the question of what size lie is justified. No lie, of any size, can be justified in political office.

Senator Button raised the matter of honesty in electoral advertising. It is a matter of record that repeatedly in this chamber the Australian Democrats have attempted to introduce into electoral legislation precisely the same terms which successive governments have seen fit to incorporate into the Trade Practices Act, and to impose, on every other person in the community who advertises, the same standards with respect to honesty in advertising, and both the Government and the Opposition have voted against that provision. In other words, the Opposition is just as guilty as the Government in voting to leave open the ability to lie when it comes to political advertising.

In the debate that preceded this debate, Senator Bishop used the word `perfidy'. I think that word applies very adequately to Senator Bishop, when she ignores the fact that the Opposition just as much as the Government has voted against the matter of honesty in political advertising. As I have indicated, and as other senators know, Sir Peter Abeles was a party to the agreement between Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. As others have pointed out, that raises the serious question of the Government's ability to make decisions, very important decisions, without being influenced by the very significant power which that witnessing of that undertaking gave to Sir Peter Abeles.

We need think only of the compensation that the Federal Government provided as a consequence of the airline pilots strike to recognise the enormous power that was being exercised by Sir Peter Abeles owing to his having witnessed that undertaking. Whether that power was ever exercised is beside the point. The point is that the Government chose to give that power in a totally deceitful way.

There is another matter in which the Government and the Opposition have combined to defeat the proper democratic processes in this country. One need look only at the processes of democratic representation and recall that, despite very strong evidence that, in the case of the Australian Capital Territory election system, the people of the ACT preferred the Hare-Clark system, which has been in place in Tasmania for many decades but, nonetheless, both parties imposed on the ACT this stupid d'Hondt system which was put in place quite seriously and deliberately to ensure the preservation of the power by the old parties.

Of course, when proposals are put up in many other electorates to adopt a fair system of representation, a system of multi-member electorates and proportional representation, we find that both the Labor Party and the coalition, the Laboreals, as one of my former colleagues called them, have voted against a fair system of electoral representation and have sought consistently to ensconce an unfair and unrepresentative system. These are just some of the processes that give the public no sense of trust-to use a word of emotion-in the integrity of either this Government, the Labor Party or, indeed, the Opposition.

One could also go on to mention the question of media ownership, which has been very much to the fore in the news in the past 24 hours and the way in which this Government and the Opposition have consistently supported monopoly media ownership, against the proper democratic interests of the people of Australia, something that the people outside this place are very concerned about. The Government and the Opposition have shown an enormous degree of carelessness in relation to this and it is something which, again, has brought the Government and the Opposition into disrepute as regards the lack of integrity and as regards the lack of trust that the public can place in Government and the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me read out the important first two lines of this eloquent matter of public importance of Senator Baume:

SPEECH.PARA: The desperate need for leadership with integrity in Australia . . .
I remind the Senate of comments made by former Finance Minister, Senator Walsh, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald not so long ago:
The former Finance Minister has said a principal reason why he left Cabinet was because he could not stand another three years of sitting through Cabinet meetings with Hawke.
Walsh is utterly contemptuous of Hawke: `Old Jelly-back', as Walsh has been calling Hawke . . . needs `a spine transplant' . . .

I do not know whether he is a jelly back, a jelly bean, a jelly belly or a jelly baby, but I do know that this Government is led by a Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who has lied to the public and that the ex-Treasurer conspired with him in that lie, that duplicity, for the personal ambitions of both men.

Remember that it was in November 1988 that Mr Hawke told Mr Keating that he would step down after the 1990 election and that he did not intend at that point to serve his full time if he were elected. Was this a private chat between two honourable men, whose handshake was their word or whose bond was their word? No. This was a meeting which demanded seconds. This was a meeting that demanded witnesses-not a Minister of Her Majesty's Government, not a colleague, not a member of parliament, but people from outside parliament. What did their choice show us? It showed us who is running the country-Bob's rich mates and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

What does the fact that they both need witnesses mean? Here are two men who have known and worked with each other intimately, hand in glove, as the Prime Minister would say, for the past eight years. The Prime Minister of this country and the Deputy Prime Minister of this country were meeting to make an agreement and they needed witnesses. They simply did not trust each other. Perhaps that it is not the greatest sin. The greatest sin is that they did plot, conspire and plan in secrecy about the future of this Government and then lied to the public. Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, tells us that he governs for all Australians, but now we know that he governs for himself and his mates.

TALK.START.PARA: —His rich mates.

—His rich mates. Why did the Prime Minister enter into this conspiracy with the former Treasurer? It was simply because he was being threatened, because he was being blackmailed. The Prime Minister was forced to lie to the people of Australia because he was being blackmailed by the then Treasurer. Why was he able to be blackmailed? It is simply because he could not do without Keating as his Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: Here is a Prime Minister who has based his whole career, his whole reputation, on integrity, openness and frankness. He thinks of himself as having a love affair with the Australian public. The public has certainly been jilted and cheated on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not another breach of promise!

—A breach of promise. This is a Government of bullies and brutes. This is a Government that puts the interests of mates ahead of the interests of government. This is a Government of eight years of broken promises. What explanation are we given for this bizarre conduct? What explanation are we given for the Prime Minister entering into this conspiracy? We are told it is because the Prime Minister believed that, if he told a lie long enough, even Paul Keating would believe it-even the then Treasurer would see the virtue in his arguments. He thought the Treasurer would decide it would be in the nation's interests if the Prime Minister continued to be Bob Hawke and not Keating. We all know what a modest, self-effacing, reluctant pretender the former Treasurer is-how in the fullness of time he would come to understand that Hawke's strengths and abilities were inevitable and so compelling that he would ultimately respect that!

SPEECH.PARA: Let us remember that it was in November 1988, over two years ago, that Paul Keating went to the Prime Minister. Two years ago he came to the conclusion that the Prime Minister was old, tired, lacking in direction and inspiration and over the hill, had served his purpose and ought to go. Notwithstanding that, the public is expected to repudiate that close-up, microscopic, forensic judgment by the former Deputy Prime Minister of his own Prime Minister that he ought to go.

Why did the Prime Minister tell 16 million people that enormous lie? Why did he so emphatically and categorically tell the Australian people a lie which led them to mistakenly vote one way rather than the other? It was not in the national interests. It was not to the good of the country. It was a grubby, grotty deal, done for self-interest, done in the interests of the Australian Labor Party. Now we are told that it was an aberration; it was a one-off. I remind the Senate of the Channel 9 Sunday program of 11 March 1990 in respect of another matter. The Prime Minister was asked:
Does it worry you that you have to tell fibs to people to win their votes? Hawke: `Well I don't tell fibs to win their votes . . .

That is his second great lie. He has not told one great lie; he has told two. The tragedy is that this was not a lie that needed to be told because it was in the national good; it was not a fact that had to be disguised: it was a squalid lie, told for the selfish ambitions of the Prime Minister and the indulgence of his Treasurer.

It is not as if the Treasurer was a wilting flower in this matter. He was not, as he pretends and purports to be now, on the edge of this. He was the instigator; he was the initiator; he was the provocateur. It was a result of his bullying and bludgeoning that he managed to intimidate and coerce this fragile, frail, weak and desperate man, who ultimately succumbed. It was he, as well as the Prime Minister, who was involved in the consummation of this evil plot, which had to be witnessed by rich mates and the ACTU.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought over the last few days that we could expect the Liberal-National Party coalition to get on the front foot because of events that occurred on Friday and Monday but there has been no sign of it at all. I expected a bit of dash and elan and-dare I say it-a touch of excitement from the Opposition, but there was nothing at all. I expected that on Monday, after a challenge to the leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), there would be a matter of public importance or an urgency motion, but there was nothing at all from the Opposition. I thought there would be a few tough questions during Question Time but there was nothing at all from the Opposition. I thought that on Tuesday we would get another rough day-a tough matter of public of importance with all the heavyweights from the Liberal Party and the National Party throwing themselves into a debate, but there was nothing then. There were no tough questions asked of the front bench and no urgency motion-nothing at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, on Wednesday, nearly a week after this matter blew up, Opposition senators have brought on a matter of public importance. They have missed the main game, the big chance, yet again. I say to them: well done, fellows. You have your strategy right again. Honourable senators opposite have come in today to tell us that leadership challenges are not the nature of politics; that does not happen in the dynamics of the political process. They have already told us that it is only the Australian Labor Party that from time to time has the odd leadership challenge.

There is one thing that is different about a leadership challenge in the Labor Party from what the Opposition has been able to throw up over the years. The main difference is that in Mr Hawke and Mr Keating we have two people with the capacity to easily fill the position of Prime Minister of this country. What we have had with the coalition is a series of duds who have been put up for the leadership. Members of the Opposition change their leadership quite often. Malcolm Fraser was a dud who gave us double-digit inflation and double-digit unemployment. He was replaced by Mr Andrew Peacock, another absolute dud. He was then knocked over in a leadership challenge by Mr Howard in 1987, 41 votes to 29-another absolute dud from the Liberals. Then they had a look at the public opinion polls and decided that Howard could not lead them to victory in the 1990 Federal election. So he was replaced by Mr Andrew Peacock recycled, whose winning margin was 44 votes to 28-again an absolute dud.

TALK.START.PARA: —A double dud.

—Senator Collins is right. Finally, temporarily they settled on Dr Hewson, another absolute dud. I can assure honourable senators that he will go down in a screaming heap like all the other duds at the next Federal election. But the Opposition is not into backroom deals; it is not into backroom politics at all; it is not into worrying about negotiations, mates or doing things behind closed doors-not at all. This could not be the Liberal Party that Milton Cockburn was referring to on 12 May 1989 in the Sydney Morning Herald in an article headed `Peacock's troubles begin'. It could not have been the Liberal Party that he was talking about when he mentioned the votes that were switched and those who changed their vote. Milton Cockburn said:

SPEECH.PARA: That leaves 13 switched votes. Twelve of these are easily identified, and here is the list of them: Senator Bronwyn Bishop, Senator Austin Lewis--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I thought that Senator Faulkner was meaning to defend the Prime Minister. He has not even mentioned him once. He has talked about our capacity to bring up this matter of public interest. He has talked about John Howard and Mr Peacock. He has not mentioned the Prime Minister once. Is he speaking within the Standing Orders?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—We all know that in that leadership ballot Senator Michael Baume, to be fair to him as he brings forward this matter, defended John Howard to the death. And it was Senator Baume's death too, of course. He is the one who accused Mr Wilson Tuckey of lying and who was to accuse Mr Peacock of lying. But we also know that Senator Richard Alston changed his vote. He was bought off with a front bench position. Senator Amanda Vanstone, Senator Fred Chaney-that very honourable man who used to be the Leader of the Opposition in this chamber-and Senator John Panizza switched votes. It could not be the coalition that Milton Cockburn was talking about in this article.

SPEECH.PARA: Wilson Tuckey, with the gang of four-Senator Puplick, Mr Tuckey, Mr Moore and Mr Shack-said on Four Corners that it had to be done `at times, I guess, by downright lying'. That could not be the Liberals. That could not be this dishonourable group of sanctimonious hypocrites who sit opposite-no, it could not be that group of people. They are the greatest hypocrites in Australian politics. They should never talk to us about leadership challenges. They have had failure after failure, dud after dud. They know it, and the Australian people know it. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I quote the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of 3 May this year:

SPEECH.PARA: If I had gone to the electorate in 1990 saying that I was only going to serve part of the term and they were voting for Paul Keating, we would not have won the election.

This is not a small deception. This is not even a major deception. This is a conspiracy to defraud the people of Australia. This is a lie of such magnitude that the Prime Minister has acknowledged that he considered he would have lost the election if he had not told that lie to the people of Australia. This was the big lie. He believes that if the lie is big enough, one can get away with it. Mr Hawke has conducted himself on that basis all through his career, including when he was president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions as well as now as Prime Minister of Australia. He deliberately set out to deceive the people of Australia so that he could win an election, and Mr Keating joined with him in that deception. It was a conspiracy to deceive the people of Australia. The explanation of this Prime Minister, who thinks it is perfectly acceptable to defraud the Australian electorate, was given in the House of Representatives yesterday. He defended himself on this matter by saying:

I had only one consideration at that time: not my personal satisfaction or remuneration but my profound belief that it would be bad for this country to have a government composed of members of the Liberal and National parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I hear Senator Collins supporting the Prime Minister's view. The Prime Minister is saying that the end justifies the means. Senator Collins is yet another Government Minister who is saying that. Senator Richardson has said it; Senator Ray has said it; Senator Button said it yesterday but qualified himself; Mr Howe has said it over in the other place; all of these Ministers are saying, `Yes, that is right. The end justifies the means and we support what the Prime Minister has said'. Stalin and Hitler also believed that they were right. They also believed that their actions were in the best interests of the people. This Prime Minister really thinks that he can walk on water. Again I quote from what the Prime Minister said in the House of Representatives yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: I profoundly believed . . . that only Bob Hawke could have won the 1990 election.

That is what he thinks. He thinks that he was the only person who could have won the 1990 election. At no stage has he ever said in his defence to this charge of perjuring himself to the people of Australia that he has done anything wrong. He is still saying that it is all right, that he is quite justified in doing this because ultimately it was in the best interests of the people that he led the Australian Labor Party and won the election for it. He made two points in his speech yesterday. These were his only defence-if we can call it a defence. He now claims that he will serve the full term and that he could not have delivered the prime ministership to Mr Keating and could have only created the vacancy.

Let me turn to those statements. Does anybody believe him? Does Senator Collins believe that both Mr Hawke and Mr Keating did not believe that Mr Hawke could deliver the prime ministership to Mr Keating? Of course Mr Hawke believed it. I will tell the Senate why he believed it. He believed it because on Monday he delivered the deputy prime ministership to Mr Howe, and the majority of the Caucus does not want Mr Howe as the Deputy Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Graeme Campbell got eight votes.

—That is right. The Caucus made it perfectly clear. Senator Schacht, from the Centre Left faction, went to Senator Robert Ray and said, `We don't want Howe, let's put up someone on your side'. Senator Ray said, `I can't do that, Chris, because Bob's promised Howe. That is how he got his numbers to retain his leadership against Keating'.
—What a load of rubbish.

—Of course that is what happened, and Senator Collins knows that as well as I do. Of course Mr Hawke could have delivered the prime ministership. That is the way it was done on Monday, and who doubts that that is the way that Hawke and Keating expect to be able to deliver the leadership in due course-another sleazy deal.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to the defence that Hawke claims that he will serve his full term. Does anyone believe that? Does anyone believe that Hawke will lead the Labor Party at the next election? Who, on the Government side, does not understand that Hawke cannot lead Labor to the next election? With every political journalist and every editor in the country telling their readers that they cannot believe what the Prime Minister says, there is no question that he will lead honourable senators opposite to the next election. Of course he will not.
Senator Crichton-Browne interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. I will put to the Senate the probability of another sleazy deal. Having worked out over the weekend that he could not lead the Labor Party to the people at the next election because of what he has done, the Prime Minister's minders told him on Sunday that he had better get out on a high-and you can bet your bottom dollar that it will probably be after the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, or some time like that. On Sunday night they conveyed that message to Keating and that is why Keating was quite relaxed about the ballot on Monday because he knows that the Prime Minister will be out within a couple of months and there will be a leadership ballot.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the Senate that yesterday again the Prime Minister was misleading the people of Australia. Again yesterday he was misleading the Parliament. We cannot accept anything that this Prime Minister or Mr Keating tells us. They are both proven liars out of their own mouths-confessed liars-on a matter of utmost importance to basic democracy in this country; a matter of such crucial moment that the Prime Minister believed that unless they conspired to tell that lie he would lose the election. It was not that he might lose the election, he believed he would lose the election. That is why they conspired to lie to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator Faulkner said a short while ago in his brief remarks, it is a pity that the Opposition did not come here today with a sense of vision. All the Opposition does is continue to ebb away. I must say, I have always been intrigued by the utter fascination of the Liberal Party of Australia with the internal processes of the Australian Labor Party-an utter absorption with the internal processes of the ALP. Politics on the other side of the chamber must be absolutely tedious-not to say boring-given the amount of time that the Liberals spend talking about the internal processes of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that there is no sense of vision opposite at all, not only on this issue but on virtually any matter that comes before the chamber, I thought I would see if I could find an appropriate quote on leadership, given that Senator Michael Baume raised the issue of leadership in his proposition. That is precisely what we are talking about. That is precisely the issue that is before us. I know that when one weighs up the value of leadership, few people could put words together better than the great American political writer, Theodore Sorensen, who said:

This planet has no dearth of powerful figures, wealthy figures, even wise and worldly figures. We have an ample supply of men and women who can fight, finance, argue, produce or lecture with great skill, but we need more who can lead. If you can contribute to that cause the rest of us thank you very much.

I think that is very apt in any debate about the leadership of the country. There is no question that for eight years Bob Hawke has given the country that leadership in partnership with Paul Keating. It is a tragedy that that partnership has been broken. That is an unfortunate political reality. There are innumerable examples of where this Government has demonstrated leadership with integrity on a continuing basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know you have put up three Keating supporters.

—I am pleased that Senator Walters raises that because I believe that in the leadership ballot on Monday I behaved as honourably as I could. I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) privately and told him what I was going to do in the ballot and why. That is a personal letter so I am not prepared to go into it. When the ballot was concluded I declared myself publicly.
—But you voted for Paul Keating.
—I did vote for Paul Keating. The ballot is over; the Prime Minister has my support, full stop. That is the way the matter has been resolved.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been a feature of the leadership and the decision-making processes of this Government since 1983 that leadership with integrity has been demonstrated time and time again. Five examples will suffice. In industrial relations, surely the processes of the prices and incomes accord is an area where negotiation is far more appropriate than the adversarial and confrontationist policies that we see opposite. Again, in the area of trade, the focus on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade; on building the Cairns group of countries to participate more effectively in arguing our case in the Uruguay Round; and on being forthright with the Americans, the Japanese and the Europeans-that is leadership with integrity. So is micro-economic reform and pushing along those processes.

The problem with the people opposite is that all they are capable of doing is making empty sounds. No alternative policy ever emerges from them on anything and they know it. That is why they have just gone silent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for a consumption tax.

—Senator Collins interjects that the one initiative that has been produced in very recent times is the consumption tax. That will be a test of the Opposition's integrity if it goes to the Australian electorate with that.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Gulf war, leadership with integrity was offered by this Government and accepted by the Australian people in terms of the manner in which we contributed and participated, and lived up to our international obligations. We did not take the easy options. We offered leadership with integrity. The same can be said in the Defence area when one looks at the Wrigley report, coming hard on the heels of the Dibb report; and the full impact of the full structure review. These are difficult issues that are being approached on the basis of leadership underlined with integrity.

Let us look at the Opposition. This is a coalition that gave us tax cuts which disappeared in five months. Tax cuts offered at the end of 1977 to win votes in an election, as Senator Foreman and Senator Collins will recall, disappeared in the mini-Budget of May 1978. This is the coalition which gave us Phil Lynch's rubbery figures in Budget after Budget. This is the coalition which gave us the capital gains tax scare of 1980 to steal the election. You have to have an institutional memory in this place-it is not a matter of talking about the politics of last week, it is a matter of talking about the politics of the decade.

This is the coalition which has produced the most dishonest State government in the history of the country, the Greiner-Murray State Government in New South Wales, which has broken over 200 election commitments from 1988 to the present time, and it is still going strong. This is the coalition which sustained the Bjelke-Petersen Government in Queensland until 1986-the most cynical and contemptible State government on the continent, ever. The Bjelke-Petersen Government raised the doing of deals, mentioned by Senator Baume, to a science of grubby manipulation and sleazy self-reward.

This is the coalition that gave us Robin Gray's Liberals who published phoney advertisements at the time of the last Tasmanian State election in the names of dummy organisations that were simply fronts for the Liberal Party. For the coalition to talk about leadership with integrity is akin to Jim and Tammy Bakker talking about religious inspiration. It is a sham, it is phoney and it is based on a fraud.

This is the coalition that gave us the treachery of Fred Chaney. This is the same coalition that gave us Billy Snedden murdered by Fraser. Then Peacock attempted to murder Fraser. Then, of course, Howard killed Peacock and Peacock killed Howard. Hewson tried to exhume Andrew Peacock and failed. It is a record of utter treachery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. That completes the debate on the matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 7 May 1991 the Senate resolved that the following matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report on or before 30 September 1991: the question of whether there are effective legal and administrative deterrents to prevent the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of information as discussed on pages 14 to 16 of the Privacy Commissioner's 1989-90 annual report.

In its report the Committee has recommended that the Government provide as a matter of urgency its response as to action it has taken, is taking or intends to take, in relation to the matters raised in the report: in particular, sanctions against public servants who disclose personal information held by a government agency without authorisation; the criminal law as it applies to those who procure the unauthorised disclosure of personal information held by a government agency; and the coverage of the Privacy Act in relation to the Privacy Commissioner's power, firstly, to investigate the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of personal information held by a government agency and, secondly, to award damages to those who have been harmed by the unauthorised disclosure of personal information held by a government agency.

This Committee reference stemmed from the Government's failure to address the concerns that were expressed by the Privacy Commissioner in two annual reports about the unauthorised disclosure of government information by Commonwealth public servants. Not only has the Government ignored the recommendations of the Privacy Commissioner, but also it has failed to address the problem despite five months of continuing evidence of unauthorised disclosures of the Commonwealth Government brought before the Independent Commission against Corruption in New South Wales.

There has been no positive action from the Government, despite evidence that confidential information is being leaked from a host of Commonwealth agencies, including the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office, the Health Insurance Commission, the Australian Customs Service, Telecom Australia, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and Australia Post.

The Government pays marvellous lip service to the role of the Privacy Commissioner. Whenever privacy concerns are expressed in the public arena the Government does not hesitate to jump on the Privacy Commissioner's back. Whenever privacy issues endanger Government legislation, Ministers claim-without fail-that they are earnestly consulting with the Privacy Commissioner. However, when there is no political mileage to be made from the Privacy Commissioner or when his privacy concerns do not suit the Government, we witness a complete change of tune from the Government benches. Senator Richardson's argument last year about the role of the Privacy Commissioner in the formulation of Government policy is testimony to this change in tune.

The Government's deaf-eared response to the Privacy Commissioner's repeated concerns about the unauthorised disclosure of Commonwealth information is a clear example of its blinkered approach to his public and legislative responsibilities. I note here that it is not an easy task. The Privacy Commissioner is charting totally new waters-where I am sure he has met with complaints from both sides of this chamber. Yet when he asks for assistance and presents an annual report to this Parliament, on two occasions he has not been heard.
I note that in the conclusion of its report the Committee states that it:

. . . has sought to amplify the concerns of the Privacy Commissioner. It notes the government's commitment to respond to committee reports within three months of them being tabled and now seeks a response from the government.

I wish to put on record my appreciation of the Committee's expeditious and efficient consideration of this matter. I particularly congratulate the staff of that Committee. They were considerably over-loaded with work. I urge the Government to respond within the three-month deadline. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
