MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

Mr President this Bill reflects the Government's commitment to the continuing process of fine tuning the migration legislation. In particular, it seeks to improve the efficiency of processing people who wish to travel to, enter or leave Australia.
The amendments are essential to ensure Australia continues to have the flexibility in law to be able to respond to the pressures of migration of people from all over the world:
. those seeking to visit Australia;
. those who are seeking to make a new home in this country; and
. others who simply seek refuge here.

The previous Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs made it clear on a number of occasions that there would be a continuing process of fine tuning the major and far reaching reforms brought about by the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989. That Amendment Act removed from the Migration Act its wide discretionary powers, and provided for the policy to be translated into law in the form of regulations. These regulations which are subject to parliamentary scrutiny, have brought uniformity and consistency to decision making.

In the present Minister's statement to the House in May of last year he detailed a 3-phase approach to changes to the migration legislation. Some decisions that the Government took at that time required changes to the Migration Act itself and this Bill deals with some of those. This Bill also deals with Government decisions taken since then on such matters as merits review of decisions and illegal entrants.
The provisions in the Bill fall mainly into three broad areas.

First and perhaps the most significant feature of the Bill, is the introduction of a new regime for the immigration processing of undocumented and unexpected arrivals, such as `boat people', where, because of timing, numbers or needs, it is not appropriate to process in the rigid custodial regime of the existing provisions.

Those provisions are primarily designed to handle people whose claims have been determined and who are awaiting removal from Australia or whose claims can be determined in a relatively short time. The new regime will enable their processing in a fair and orderly way, including the provision of humanitarian assistance and medical treatment on arrival, without releasing those people into the broader community before their claims have been properly considered.
Second, the Bill introduces some important changes to merits review. It will allow for:
. a significant increase in the time given to seek review of decisions;
. a broadening of the classes that are reviewable; and
. a modification of the Minister's unique public interest powers to protect the interest of applicants for merits review.
These changes take account of submissions from the community and advice from the Administrative Review Council.

Third, the Bill introduces other important concessions and measures to improve efficiency and enhance the Act's operation. These include the protection of returning residents from innocently falling foul of provisions which could cause them to become illegal entrants.

In addition the Bill will assist people who are ordered to be deported. They will have the right to request or consent to their deportation before the expiry of the period of grace and thereby minimise their liability for custody costs.

The Government is also making provision to require all visa and entry permit application forms to include a requirement for a declaration to be made about the applicant's character or conduct or both. All non-citizen applicants or, in some cases, another person on the applicant's behalf, for example the parents of children, will be required to make the declaration. The making of the declaration will be a precondition to the existence of a grantable application and a false and misleading statement in a declaration will make the applicant an illegal entrant. The provisions enhance existing administrative practice by making the declarations a statutory requirement and linking false or misleading statements directly to the sanctions of becoming an illegal entrant.

As I said earlier, perhaps the most significant feature of the Bill is the introduction of a new regime for the orderly processing of persons who arrive in Australia without documentation. I speak primarily of persons who arrive by boat at our northern shores such as the Cambodian boat arrivals. It is important that such people be treated sensitively and yet in a manner which is conducive to orderly migration procedures.

Such persons require immigration processing before they can be allowed to enter Australia-that is entry according to the Migration Act-as distinct from being physically present in Australia. It is often inappropriate to process them within the custodial regime of the existing provisions of the Act at sections 88 and 89. Those sections are more appropriate for cases where a decision to turn around the person or to allow the person to enter can be quickly made. Recognising this, the Bill also makes it possible to transfer a person from section 88 or 89 custody into what will be called a processing area.
In view of their immigration status, persons being processed under the new regime will be called unprocessed persons.

Honourable Senators will appreciate that when such people arrive in Australia it is necessary to check their identities and that their claims for entry to Australia be thoroughly investigated. To do otherwise would provide Australia with a reputation for being a soft target for persons simply wishing to find a better place to live.

The new provisions will allow immigration officials the time necessary to make fully informed decisions about the entry of these people to Australia. Until these people are properly processed for immigration purposes they will be regarded as not having entered Australia for the purposes of the Migration Act.
To support these procedures the Bill provides for them to be kept in processing areas. These processing areas will be gazetted.
Under these provisions a person will be removed from Australia if they become a prohibited person.
A prohibited person is defined as someone who:
. Has requested to leave Australia. I make the point that they are free to leave Australia at any time they choose.

. Has not applied for an entry permit within the prescribed period of time. These time limits will be specified by regulation. This prevents an unprocessed person from stalling processing by not applying for an entry permit.
. Is refused an entry permit.
The status of prohibited person is most likely to arise where a decision is made after identification of the individual and full consideration of the individual's claims.

In common with certain other provisions in the Migration Act there are penalties provided to deal with people who bring undocumented people to Australia. They will be responsible for meeting the costs associated with the processing of these persons' claims, including accommodation and other maintenance costs.

I have mentioned section 89 of the Act-the turn around provision which primarily deals with persons who arrive undocumented by air. This section has been amended to make it clear that its notice provision in relation to carriers is not incorrectly linked to the ability to remove and keep in custody persons who are not allowed to enter Australia. The notice provision in section 89-as in the comparable new processing area provisions-was only intended to render the carrier liable for the costs of removing the person and the custody and maintenance of the person while awaiting removal.
I now wish to address in some detail the changes to the merits review system.

The Amendment Act of 1989 made provision for a statutory two-tier merits review system of certain decisions under the Migration Act. The aims of that system-not just independent review but review that is fair, just, economical, informal and quick-continue to be met. These changes are in the nature of fine tuning but at the same time give significant benefits to applicants.

The time in which review can be sought has been effectively doubled. At present a review applicant in Australia has 28 days in total in which to seek review both at the first tier and if necessary at the second level of review. Any delay by the applicant in seeking a review at the first level effectively runs down the time they have to seek any review at the second tier. These provisions are difficult to explain and confusing to applicants.
This Bill means that there will be 28 days for each level of review for applicants in Australia and in the case of applicants not in Australia 70 days for each level of review.

In addition, the classes of decisions that can be reviewed have been broadened. Section 120 of the Act does not allow for review of certain classes of would-be review applicants, in particular illegal entrants who have had an earlier entry permit application rejected. This Bill will allow:
. humanitarian consideration to be given to applicants whose refugee claims have been rejected; and
. access to merits review to longstanding illegal entrants who came forward as a result of the Government's concessions that took effect in December 1990.

I have previously referred to the Minister's special public interest powers which can be exercised following merits review of a decision. The kind of decision that the Minister can now make under section 115 following first tier review is on the basis `that is more favourable to the applicant'. The amendments to this Bill will allow the Minister to set aside a review decision that is unfavourable to the applicant and substitute a decision favourable to the applicant and which is one the applicant initially sought, or one that the applicant agrees to.

It is important to recognise however that the exercise of the Minister's special public interest powers at sections 115 and 137 of the Act are non-compellable and the Minister has no legal duty to consider their exercise or to exercise them regardless of circumstances.

While speaking of the Minister's unique powers, the Bill introduces an amendment which makes it clear that any reference in the Act to the grant of a visa or entry permit is subject to sections 24 and 34 of the Act and therefore subject to control by regulations under the Act. However, the amendment also recognises that the Minister's special powers in sections 115 and 137 are an exception.

While on the subject of merits review, the Bill brings the remuneration and allowances of the members of the Immigration Review Tribunal-the second tier of merits review-into line with changes to the structure of the Senior Executive Service brought about by amendments to the Public Service Act 1922. This is not a pay rise but simply a realignment to continue the original parity with the Senior Executive Service.
I finally turn to detail some of the other important concessions and measures to improve efficiency and enhance the operation of the Migration Act.
The concept of entry visas is expanded by the Bill.

The entry visa was introduced into the Migration Act in December 1988 as part of the `Master Plan' for passenger processing at Australian airports. It was a most significant step then as it enabled a single document to be issued for travel to Australia which also operated as an entry permit on entering Australia. There was no need to separately issue an entry permit at the airport.
That arrangement has been very successful and the Government has decided to take the concept a stage further with this amendment.

The Bill amends the entry visa provisions so that an entry visa can be issued to a person in Australia to operate immediately as an entry permit and should the holder leave Australia, as an entry visa.
This will greatly simplify the documentation regulating travel to and stay in Australia.

While on the subject of the `Master Plan' for passenger processing and visas, an extended definition of `valid visa' has been provided to include those documents which, prior to November 1979, were issued administratively to enable non-citizens to travel to Australia. While there may only be relatively few of these documents still in existence the amendment is necessary so that they may be removed from circulation by cancellation and replaced with the current return visas. This will ensure that procedures for re-entry into Australia are standardised.

A number of adjustments are made by the Bill to the section 20 provisions which can, in conjunction with section 14 of the Act, cause a person to become an illegal entrant where the person has failed to make certain disclosures to immigration officials. Currently, an Australian resident, who has, either in Australia or during a visit abroad, contracted some disease or condition which had to be disclosed to the authorities would become an illegal entrant if the disclosure was not made.

This amendment recognises that a returning resident should not be subject to this provision and provides an exemption from the consequences of not making a disclosure of his or her disease or condition unless he or she was suffering from that disease or condition when they originally entered Australia and did not disclose that fact.

These concessions do not disturb the broad coverage of section 20 in relation to people who do not notify certain health and character conditions prior to or on arrival in Australia. However the amendments mean that permanent residents who return to Australia after travelling overseas will not suffer as a result of innocently falling foul of section 20 on medical grounds.

Other words have been inserted into section 20 to emphasise the point that a person on each and every entry and re-entry to Australia comes within the reach of the section and requires the appropriate official endorsement under the section on each and every entry and re-entry to avoid `breaching' it.

A technical amendment is also made to the section 20 provisions to stress that a person making a false or misleading statement in a declaration about character or conduct in a visa or entry permit application form is in `breach' of section 20 and hence becomes an illegal entrant.

I spoke earlier of the changes the Bill makes in the wake of the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989 which fundamentally changed the nature of decision-making under the Act. That Amendment Act meant that a decision under the Act to grant or refuse a visa or entry permit, with the exception of the Minister's special public interest powers, is controlled by regulations. Section 47 of the Act-which deals with the grant of permanent entry permits after entry to Australia-has consequently been left with some redundant provisions. These are now being removed.
There are other important though somewhat technical amendments which are set out in detail in the Explanatory Memorandum.

Mr President, this package of amendments will allow for the more flexible and efficient processing of persons who wish to travel to Australia or who seek to remain in this country after arrival by air or sea or who are required to leave Australia whether voluntarily or otherwise. Importantly, it introduces additional controls on the flow of potential illegal entrants into Australia while at the same time allowing Australia to uphold its reputation as a country prepared to treat justly and fairly people who seek to enter it.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.
SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO 2) 1991

The Bill first makes an amendment to the Social Security Act 1947 so that, with effect from 15 April 1991, a special benefit will be payable, at the discretion of the Secretary to the Department of Social Security, to a person who is the holder of an extended eligibility (spouse) entry permit on the basis of a relationship with an Australian resident where the application for that permit was made on or after 15 April 1991. This coincides with the commencement of the Migration Regulation that operates in such cases.

The new clear English Social Security Act 1991 reflected the 1947 Act as it stood at the end of the Autumn Sittings 1990. The 1991 Act will come into operation on 1 July 1991. Amendments made to the 1947 Act during the Budget Sittings 1990 and the Autumn Sittings 1991 need to be incorporated into the 1991 Act before then. The exercise is a straight translation of existing policy and is being done in two stages.

First, the Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill 1991 will provide for amendments made to the 1947 Act by the Social Welfare (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Act 1990, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act (No 2) 1990 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act 1990 to be incorporated into the 1991 Act.

Second, this Bill will provide for amendments made to the 1947 Act during the Autumn Sittings 1991 to be incorporated into the 1991 Act. To that end, the Bill makes amendments to the 1991 Act to exclude approved scholarships from the definition of income, to exempt moneys invested in certain funeral bonds from the ordinary income and assets tests, to confirm the primacy of Commonwealth legislation in relation to recovery of overpayments from compensation lump sums, to provide for the qualification for special benefit of certain holders of extended eligibility (spouse) entry permits and to provide for some minor policy and technical amendments.

The Bill also makes some amendments to the 1991 Act to give effect to policy initiatives. The maintenance income free areas for pensions and benefits are to be indexed on 1 July each year. The maintenance income free area is the amount of maintenance or child support a person can receive before affecting the rate of her or his pension or benefit. This annual indexation will ensure that the allowable level of maintenance or child support is not eroded over time by inflation and will maintain consistency with the introduction of annual indexation of the basic pension free area for ordinary income from 1 July 1991.

The pharmaceutical allowance is to be indexed from the first pension or benefit payday after 20 September each year. This will ensure that a person is compensated fully for any increase in the concessional beneficiary charge on 1 October each year. The Bill makes amendments to give force to this change.

The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act 1990 provided that, as from 1 July 1990, portability of wife's pension and class B widow's pension would be restricted to 12 months. Payment would cease after 12 months' absence where a person leaves Australia on or after 1 July 1990. Where the person left Australia before 1 July 1990, payment would cease on 1 July 1991.

The Government undertook to revise these provisions following concern expressed by, and extensive consultations with, various community and welfare groups. The amendments to be made by this Bill give effect to that undertaking.

Also included in the Bill is the insertion as a Schedule to the 1991 Act of a social security agreement with the Netherlands, an amendment to the National Health Act 1953 to ensure that a person is not disqualified from enjoying the benefits attached to holding a pharmaceutical benefits card because of the operation of the deeming provisions in either the 1947 Act or the 1991 Act and provisions to make some minor policy and technical amendments.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SOCIAL SECURITY (DISABILITY AND SICKNESS SUPPORT) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill would implement further significant reform to the Australian social security system. It would give effect to the major initiatives announced in the 1990 Budget to restructure income support for people who are disabled or sick. It would see the introduction of an entirely new strategy-which will help us deal far more effectively with the needs of people disabilities in the 1990's.

I do not need to remind members of the urgent need for these reforms. For many years now, the basis for, and the operation of, invalid pension and sickness benefit have not been satisfactory. With invalid pension, the problems stemmed from the qualification criteria set out in the legislation, and subsequently elaborated in administrative law. With the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) gaining jurisdiction to hear invalid pension appeals in 1981, a solid body of principles regarding the key concepts of invalid pension were erected, such as the terms ``permanently incapacitated for work'' and ``85% incapacity''.

The AAT went a considerable way in taking account of socioeconomic factors and the labour market in assessing a person's incapacity for work. We reached the stage where a person could suffer from a minor medical condition but, because of a combination of age, education, lack of skills in English, work history and worker's compensation, could end up receiving invalid pension. Subsequent legislative amendments in 1987 went some way to reducing the impact of socioeconomic factors by introducing a requirement that at least half of the permanent incapacity had to be directly caused by a physical or mental impairment.

At the same time, there were a small but significant percentage of cases where relatively young people, even people in their 20's, who were not manifestly impaired but were being awarded invalid pension with the expectation that they would continue to receive it on an indefinite basis. The concept of permanent incapacity for work became self-fulfilling and only some 2 per cent of invalid pensioners went off pension because of their return to employment. Overall, there has been minimal movement into the labour market by invalid pensioners.

Another important issue has been the failure of any significant number of invalid pensioners to benefit from rehabilitation. Very few were referred or, if referred, accepted for rehabilitation. This was basically due to a lack of motivation which again appears to be linked to the fact that invalid pension was regarded as a permanent payment.

Sickness benefit has also had a number of problems. The first problem is a matter of statutory interpretation as the level of incapacity is not specified in the legislation. Although some AAT decisions have agreed with the Department of Social Security that the level intended is total incapacity, the issue should be beyond question.

Another problem has been that the medical certificates provided by the beneficiaries' treating doctors are often vague and of very little assistance in assessing qualification. This has led to routine referral to a Commonwealth Medical Officer, in particular where a person is on sickness benefit for an extended period. The end result of these problems has been that there have been many cases where clients with impairments too insignificant to warrant grant of invalid pension have continued on sickness benefit for several years, in a manner which is inappropriate to the intentions of the payment. Although recent review measures have significantly reduced the number of long term beneficiaries, it is important to make the short term nature of the payment clear in legislation.

The major changes introduced in this Bill build on the successful social security reforms of recent years which have received widespread community support. The changes are based on the report of the Social Security Review, ``Income Support For People With Disabilities'', extensive community consultation and the work of the inter-departmental Disability Task Force.

The Bill provides for the replacement of invalid pension by disability support pension (DSP) which will have revised qualification criteria. It will also provide for the replacement of sickness benefit by sickness allowance (SA) which will be more clearly defined and will not be payable on an indefinite basis. Other changes will include an increase in the rate of mobility allowance from $22 a fortnight to $40 a fortnight, and the phasing out or abolition of incentive allowance, rehabilitation allowance and sheltered employment allowance. The portability provisions will also be tightened.

The Bill would also provide that children who are attracting child disability allowance are eligible for a Health Care Card. The extension of eligibility for Health Care Cards is an important element of the Disability Reform Package and would assist those families providing daily care for children with disabilities and who, therefore, incur higher medical and pharmaceutical costs.

This Bill gives effect to a wide ranging strategy for a comprehensive reform of disability support. The main features of the new disability support pension are that, to qualify, a person must have a physical, intellectual or psychiatric impairment of 20% or more and a continuing inability to work for the next 2 years. A permanently blind person will automatically qualify for a disability support pension, under provisions similar to those current for invalid pension. Those in receipt of invalid pension just before the commencement of disability support pension on 1 October 1991, will automatically be granted disability support pension without having to lodge a fresh claim.

A key aspect of the disability support pension is that the inability to work as defined in this Bill must stem completely, or virtually completely, from the person's impairment. Non-medical factors will not be considered in the process of assessing a person's inability to work except that, for people aged 55 or over, consideration will be given to the connection between their age and the likelihood of their finding work in the local labour market. This Bill would include the provision for the deferment of disability support pension payments for relevant persons who do not take reasonable steps to meet the active requirements of the pension-to receive treatment, undergo a program of assistance or undertake job search and work. However, these provisions will not commence until 1 October 1993 when the infrastructure for the reforms will be complete.

This is an initiative aimed very much at providing real hope and assistance for people who are disabled or sick. It offers assistance and scope for people who are disabled or sick to acquire skills so that they will be better placed both now and when the labour market starts to improve. To encourage transition to work, a disability support pensioner who finds employment will, in the majority of cases, have his or her pension suspended for up to 2 years rather than cancelled outright.

For those who are completely, or virtually completely, incapacitated for work temporarily because of sickness or accident, a sickness allowance will be payable. This allowance will generally be payable for periods of up to 13 weeks at which time fresh medical and other evidence will be required. Payments will not extend beyond 12 months except in exceptional circumstances where it is clear that the person's incapacity will end during the next 12 months, or where the existing condition seriously worsens or a new condition develops.

An employment entry payment of $200 will be paid to any qualified person on a disability support pension who finds full-time work or whose earnings from work exceed the level of income at which either job search or newstart allowance ceases to be paid to a person aged 21 years or over. This, as well as the suspension rather than cancellation of pension for disability support recipients trying out work, will encourage a person in receipt of a disability support pension to take up work to the extent possible and prepare the person to enter the workforce.

This Bill would continue the development of a common allowance structure for income support given to young people. This will be done by aligning the rates of disability support pension for people who are under 21 with the rates of job search and newstart allowance payable to people under 21. However, this Bill recognises the extra expenses that have to be borne by young people with disabilities and it provides for the payment of a youth disability supplement to people under 21 who will be receiving disability support pension. The supplement is to be aligned with the rate of child disability allowance. Also, the income and assets tests will not apply to the maximum basic rates of disability support pension payable to a person under 21 who is permanently blind. Additionally, a disability support pension recipient aged under 18 is, for similar reasons, not subject to a parental income or assets test.

A central feature of the Disability Reform Package is a greater emphasis on rehabilitation and assistance to return to the labour market. This will not of course be possible for invalid pensioners and disability support pensioners residing overseas. Unlimited portability for all invalid pensioners would, therefore, be inconsistent with the present direction of reform. This Bill will limit the portability of invalid pensions to 12 months for new pensions granted on or after 1 July 1991. This limitation will not apply to pensioners who are assessed as severely disabled or where a social security international agreement provides otherwise. This amendment will also bring the rules for portability of invalid pension into line with the 12 month limitation for sole parent and wife pensions.

I conclude by emphasising the positive directions of these reforms. There must be no impression that this Bill will penalise those who are disabled or sick. Rather, the Government's desire is to avoid the problems of the past where, too often, income support has been seen as the final and only solution, with no integration with rehabilitation or labour market assistance. The provisions in the Bill would signify a new deal for people who are disabled or sick to help not only their participation in the labour force, but in the broader life and work of the Australian community.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
SOCIAL SECURITY (REWRITE) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The clear English Social Security Bill 1990 was introduced into the House of Representatives during the Budget Sittings 1990 and reflected the 1947 Act as it stood as at the end of the Autumn Sittings 1990. The Social Security Bill 1990 is now the Social Security Act 1991 and will come into operation on 1 July 1991.

Amendments made to the 1947 Act during the Budget Sittings 1990 and the Autumn Sittings 1991 will need to be incorporated into the 1991 Act before it comes into effect. This involves a straight translation of existing policy and will be done in two stages.

First, the Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill 1991 will provide for amendments made to the 1947 Act by the Social Welfare (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Act 1990, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act (No 2) 1990 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act 1990 to be incorporated into the 1991 Act. This covers initiatives such as:
. tax file numbers;
. deeming (loans and deposits);
. liquid assets tests for sickness beneficiaries;
. recovery of overpayments;
. employment entry payment for sole parents;
. disaster relief payments;
. extension of qualification criteria for remote area allowance;
. extension of qualification criteria for carer pension;
. pharmaceutical supplement and allowance; and
. the amended international social security agreement with the United Kingdom and the new one with Malta.

The Budget 1990 initiatives which affect the unemployment benefit and job search allowance structure in the 1947 Act are incorporated into the new provisions for job search allowance and newstart allowance to be inserted into the 1991 Act by the Social Security (Job Search and New- start) Amendment Bill 1991 which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 18 April 1991.

The Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill 1991 will also provide for some minor technical refinements to be made to the 1991 Act to make sure that it correctly reflects the current legislation and policy.

In the second stage of updating the 1991 Act, amendments made to the 1947 Act by the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 (introduced into the House of Representatives on 13 March 1991 and dealing with initiatives such as exemption from the income and assets tests for certain funeral bonds, approved scholarships and compensation recovery) will be incorporated into the 1991 Act by the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No 2) 1991.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill amends the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, the Social Security Act 1991, the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 and the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1986.

The Bill contains a number of minor changes to improve the administration of benefits for veterans and dependants under Veterans' Affairs legislation. These relate to the repeal of obsolete provisions for Boer War Veterans, the payment of pharmaceutical allowance to orphans not in receipt of orphan's pension, indexation of the pharmaceutical allowance, amendment of the Repatriation Commission's review powers to allow certain decisions to commence from a date earlier than the date on which the decision is made, the removal of an anomaly affecting the adjustment of pension following lump sum compensation payments under the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, amendment of the definition of ` `disease'' and indexation of the maintenance free area.
A number of other minor amendments to the provisions for service pension have been made to bring these into line, and maintain consistency with, the Social Security Act 1991.

The most important and far reaching change, however, relates to the Government's decision, announced on 22 January 1991, to extend benefits to dependants of female veterans on the same basis as applies to dependants of male veterans. These changes will remove a longstanding area of discrimination in the payment of benefits to the dependants of veterans and will ensure that the dependants of servicewomen who served in the Persian Gulf, as well as dependants of female veterans from earlier conflicts, will be entitled to benefits under Veterans' Affairs legislation. This will include entitlement to Defence Service Homes loan and insurance benefits.

The extension of benefits to the dependants of female veterans will cost an estimated $1.601m in 1991/92, $1.847m in 1992/3, $2.094m in 1993/4 and $2.339m in 1994/5. The indexation of the pharmaceutical allowance will cost an estimated $1.127m in 1991/92, $2.524m in 1992/93, $3.821m in 1993/94 and $5.079m in 1994/95.
The Bill will not have any other significant financial implications.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY (REWRITE) TRANSITION BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —We were discussing with the Minister a number of issues relating to these amendments and I wish to ask: will the Minister be present for the remainder of this Bill? (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was speaking when this matter was adjourned some hours ago, so it is difficult to recall exactly where I was, but at the time I think I was commenting on the Australia Democrat amendment about voluntary work. I explained the situation for people under 18 years of age and over 55 years of age. So I believe the question that Senator Lees would wish to be putting to me, were she on her feet, would be, `What happens to the rest?'. I was about to explain that. I was saying that any age that we decided on for the cut-off point would be a problem. I do not think that the ages of 18 or 55 are any worse than any other age that one might try to set.

SPEECH.PARA: If the question then is why should we do this at all, the answer is that the group of people between the ages of 18 and 55 are those who are the most employable. They are the ones who, with assistance in labour market programs, et cetera, would be most likely to find work. So, for that group of people, we want to place the emphasis on the provision of courses and work placements, et cetera. That is the reason for the difference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —To continue on the issue of voluntary work, it goes back to an earlier question I asked regarding the actual number of hours per week people are expected to be looking for work. I agree that it is very difficult to set a specific figure. However, if we take Adelaide as an example, people get the Adelaide Advertiser on Wednesdays and Saturdays and they can check through the jobs. That probably takes no more than 15 or 20 minutes. A person may be lucky enough to find something at the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) but, out of all those jobs suitable, they would be very lucky to rate one or two interviews. The whole process of continuing to look for work will not take more than half the time. Here we are coming back to about 20 hours a week.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we also need to note some earlier comments the Minister made about a very few people on Job Search allowance actually being able to access any of the training options. Therefore, what does the Government suggest people do with the remainder of the time? If they fulfil requirements with regard to looking for work, are available for interviews, and attend the CES or Department of Social Security whenever required, why can they not then do voluntary work in their remaining time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been told about something I said earlier that I am not sure I said. So I am not sure whether this is a correction; it depends on what other senators may remember. The figure of 30 per cent is an overall figure of the number of courses that would be available. For Newstart the figure is 38 per cent and that is somewhat higher than that 30 per cent overall figure. Obviously the numbers of those on Job Search allowance (JSA) are lower, hence they bring that average down. It is by no means the case that from that one could glean that no-one on JSA gets an opportunity for training, because plenty will. I will make sure that, in the course of Budget discussions, along with my colleague Mr Dawkins, that more people do get that opportunity. Again, that is something that we have to address in the Budget process.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no doubt the case, as Senator Lees says, that the Adelaide Advertiser-not that I am a particular fan of that newspaper at present-does not have a long list of vacancies. I do not know what the main paper is in Geelong, but I am imagine that if I were looking at it, the list of vacancies would not be too long, either. So one could look at a the situation in a number of places and find the same problem. I have said here that the Government's view is that, during the rest of this calendar year, the economy will improve and, in the rest of the financial year, it will get better. So people will be looking at more advertisements in the Adelaide Advertiser and more possible placements through the Commonwealth Employment Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the Minister his opinion of voluntary work. Does he see it as a worthwhile occupation or pastime for those who are unemployed? I would certainly argue that it would give the unemployed a chance to keep in touch, particularly with other people. The risk, particularly with those who are getting into an unemployed way of life, is that they tend to become more and more disheartened. They suffer further and further rejections. One real opportunity for them to feel that they are taking part is to do voluntary work. This is why the Australian Democrats will push ahead with these amendments and hope that, if the Government does not support them now, when the Budget considerations are being made-as I do not believe these proposals have any financial implications-the Government will consider permitting people to do voluntary work as long as they fulfil other requirements of the Government. What is the Minister's opinion of voluntary work?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Lees will be aware, voluntary work is not prohibited at the moment. Many people who are unemployed, be they on the Job Search allowance or Newstart, do voluntary work for a number of hours each week. We are arguing about quantum, not whether they can do it. Voluntary work certainly has a role, not just in making people more employable and more attractive to employers but also in terms of self-esteem. Very often that is the key.
—It is much more than that.

—I have said it is more than that, but I am saying that it does include that. I do see a role for voluntary work; that is why the Government has not stopped it. I am prepared to look again at the question. I am prepared to talk to groups representing the unemployed about it and see, with my colleague John Dawkins, whether there is any possibility of change. At this point I am not convinced that there needs to be any change, and hence the Government is sticking with its position.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

This is to eliminate the ordinary waiting period of seven days for payment of the Job Search allowance, enabling people who lose their jobs to immediately receive payment. TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to see whether I can determine what the average period is. It might take us a little while to work that out. I doubt very much whether I can undertake to give Senator Lees an answer today. It might take some time, but I will certainly set the Department to work to find out.
—If I can ask the Minister an additional question, what is the Government's reasoning for the waiting period of seven days?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

I do not really believe that this has been the great argument in terms of waiting periods. I explained in the Senate, before I gave a quite detailed answer, the way in which waiting periods work and the way discretion is often used for people in hardship.

These amendments refer to the more controversial waiting period, which is for education leavers. I firstly refer to the Minister's answer in this place on 15 May. We are very pleased to note that there has been some improvement in that now only 63 per cent of education leavers are actually serving the waiting period. However, I emphasise that there are still large numbers of young people who are severely disadvantaged by this provision. When the waiting period was initially discussed, what was the reasoning behind it? Why was this waiting period of 13 weeks put in place?

TALK.START.PARA: —That 13-week period is, of course, existing policy. It is there because at the end of a school year it roughly corresponds with the holiday period that goes between the end of school and the start of universities, colleges and the like in the new year. Generally speaking, there is something like a 13-week gap, so it roughly corresponds. There is a difficulty here in that, if we do not have that kind of waiting period, those who have not genuinely left school and intend to go back will be able to claim a benefit to which they would otherwise not be entitled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister agree that it also catches those who leave school with genuine reasons or in fact graduate, be it from a school, a college of technical and further education or a university? It also catches those young people who decide to leave school specifically to seek work and those who may not fulfil requirements for staying at school. It is causing quite considerable hardship. I can quote a number of cases, particularly country cases. I will pass these to the Minister later rather than reading through them now. But one young gentleman asks:

SPEECH.PARA: What am I supposed to do? I didn't choose to give up my education and I don't choose to be unemployed. How am I supposed to survive?

The examples go on. I ask the Minister: if these amendments are not accepted now, will he again look at this matter in the Budget? If he does not reduce the 13-week waiting period to six weeks, and the six weeks to four, what other measures, other than the ones now in place, can he put in place to ensure that everybody who needs to access the benefit under the hardship provisions is actually able to do so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did explain this some weeks back. Senator Lees has referred to an answer that I gave about the numbers of school leavers. I think I extended the example beyond school leavers. From memory the question went into other areas too. I explained that quite a few are able to use the hardship provision to escape the waiting period. As far as I am aware, that hardship provision is being administered with some compassion and fairness. I am not aware that we are being overly harsh; the provision is there for a particular purpose. We need to remember that it is being exercised not simply in a third of cases-we are talking in round figures; I do not intend to be exact. The truth is that not everyone applies for hardship provisions because not all school leavers consider themselves to be in hardship, or could possibly demonstrate it if they did. But, where there is a demonstration that hardship exists, the record shows that the Department is prepared to accede and grant a benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Lees is saying that she does not think we are doing enough in that respect, then I am more than happy to look at the cases and talk to the Department about a change in attitude. But I am, as we speak, satisfied that enough is being done. Just so that I have answered the whole question, let me add that I do not believe that this is going to be a matter for discussion in the Budget discussions. I have decided not to raise it. So another colleague would have to for it to come up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. While stating that the Australian Democrats would prefer to see the period reduced substantially, I point out that we would also be happy if young people were informed that they could in fact apply, that there are hardship provisions and that some information was routinely given to let young people know that they can apply.

SPEECH.PARA: 8. Clause 7, page 31, after proposed section 542, insert the following section:
Requirement to attend for counselling

``542a. (1) Where a person is receiving a job search allowance, the Secretary must, on the expiration of 6 months from the day on which the person commenced receiving the allowance, notify the person in writing that he or she is required to attend an office of the Department or of the CES for the purpose of counselling and advice in respect of that person's attempts to obtain employment.

`(2) Where a person has received a notice under subsection (1) and has not, without good reason, within 14 days from the day on which the person was issued with a notice, attended an office of the Department or the CES for counselling and advice, a person will cease to be qualified for a job search allowance until the person attends for counselling and advice.'.''.

This is to insert a proposal in the legislation that would require the Secretary to invite those who have been unemployed for six months to attend an office of the Department or the CES for the purpose of counselling and advice in respect of a person's attempts to obtain employment. As I understand it, the Government's proposal is simply that after six months one is able to take advantage of various labour market programs. But the weights, in a sense, are not really placed on those who are out of the work force until the 12-month period has expired.

We certainly take the view that it is leaving the matter far too late. People ought to be made aware of their options, which ought to be explored with them. People ought to be given a realistic appraisal of their prospects and the best way of seeking to re-enter the work force. Perhaps judgments should be made at that stage about where and to what extent they have been looking. Ultimately, of course, they would be made aware that there is a cut-off point. In line with our announced policy on the matter, we believe that it is necessary that this happen at an early stage rather than waiting until the horse has bolted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason that the Government is opposing this amendment is that I think the administrative arrangements adequately cover what Senator Alston is seeking to do. Under administrative guidelines that will be applied to the Job Search allowance (JSA), there will be an interview for any person concerned both by my Department and by the CES. That is at various times.
—That is compulsory, isn't it?

—People do have to come in for the interviews; there is no doubt about that. Each JSA recipient will be interviewed by the CES during the first three months of unemployment. My Department then reviews a person's entitlement at the three months stage. I do not propose to use phrases like `putting the weights on them' but obviously there are activity testing requirements that they have to satisfy in those interviews to convince us that they have been doing the right thing.

SPEECH.PARA: At six months, the CES will then interview each recipient to explain what labour market programs might be available to them and what kind of assistance the CES might be able to give. With all of those steps along the way, it is not as if payments are easy. The complaint of the Australian Democrats is that what we are doing is too tough. I do not think that we need to do what the Opposition is suggesting to bring about the situation on anyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister saying it will happen in any event under his approach?
—All those interviews to which I just referred will happen in any event.
—So, the Minister is saying that our proposal is unnecessary because he will be doing just that?

—I suppose Senator Alston is referring to a counselling session; I am not certain that I would call these interviews counselling, necessarily. In some cases they might be and in some cases they will not be. But in all cases the interviews will be taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

One of the complaints that I get from people around the country-not just unemployed people but also people receiving other forms of social security payments-is that we send them too much correspondence. They complain that I am eating up forests willy-nilly and that they should not get as much.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not certain that the sending of a two-line letter to somebody on these occasions is necessarily any better than making a phone call. I am trying to not make the process so bureaucratically nightmarish as to make it impossible. In any event, on every occasion this is not going to advantage clients. There will be times when, say, a course suddenly becomes available and the CES wants to ring and say, `Look, here is the situation'. But if the requirement was for notice in writing, then the client on those occasions could be disadvantaged. I am not even sure that the amendment, which the Australian Democrats are seeking to move, actually helps the people they are trying to help.

TALK.START.PARA: —If some of the penalties were not so draconian, we probably would not be quite as concerned. I am not suggesting that some contact cannot be made by phone. I think the Minister has given us an excellent example of when indeed telephone contact would be appropriate. But I believe information in writing is essential, particularly if missing this piece of information is going to mean that these people are cut off benefits for possibly weeks.

—In the normal course of events, these things are done by way of correspondence. There is no doubt about that; that is what usually happens. But there are times, though, when it is going to be much easier and, in fact, better not to because it will help the client more to do it by telephone. All I am saying is that this amendment is inserting a requirement that can disadvantage clients and I do not see why we should proceed with it.

—Having heard that exchange, I might indicate that our predilection was to support the amendment, but I am now prepared to not support it on the basis of what the Minister has said. If we accept his assurance that in most instances advice will be by correspondence and that every endeavour will be made to ensure that people are notified by one means or another; if that is effective and there is no question of people being disadvantaged as a result of claiming not to have received notification, we would be prepared to give the Department and the Government the benefit of the doubt at this stage. But, certainly, if there are any complaints of people being disadvantaged, we would be very interested in rectifying that.
—I ask the Minister whether it will be possible, if this goes unamended, for people to actually have their benefit cut off because they have missed a relayed telephone message.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

But that is not the intention here and it will not happen. Basically, it does not happen now unless a mistake is made. This legislation will not change that. I can give all the undertakings that Senator Alston just requested. It is simply not going to be a problem.

These amendments would remove, if passed, the compulsory element in Newstart. Newstart certainly does have some positives: it offers increased training opportunities; it offers some paid work experience; and, I think, from answers that we had earlier today from the Minister, it will improve the situation for those who wish to undertake voluntary work. The Australian Democrats, however, see no need for compulsion. Only about 30 per cent of unemployed people will get an opportunity to partake in one of the approved courses. Looking at the number of people volunteering, there are already too many for some of the volunteer centres to accommodate because there are so many asking to take part. The Government's work experience program is also limited. There are more than enough unemployed people to fill every possible type of program that the Government has on offer.

We therefore see absolutely no need for compulsion. We believe it is a slap in the face for the unemployed to suggest that the only way we can get them to do anything is to enforce it. We hope that the Government will rethink the whole idea of compulsion. We believe unemployed people are only too willing-and, in fact, extremely anxious-to either get back into the work force or do something useful and productive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that gets to a debate on the whole philosophy of what we are about. I do not seek to conduct a full debate. I do not look upon these agreements, nor does the Government, as being punitive; they certainly will not be. These agreements will be positive in assessing what the Department and the client can do together to assist the client in getting some work. It must be remembered at all times that the client will be negotiating the agreement. Those concerned will actually be sitting down and talking to the Commonwealth Employment Service, in most cases, about what they think is possible for them. SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 7, page 64, proposed subsection 603 (1), line 10, omit ``not required'', substitute ``taken''.
(7) Clause 7, page 64, proposed subparagraph 603 (2) (a) (i), lines 21 and 22, omit ``remote area'', substitute ``an area described in subparagraph 601 (2) (a) (iii)''.

Amendment 8: again, I think this is not really worth a speech; but I will do that if any honourable senator requires it.
