SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 25. Clause 7, page 65, proposed subsection 604, line 4, omit ``is to have'', substitute ``may have''.
This relates to the requirement as in compulsion, and we have already dealt with that.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 26. Clause 7, page 65, proposed section 605, lines 7 to 18, omit the section.

Again we are looking at the compulsory element with this amendment. As for amendment No. 25, as the compulsory element is staying and both the Government and the Opposition are happy with that being so, this alternative amendment requires a notice of requirement to enter into an agreement to be in writing and specifies a duration for the agreement of no more than six months. This would ensure agreements did not continue indefinitely. It would also provide an opportunity for review.

TALK.START.PARA: —This refers to the principle of what is reasonable and what is set in administrative law. I can only repeat my strong belief that we just do not keep adding these sorts of amendments. I do not think that they actually do anything. In any event this part about six months can disadvantage people. It would be fine for the average client in Sydney, but it would not be as good for people in the bush. I just do not think it is sensible, let alone just.
—I ask the Minister: how long does he envisage contracts lasting?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the problem. We cannot give an answer to a question such as that because it will vary with individual circumstances. In some cases the Department may feel that it ought to be a month and in other cases it ought to be 12 months. It will vary. That is why there has to be the flexibility. There is no general rule.
—Will there be a specified time on every one of the contractual agreements?
—The answer to that question is yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 14. Clause 7, page 65 at end of proposed subsection 605 (1), add ``within 8 weeks of the person having commenced to receive a Newstart allowance''.

This amendment would introduce a time limit on the period during which a Newstart agreement must be negotiated. At the moment it is open-ended. We believe that it does make sense for all parties not to have a protracted period of negotiation and that there ought to be a clearly understood limit on that process. This is an effective way of doing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what Senator Alston is saying and I concede that it would not be a good thing if we were to allow lengthy periods of time to elapse for the negotiation of agreements. Again, it gets back to what I said before about the needs of individuals. Some people in remote areas, who find access difficult and who will not be able to attend a number of appointments quickly-it may be that a number of appointments are required before an agreement has been properly negotiated-can be disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure Senator Alston and the Opposition of our determination to get the job done as quickly as possible. If we set blanket rules, we can disadvantage some individuals. In some circumstances it will not suit. In any event, even for people who are not in remote areas, it may be the case that trying to get the agreement exactly right for an individual may require more assessment, more examination, and could take a little longer. I am just reluctant to set an actual limit. I think that Senator Alston will find that as the Newstart program develops most of the agreements will be negotiated within this period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Within the eight-week period?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 26a. Clause 7, page 65, proposed subsection 605 (3), line 16, after ``notice'', insert ``in writing''.
26b. Clause 7, page 65, after proposed paragraph 605 (3) (b), insert the following paragraph:
``and (c) the duration of the agreement which shall not exceed 6 months.''.
I think I made all of the remarks I needed to make when I spoke on the amendments in general.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 27. Clause 7, page 65, proposed paragraph 606 (1) (e), lines 27 and 28, omit the paragraph.

I know that I have been going through a lot of individual amendments and I guess it is difficult to categorise some as being more important than others. This particular amendment would eliminate the broad catch-all clause, perhaps the one that is still of most concern to the welfare agencies and those who work with the unemployed. This would enable the Government to ensure that people undertook any measure designed to eliminate or reduce any disadvantage the person has in the labour market. Listening to the Minister's earlier answers today, I can understand that he will again make comments about fair and reasonable.

The problem is that many of the people who are seeking assistance do not have a background in law, do not understand exactly what is being required of them and, therefore, I think it is extremely important that we spell out here and make it very clear exactly what the Government does mean to happen under this clause. Could the Minister please provide us with some information as to what types of activity he sees coming in under this clause?

TALK.START.PARA: —In this case, I do not agree with what Senator Lees is trying to do, in any event. This clause had to be drafted as a pretty open-ended provision, because for some clients there are barriers that they will have to overcome-remembering at all times that agreements have to be negotiated between two sides. But there are barriers to be overcome, such as difficulties with the language or literacy or numeracy problems. They could also relate to people with disabilities and what type of rehabilitation they might have to undergo. I believe that this clause is to the advantage of clients, not to their disadvantage and in that respect its drafting is quite deliberate. The other comment that I make on the clause, even though Senator Lees has not raised it, is that later in the debate-and I am not sure what the order of amendments is; there are too many of them for me to keep up with them-the Government will move an amendment to ensure that work for the dole is not a possibility.

—The Opposition takes the view that it would be unworkable to try to specify every possible instance whereby it might be reasonable to require cooperation and participation. It is always a concern that these sorts of provisions can be abused, and that is why we have a system of administrative law to read down if necessary. I would think that we would all be very vigilant to ensure that these provisions are not used to compel people to undertake activities that are clearly unreasonable. But unless these provisions are included, I suspect that the balance would swing very much the other way, and we would find all sorts of excuses being used to explain why a person was not caught by any one of the litany of items that are specified. We will certainly be vigilant in seeing how this is applied. We do not think there is any alternative other than to allow broad discretion at this stage.

—I think I must trust people a little more than Senator Alston does. The Democrats still have some concerns, Minister. I shall therefore ask the Minister a series of specific questions. First, under this clause would people be required to actually move residence?
—No.
—Would people be asked to undertake programs such as weight loss courses?

—I am not going to rule out the possibility that it might be suggested. Plenty of people have suggested it to me. These things all have to be done by agreement between two parties. For instance, if I were in the situation of being advised that way, I would say that plenty of people had told me that and that I had tried for 20 years and failed and that, if that were a compulsory requirement, I would be in trouble. So I do not agree, and I am sure that is what many people would say. On the other hand, some people might take the advice and do the right thing, improving not just their job prospects but also their prospects for a longer life.

—I thank the Minister; most enlightening. I think the Minister would agree, however, that there is a rather unequal power balance between the people either side of that desk in a CES office, and we are talking about some of the most vulnerable Australians. I think it is totally unrealistic even to suggest that type of requirement. I again go back to the compulsory element and the fact that people will have to actually know the appeal process before they are able to get to a situation that they are happy with. I also refer to some points that I made in my speech last night about the concerns that the CES has in regard to adequate training and being able to assist people. Moving on, does this clause also mean that people may be required to actually undergo medical treatment?

—I did not catch the honourable senator's last comment, and I will ask her to repeat it later. Before that can I say that, on this whole score, every person with whom we will be negotiating an agreement will know of the appeal process. We will tell them about it. It is not as though they will not know they can appeal. I really worry about the attitude. It is almost as though the CES and, in some cases, my own Department are being seen as some kind of enemy of the unemployed and are out to crush them. That is not what this is about. Certainly, there is an element in this of making sure that people take advantage of opportunities to improve their skills. Certainly, we will continue to ensure that people are subjected to activity tests to ascertain suitability for work. But that does not make us an enemy. It is not as though we will be sitting down as adversaries, across the table, to fight it out to the last drop of blood. That is not what the officers in the CES and the DSS are about. Out of the thousands and thousands of them who participate in this process, we might get one or two who will be unkind or uncaring, but the vast majority of these people do their job well and they ought to be given credit for it.

—I do not wish to reflect in any way upon the front-line troops in the CES and DSS. However, our job is a legislative one. Our job is to see that the legislation is written in such a way that all people, including those on both sides of the desk, fully understand the requirements. Therefore, I ask the Minister again: is medical treatment a possibility in relation to what could be required under this clause?
—Certainly there can be references to medical treatment, but people are not going to be directed in that respect, no.
—In relation to a person's general deportment and dress, under this clause would it be possible to refer people to personal grooming courses?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding of this-and no doubt my advisers will correct me if I am wrong-is that if one wants to apply for a job as a valet and he has a bone in his nose it is possible that the officers may suggest that he get rid of the bone. But it is not the case that we in the Government will be setting ourselves up as the arbiters of good taste in matters of dress. I cannot rule out the possibility, though, that on some occasions it might be suggested to a client that something might be done about appearance. If one applies for a job in a public contact area, for example a waiter in a club on a Friday night and insists on wearing just shorts and thongs, that could be a problem, and it may be that officers would have to take that into account. I do not want that reply exaggerated into our saying that we will be telling all clients how to dress because we will not be.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 12. Clause 7, page 65, proposed paragraph 606 (1) (e), line 28, after `market' insert `, not being measures compelling the person to work in return for payment of newstart allowance'.

This amendment explicitly negates the possibility of the Secretary requiring a person to work, and this is the measure that I referred to earlier. We all know what it is about so I will not speak further to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply say that it is unfortunate that the Government chooses to rule these matters out absolutely. We certainly take the view that, just as it is impossible to define what might be appropriate in terms of measures to eliminate or reduce any disadvantage, there may well be circumstances in which it is desirable that people be given fairly firm encouragement to pursue a range of other activities. We therefore oppose the removal of the explicit writing in, in this way, and we will be opposing the amendment.

—The Democrats will be supporting this amendment. We argue that the unemployed desperately want to work. The problem is lack of jobs, not lack of interest. I point out to Senator Alston that an amendment that we had before the Committee earlier would have given unemployed people the opportunity to do voluntary work on a far more regular basis. Senator Alston opposed that amendment. I ask Senator Alston specifically now why he opposes the cutting out of compulsory work for the dole when voluntary work was ruled out by him earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the question is directed to me, I should at least attempt to answer it. As I understood the Democrats' amendment, it was not couched in terms of their supplementary notes. They were suggesting that the amendment would allow people over the age of 18 on JSA to undertake voluntary work for up to 60 days. I can accept that there are circumstances in which people may well find that an extended period of voluntary work is appropriate. That may well be the case, for example, for people over 55 years. But to bring it down to people aged 18 years seems to be going against what the Democrats are trying to do in the first instance; that is, having them focus all their efforts on looking for work. If they cannot find that down the line, judgments can be made.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has explained that it is a balance between part time and full time-that one cannot do voluntary work on a full time basis-and again that is reasonable. It is a question of how much part time work is being done before one is effectively disqualified from being able to search actively for employment. Whilst we want to encourage as much voluntary work as possible, we take the view that the priority ought to be looking for work in the first instance. The Democrats' amendment, which would have allowed people to work for up to 60 days per calendar year when they are aged 18 and have only been on JSA for two months, seemed to me to be premature in the extreme. Voluntary work ought to be a last resort. An 18-year-old doing it two months after he or she has joined the dole queue is almost encouraging that person not to find the work that he or she ought to be looking for.

The only other point that Senator Lees put forward in relation to our opposition to the amendment is that we should not take this view at all, that somehow we should not insist that people look for work at any stage. The way she couches her argument here is the way she consistently couches it; that is, to categorise all the unemployed as having precisely the same attitude. We just do not accept that. We certainly accept that the great majority of people want to get into the work force. It makes obvious commonsense to all of us. Most of us are rational human beings. Most of us appreciate that one is better off getting a decent income than trying to subsist on 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. But we cannot generalise across the board. We cannot lump all the unemployed together and say, `All of the unemployed desperately want to work', any more than we can say, `All the unemployed are determined not to work'.

Human nature varies enormously. We ought to tailor our attitude to a judgment that we make about a particular individual or groups or classes of individuals. To apply a rule of thumb or a starting prejudice that somehow all of one group of people are wonderful and all of another group are terrible is almost to guarantee that one will get it wrong. We do not start on that premise. We do not make prejudgments. We simply say that at the end of the day we ought to have the power to require people to do certain things when we judge that all else has failed or that proper efforts are not being made. That is an appropriate response to a situation. One does not rush into it; one assesses what one thinks is reasonable. As the Minister constantly says, no-one is in the business of forcing people to do something. In a Western democracy in the twentieth century one could not get away with it. We are nowhere near that sort of a state.

Most of the accusations and the Democrats' criticism, no doubt, of the Government would be that it has moved across to our view of the world because that is overwhelmingly the view of the community-that there ought to be these sorts of pressures and responses that reflect individual circumstances. There might be a red-necked minority who think that everyone on the dole is bludging. We do not take that view for a moment. Neither do we give people this wonderful, unquestioning benefit of the doubt across the board. In the same way that it cannot be said that everyone on an invalid pension is malingering, it cannot be said that no-one on an invalid pension is malingering. If the Democrats want to approach the debate in that way, they will simply provoke extremist and emotive responses. We do not think that helps. We will continue to argue that there ought to be a lot more sensible discretion applied-and not just to a certain point. We think that, where the political advantage might weigh against going farther down that logical track, rather than backing off, we should go the whole way through, give ourselves a range of options and apply them responsibly and sensitively so that we achieve what we claim to want to do-that is, to maximise everyone's opportunities to ensure that the taxpayer is not left holding the can for those who somehow are not making the effort that is expected of the great majority of others.

A poll conducted by Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd in 1988 not only showed that something like 80 per cent of the community thought that work for the dole was a good idea but also that 71 per cent of the unemployed thought it was not a bad idea, either. I am not taking a broad brush approach and saying that everyone ought to be working for the dole. I am simply saying that, if one is fair dinkum about one's policies, one ought to be prepared to examine all options and look at the best ways in which one can assist. Therefore, one should not rule out an option, as this Government has chosen to do, for political purposes.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 28. Clause 7, page 65, proposed subsection 606 (2), line 34, after ``undertake'', insert ``and the services and programs to be provided to the person to assist them''.
29. Clause 7, page 66, after proposed subsection 606 (4), insert the following subsections:
`` `(4a) In exercising a power under the section, the Secretary must act in accordance with directions from time to time in force under subsection (4B).
`(4b) The Minister, by determination in writing:
(a) must give directions relating to the exercise of the Secretary's power under the section; and
(b) may revoke or vary those directions.
(4c) A determination under subsection (4b) giving, revoking or varying directions is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.'.''.

Firstly, amendment No. 28 provides an obligation on the CES to provide programs. We have discussed this before. I really want to deal with amendment No. 29, which enables the Minister to issue directions regarding the content of the agreement and ensure the Secretary follows these directions, which will be disallowable instruments. We covered quite a bit of this ground earlier when the Minister said that flexibility was needed. Perhaps the Minister can summarise that by explaining specifically why we do not have a disallowable instrument before us so that we, the unemployed, the CES and the DSS all understand exactly what will be required.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed new section 606 outlines the powers of the Secretary. The Secretary has to be taken into account in drawing up these agreements. The Bill provides that the Secretary has to look at a persons's needs in assessing that person's capacity to undertake some sort of activity. It is all there. This all goes back to what I have said on about a dozen amendments so far: the specifics of the agreement will always be subject to negotiation between the client and the Department. Surely that is the crux of the issue. I am not even sure what this amendment is supposed to do. Already the Bill sets out what the Secretary has to take into account. In any event, if clients do not like it, we are telling the clients about their right of appeal, and clients will not sign it if they do not like it. Perhaps we are setting up straw men and knocking them over, but it is not really helping anybody. I do not understand the real purpose of this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall try again to clarify it for the Minister. We are putting people in a situation where, if they do not comply, they will then lose their income. I believe that they have a right to know very specifically-and as we discussed earlier, there is a catch-all clause there; the one that says, `Any measures designed to eliminate or reduce any disadvantage' et cetera. This is one of the reasons I went through a number of the questions that had been put to me about what people would be required to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment is very stressful for most people. I take Senator Alston's point that there will always be a small number of people in whatever profession, whatever temporary occupation, whether they be unemployed or sickness beneficiaries, who are considered not to be pulling their weight. But should we put those people out on the street? I ask the Minister specifically to look at the difficulties people will have when they do not fully understand what all the requirements may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, with the start of an initiative of the scope of this one, I will have to monitor it constantly. I do not intend simply to leave it alone and have a look at it again in a year's time. I will be watching to see how agreements are going and what kind of problems we are encountering. We can administratively sort out any of the difficulties that might occur. I go back to the central point, which is that this is an agreement between two parties, negotiated between two parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The CES does not intend to use its clout to crush the aspirations of the person on the other side of the table; rather, it is there to help. It is a classic case of people from the Government being there to help. With these agreements, we will be seeking to make sure that we talk through with individuals what their skills are, what possibilities there are for improving those skills, what areas of employment they might be able to seek, and what programs they can benefit from. That is the emphasis of this. That is what it is all about. I can assure honourable senators that we will be looking at this constantly and so will Minister Dawkins. We hope that there will be no need for any intervention because the system will work well. I am confident that that is the case. But, if on the off chance there is a problem here, we can intervene administratively and sort it out.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Clause 7, page 66, proposed paragraph 606 (5) (c), line 17, after ``time to time'' insert ``at the request of either party to the agreement''.

This amendment seeks to insert into proposed new section 606 the words `at the request of either party to the agreement' after the reference to `time to time'. It is pretty much a tidying up exercise. I do not think it is of great import.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrat amendment No. 30 is very similar to the one the Government has just successfully moved. Therefore I move on to amendment No. 31. I move:

This again looks at the compulsory element. Obviously, it is not going to be accepted, but the alternative includes provisions that the terms of the agreement have to be reasonable. I understand the Minister's line on this. Again he goes back to administrative law, but the problem again is that the people on the other side of the table, those who have to undertake the agreement, may not fully understand. It would surely be far better for them if the word `reasonable' were included so that they will be required to attend negotiations at reasonable times and so that a notice advising a person that he or she has failed to enter the agreement must actually set out the reasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

31b. Clause 7, page 66, proposed subparagraph 607 (b) (iii), line 28, after ``agree to'', insert ``any reasonable''.

31c. Clause 7, page 66, proposed subparagraph 607 (c), lines 32 and 33, after ``notice'', insert ``in writing'' and after ``agreement'', insert ``and such notice shall set out the reasons for the giving of the notice''.

These amendments were to be moved in case amendment 31 was not agreed to. I think I have already given my explanation. I was very disappointed to see the Opposition remove an amendment which, I understand, was very similar to ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Clause 7, page 66, at the end of proposed section 607 add the following subsection:
``(2) A notice under paragraph (1) (c) must:
(a) be in writing; and
(b) set out the reasons for the decision to give the notice; and
(c) include a statement describing the rights of the person to apply for the review of the decision.''.

The effect of amendment No. 10 is that where a person is taken to have failed to enter into a Newstart activity agreement, that person must be notified in writing of the decision and the reasons for the decision and must be given with details of appeal rights. This is at the heart of a number of Senator Lees's concerns. It is not the case that we are just hoping that an officer will tell people. We are setting for ourselves quite a standard, a standard which the CES has not been in the habit of following. It does put some sort of administrative burden on it, but for the sake of fairness and equity the Government has taken up the suggestion and we are including it in this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support this amendment. We are very pleased to see it here. I understand that it was through negotiations with Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) that it was agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

33. Clause 7, page 67, proposed subparagraph 608 (1) (j) (ii), lines 32 to 34, omit the subparagraph.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support this amendment, as we have supported each and every other Government amendment, apart from amendment No. 12.

SPEECH.PARA: 46. Clause 7, page 84, proposed section 625, lines 4 to 34, omit the section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Senate adjourned last night at midnight I was outlining how the Telecommunications Bill 1991 and the six associated Bills, by the merging of Telecom Australia and OTC Ltd and the introduction of a competing second carrier, were in fact introducing sweeping reforms. While indicating our reluctant support for the Bills as the lesser of two evils, I outlined some of the problems that the Australian Democrats have with these Bills-namely, the extraordinary amount of ministerial discretion whereby the scrutiny of Parliament is bypassed; the need for increased consumer protection; and the fact that we are being asked to accept in good faith that the Government, with major pieces of the overall plan missing at this point in time, would, without question, do the right thing further down the track.

SPEECH.PARA: I now want to turn my attention to what tangible action can be taken to assist Australia's potential to develop a valuable export-oriented telecommunications equipment and capabilities industry-and I believe that potential is enormous. Australia's exports of vital telecommunications equipment have increased three-fold in the last four years. Compared with the outstanding balance of payments debt, the $240m worth of export earnings of this industry last year is a mere drop in the bucket. But it is an industry which produces tangibles, and while the entrepreneurs were assets stripping in the 1980s local telecommunications manufacturers were growing an industry producing export quality, innovative and diverse products, along with skilled employees.

The Telecommunications Bill 1991 omits all references to this $3 billion growth industry. Lip service has been paid to preserving a telecommunications manufacturing base as the spearhead of Australia's launch into the global telecommunications markets. In November last year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) claimed that the introduction of deregulation would be a major boost for Australian industry, particularly telephone manufacturers. But the United States example shows that because of imports of cheap equipment from South East Asia, the majority of telephone manufacturing companies in the United States no longer exist. Since this Bill makes no specific reference to the protection of Australia's equipment, skills and capabilities in the telecommunications equipment industry, the Democrats will be moving two amendments which we feel will give both flexibility and a guarantee.

Overall, it is the nature of this Bill that it deals exclusively with the needs, desires, wishes and wants of the network carriers. That is its priority and it leaves little room for the needs of the Australian community for a locally-based high technology telecommunications industry. We argue that once the knowledge base, skills and ideas have been lost they are irretrievably lost. In addition to including new clauses in the objectives of the Act, I intend to move an amendment to the carrier licence conditions which will require carriers to bias their purchases in favour of Australian manufacturers where they are able to do so.

Another potential problem we see with the Bill is the impact Austel's regulatory powers of technical planning would have on the broadcasting industry. Broadcasters are licensed under the Broadcasting Act 1942 which is currently under review. Technical conditions pertaining to licence warrant are determined by the Minister. Notwithstanding the fact that there is a Minister in common, the technical regimes are currently quite different and will remain so unless the Broadcasting Act 1942 is amended-which we expect will happen.

The Telecommunications Bill puts the broadcasting industry in the invidious position of being answerable to two statutory authorities at the same time. Under this Bill, Austel will be responsible for the planning and technical regulation of broadcasters. We believe the potential for conflict is enormous. For these reasons we believe that the Telecommunications Act should be subject to the Broadcasting Act in the same way as the Radio Communications Act 1983.

Last night Senator Alston spent a considerable part of his speech talking about the inefficiencies of Telecom and the successes of OTC and stating again, as we know, that the Opposition will privatise Telecom and OTC and anything else. I want to state again our view that Telecom, whilst a monopoly, has not been as inefficient as its critics claim and that there is still a role for a public monopoly. We have lost that battle so we are now in the process of salvaging what I think is best for the new, merged public utility.

We think it is a bit of a cheek to charge two public utilities, which have already been paid for by the public, a merger fee of around $1 billion simply for the luxury of implementing Government policy. We do not think it is at all ethical to use this Bill as a backdoor revenue raising measure, so we will be denying the Government this form of revenue raising.

In conclusion, these are tremendously important Bills and the focus of the Democrats' amendments to these Bills is to reduce the unseemly high level of ministerial discretion, to ensure environmental protection, which my colleague Senator Coulter will address, to facilitate public input, and to maximise consumer protection so that some years down the track we will continue to have a healthy, viable and competitive telecommunications industry in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address some fairly brief remarks tonight to the Telecommunications Bill 1991 and related Bills. I want to dwell, as Senator Kernot may have expected, on some of the positive aspects of the coalition's policies in relation to telecommunications, specifically the need to privatise telecommunications and create a more competitive market. Senator Kernot mentioned some matters which are of concern to all Australians. She dwelt initially on the potential for these matters to affect the quality of life of virtually every Australian. An extremely high percentage of our population has access to the telecommunications network.
—The highest in the world.

—Exactly. That is particularly the case in relation to people in the Asia-Pacific region. Senator Kernot sparked a thought in my mind when she mentioned the capacity of the telecommunications system to affect people's lives. As I looked across the chamber last night, I saw Senator Richardson sitting there. I am sure that he would have liked the phone system to have had the capacity to affect people's lives in a far more effective way over the weekend. But I will get on to the more serious issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition speaker before me, the shadow Minister responsible for telecommunications, Senator Alston, referred to some of the inefficiencies of Telecom Australia. On a number of occasions the Opposition has applauded the increases in efficiency in Telecom. They have been numerous and there has been an increase in productivity and efficiency within Telecom. Most people who are affected by the telecommunications system in Australia do, however, recognise that further reforms could deliver benefits to the consumers. The Opposition argues that, unless we privatise Telecom and allow it access to capital without the restrictions imposed by government and the fiscal constraints imposed upon this Government at the moment, we will not get an increase in efficiency and productivity that we need.

A recent study by the Australian Telecommunications Users Group estimated that competitive reforms within Telecom could secure a 20 per cent reduction in labour and capital requirements. This would give a 15 per cent price reduction and save users in the order of $1 billion. That equates to about 18c per day per user of telecommunications. If we stretch the bow a little bit longer, that is almost one free call a day per user in Australia or 30 free calls per month. That would be of significant benefit to both business and normal residential users of the telecommunications network. That example illustrates the potential that can be achieved if we have a competitive telecommunications system.

The Opposition fears that the Government proposal-the megacom proposal, the duopoly proposal-will be unable to deliver the sort of competitive environment that Australia needs. Senator Kernot and Senator Alston have both referred to the great potential for a telecommunications industry in Australia to become a global industry able to compete on the international stage and able to create rapidly growing employment opportunities for Australians. As I said, it would provide a very positive input to Australia's export income during the next 10 to 15 years.

It is worth noting the amount of telecommunications in Australia in comparison with our near Asia-Pacific neighbours. In Australia and New Zealand, there are roughly 50 lines per 100 people; I think it is something like 45 in Australia and about the same in New Zealand. In comparison, Indonesia has 0.5 of a line per 100 people; Malaysia has 7.4 lines per 100 people- clearly more developed; the Philippines has 1 line per 100 people; China has 0.2 lines per 100 people. When we bear in mind that China has a population of 1.1 billion people, if that figure increased just marginally, the potential for growth in the Chinese market alone is quite phenomenal. The nation of Vietnam, which is now rapidly opening up, has is only 0.1 of a line per head of population.

Honourable senators who had the chance this morning to read Newsweek, the magazine in The Bulletin, would have noticed that it featured an article about Vietnam. The prediction was that Vietnam could easily become another Korea within the next 10 to 15 years. That sort of rapid development creates enormous potential in the telecommunications business. There are already a number of companies in Australia trying to get into Vietnam's telecommunications market.

One does not really need to be an Einstein to work out that, in the business of telecommunications, there is potential for growth, potential for export earnings for Australians and potential for employment which is very significant in this Asia-Pacific region. Australia can quite readily service this need, particularly when we consider that we are in the same time zone. We have a lot of common links with the region. The Minister at the table, Senator Collins, who lives in Darwin when he can, would realise that the closeness of Australia to Asia certainly makes this a market which we can develop very rapidly.

It is also interesting to look at what has happened with employment in Australia. There has been a terrible downward swing in employment levels and an upward swing in unemployment levels. For example, in the agricultural sector, there has been an increase in unemployment of 163 per cent and, in agricultural services, 345 per cent in the past 12 months.

However, there are two sectors that have shown an increase in employment. It would not surprise many of my colleagues to know that the public administration and defence sector is one of the few areas where there has been an increase in the employment levels over the past 12 months, whereas just about every other sector has shown a massive decline in employment. One other sector which is a bright light in the Australian employment scene is the communications sector. I cannot quote any national figures, but I do have in front of me the figures for Western Australia where in 1990 there were 9,384 people employed in that sector. That figure has increased to 12,401 in the current year. So just over 3,000 more people have become employed in that sector in my home State of Western Australia. Even though Telecom is a monopoly, the changes that are about to come about as a consequence of this legislation, it is fair to say, indicate that the communications industry is a bright light for an improved employment and economic outlook, and it will continue to be so.

There is one other example that highlights the potential for Australia's telecommunications industry internationally and that relates to the international traffic that flows through Australia. We compare very favourably with some of the rapidly expanding economies in our region. Japan, for example, has 319 million minutes of international traffic through its network. Singapore, a much smaller country, has an international traffic level of 99 million minutes through its network. Australia, by way of comparison, has 239 million minutes of international traffic through its network. So here is another area where Australians demonstrated a clear comparative advantage. We must ensure, moving into the next decade, that we can take advantage of that situation. We must then ask ourselves what the Government's approach is to maximising these export opportunities.

I reiterate that the telecommunications market is set to expand to a level of about $178 billion by 1995, just in the Asia-Pacific region alone. The growth in gross domestic product of those nations in our immediate backyard, as I term it, is about 10 per cent per annum. The international traffic increase is expected to be about 25 per cent in that time.

What, then, is the Government's approach? Its approach is to set up a duopoly instead of a monopoly. I guess that a duopoly will be epitomised by the fact that Telecom-which is capital starved at the moment; no-one would deny that-would be combined with OTC, which has already been described as a relatively successful organisation, and a duopolist competitor would be created based on the debt-ridden Aussat Pty Ltd.

Certainly from the Opposition's point of view, the outcome from setting up a structure for the future of telecommunications would probably be far from ideal. Desirable outcomes would be to increase competition; to increase the number of opportunities for all people wanting to play the telecommunications game to get involved; to ensure that we have the most efficient production and delivery of telecommunications services, both within Australia and internationally; to reduce prices to the Australian people, which I have already demonstrated could take place; and to make us as competitive as possible internationally in an area in which we have already proven that we have a comparative competitive advantage.

Telecom's ability to compete has already been severely affected by its financial constraints. Clearly, by retaining it in public ownership, those financial constraints will remain. By subjecting it to further competition, I guess that it is fair to say that its current financial disadvantages can only be increased. I suggest that privatising telecommunications and creating fair and open competition will give Telecom and other players in the game the ability and advantage of being able to move right out to the leading edge of technology and export capabilities and competition within the region. I do not think it is fair to the telecommunications industry as a whole to allow it to have the shackles which would be associated with the highly regulated duopoly which we are about to enter into under this legislation.

I conclude my remarks by reiterating some main fundamentals of the Opposition's approach to this area. That approach does not, of course, follow the United Kingdom example of creating a highly regulated duopoly or of privatising an authority such as Telecom before creating a fair playing field, to use an oft-stated cliche of this year. We believe that the Government has firstly to create a fair playing field to create an environment where there can be full and effective competition and then to privatise Telecom-cum-Megacom. We have specified in our policy that Australian ownership would be maintained in a majority and that the employees of Megacom or Telecom would be given preference. Our privatisation of Telecom would take into account the state of the Australian capital markets and the potential of those markets to absorb the float of that body. We have also specified that community service obligations would be met in a most politically accountable, clear and visible manner and appropriated from the Budget.

The other matter which is obviously a very important part of that process is to allow the private sector, the capital markets and small, medium-sized and big investors to put the capital into this body, which is clearly demonstrated as being in an industry where there will be growth and profits in the next 10 to 15 years. That is something that cannot happen under the public ownership scenario that we have at the moment.

My final comments relate to the ideological battle between the political parties at the moment and how this relates to efficiency, the future of Australians and their future potential employment prospects. We clearly have a leaning towards more competition and privatisation, getting public ownership out of these trading type enterprises where we see that there is no role for government. There is clearly a role in the regulation area to ensure that there is a fair playing field, but certainly not in running an operation and being involved in service delivery.

Members of the Government have often accused this Opposition of having a high esteem for the Thatcher solutions and turning to Margaret Thatcher's examples in the United Kingdom whenever we talk about privatisation. One of the benefits of having been in opposition for eight years is that we can learn from some of the mistakes made not only in Great Britain with privatisation but all around the world. One of the great mistakes, which is certainly recognised here and by the speaker before me, Senator Kernot, was that a duopoly was set up. I must admit that private monopolies are not a hell of a lot better than public monopolies, and duopolies are not a hell of a lot better than monopolies.

I am asking this Government to learn from the United Kingdom example. A comparison based on the scale of world local call charges shows that Australia has the second highest local call charges and that Great Britain has the highest, taking aside all the reasons for that, be it the size of the nation or how far apart we all are. If we look at all the empirical evidence, the call charges and how much we pay out of our pockets at the end of the month, we can see how that affects the average consumer in Perth, in Darwin or in Melbourne. Great Britain has the highest local call charge in the world and Australia has the second highest. So why do we not as a nation put aside ideological considerations and our attachment to the members of the telecommunications unions and try to create a structure for telecommunications that will deliver benefits to the people of Australia-the users of the telecommunications system-and create export opportunities? I put it to the Government that the example that occurred in the United Kingdom would lead us to believe that the industry does require as much competition as possible, that a duopoly is not the ideal outcome and that a vigorous telecommunications structure which allowed as many players to get involved would certainly increase competition, lower prices and benefit consumers by increasing service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with pleasure to speak in support of my colleagues in this telecommunications debate. This is a very interesting subject. Obviously, the purpose of the Telecommunications Bill 1991 and allied Bills is to provide competition in the telecommunications field. For far too long we have had a monopoly in the telecommunications system in Australia. Telecom Australia is providing a top service. However, it has been controlled by the telecommunications union, resulting in a lot of inefficiencies. For example, as Senator Campbell has told us, Australia has the second highest local call rate in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of these Bills is to provide some competition by replacing the current regulatory regime. The central proposals are a scheme of licensing of general and mobile telecommunications service providers; the reservation of certain telecommunications services to licence holders; the provision of access to rights to networks; and a scheme for the subsidisation of standard telephone services for remote areas. This legislation came about as a result of a statement made back in 1988 by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans. To achieve the aims of this legislation, obviously a cartel such as the Australian Telecommunications Authority has to be the instrumental body to regulate the industry. The Government is going about it by merging Telecom and OTC Ltd, which, incidentally, the Opposition opposes.

As I said a little earlier, Telecom does provide a good service. If one travels around the world, one will find exactly how good it is. In the deregulated system that America has, people who want to telephone out of the country are indeed very lucky if they happen to have the call number for OTC. Immediately they get that OTC connection, they have no further trouble.

But when one tries to contact Australia from America, Europe or other countries through their systems and using their carriers, I am afraid that one runs into nothing but trouble. I am full of praise for the way in which both Telecom and OTC operate. Unfortunately, as I have already mentioned, Telecom charges for internal service calls are certainly too high. There are also other regulations that annoy one in these deregulated times. Australia has either the highest or second highest call rate but, when one compares our subscriber trunk dialling charges with some of the European charges, especially those of Switzerland, Germany and Italy, we come out very well.

We are going to merge Telecom and OTC and then provide another competing carrier. Here we have a forced marriage, a shotgun marriage or whatever one likes to call it. Not only is it a shotgun marriage but there is also a forced dowry of $1 billion which has to be paid for the combination. In moving towards the duopoly system, we find that the competitor will come from the sale of Aussat-including its debts-to a willing buyer. To sweeten it up a certain amount and hopefully get someone interested, the Australian Telecommunications Authority (Austel) will provide, through the Bill, a cellular mobile telephone service to go along with it. Because of the duopoly, Austel had recommended that there should be three carriers allocated simultaneously around the time of deregulation but, unfortunately, as a result of this Bill, there will be no other competition until 1997.

I move on to the basics of how it is going to operate. The competitor, having been set up, will have a right of access to use the current Telecom network in connecting at a determined cost-which could be called an access cost, for want of a better word-but Telecom will have to make that very transparent and have a cap on the charge for that calling. I fail to see how that is really going to be carried out because Telecom, or Megacom-the OTC-Telecom combination-will be the big dealers in a situation with the new competitor not even hoping to achieve more than the 30 per cent of the play by 1997, if I have got it right.

The Telecom-OTC combination will be in a position to provide other than good competition to the competitor, depending on the price of that connection fee. Let us hope that good competition will come about, particularly in view of the non-competition from cellular mobile telephone systems. We do not quite know how that cellular mobile system is going to operate; whether it is going to cover all Australia, certain areas of Australia or, indeed, be restricted to the capital cities. That is where we could have got the necessary competition to the Telecom-OTC set-up. I believe that we will get that competition in time if technology is allowed to take over but technology can be held up by regulation. Whether the prevention of other mobile cellular systems until 1997 will stop other technology coming forward, I do not quite know.

Just getting away from technology, I note that one of the measures that goes along with the deregulated system will be that the two carriers will still provide the connection to the first telephone in a property until 1993. After that it will be only to the boundary of the property. Let us talk more about remote areas. I welcome this measure because if Telecom, or whoever it is, is supplying a service for telephone connections to a rather large property where the homestead is 20, 30 or 50 kilometres away from the boundary-although, if one gets to that distance one is more likely to use radio telephone connections-this is a step forward. Those property owners can be connected a lot more cheaply by using licensed private technicians-telectricians, or whatever word one likes to use. The property owner would simply have to buy the suitable approved cable at the best available price and find a contractor or someone who has got the equipment to plough it in so as to bring the connection to the homestead. Then the first telephone and the other necessary material can go in from there. I welcome that sort of thing.

Getting back to the duopoly and the sort of competition it may not get, I do believe that technology will take over in time and provide a certain amount of competition. If we look back over the years we see that Telecom was saved from the progress of technology by the advent, some years ago, of the optic fibre. If the optic fibre had not come along when it did, we would have had a greater extension of the satellite technology. I believe that the satellite technology in Australia has been neglected to a certain extent.

I know that price is a consideration, but with our Aussat system we could have made greater use of advancements in satellite technology. Unfortunately we did not. I believe that Telecom had a lot to play in that line by making sure that satellite technology did not get off the ground too much. Of course, its efficiency in the provision of services was increased greatly by the use of the optic fibre. But the advanced state of optic fibre will not last forever. I believe that the Aussat II systems of satellites which are due after 1992-or some time like that-will make a lot of difference.

I refer to some information that I received from Telecom as a result of questions I asked at Estimates committee hearings. While I am on the subject of Telecom at Estimates, I give credit to Telecom because this year it was much more forthcoming with its information than it was the previous year when I gave it a blast and put a reservation in the report that it had not been too cooperative and forthcoming. However, this year Telecom was certainly 100 per cent better in answering the questions that I asked and it has made me far more aware about a lot of the up-dated technology. However, we should bear in mind that the cellular mobile system can never get beyond 20 per cent of the geographical area of Australia. In other words, the remote geographical areas covering 80 per cent of Australia will never have cellular telephones as we know them now.

Certain projects are being considered. One is the Iridium project, which is a low earth orbit mobile satellite technology which Motorola developed in the United States of America. It uses a constellation of satellites which we are able to make great use of. The unfortunate part about it, even though it has application in Australia, is that it cannot be used for a favourite subject of mine; that is, safety precautions, where we could have a safety network by using certain receivers or transmitters-not that we use them to broadcast or receive-to notify a certain location.

There is another mobile system which Telecom is experimenting with, along with others, using cellular mobile phones with the Inmarsat satellite system. With the technology available that could be used in remote areas but the cost would be around $70,000 per service and $10 per minute to use. Of course, in this day and age that is out of the question. I believe that in three to five years time those sorts of things will be viable for use in remote areas.

Another project involves Mobilesat, which is to be provided on the B-type series of Aussat satellites and which is due to be launched in early 1992. I believe that these projects will be useful in providing the technology to provide communications in remote areas. OTC is experimenting with another set-up called Fleetcoms. Those are the sorts of innovations, developed partly by Telecom, that I believe are around the corner and will provide services in remote areas of Australia.

I turn briefly to the community service obligation, which is the provision of telephones and other equipment that are not readily available in certain areas. My fear is that, with the privatisation of communications, those areas may miss out. After the merger it will be mandatory for Telecom and OTC to provide those services, but it is not quite spelt out to what extent and to what areas they will be provided. From my reading of the legislation, any proposed new carrier has not quite spelt out how it will carry out community service obligations. Perhaps it will just rely on the Telecom-OTC combination or it might be fulfilled by others on contract. I have heard various explanations of how it might work. Indeed, an American group gave our interested back bench committee a run-down on how it could work. But it was never spelt out to me. One of the biggest reservations I have with this sort of merger is how those community service obligations will be kept in Australia.

In conclusion, we are opposing the merger of OTC and Telecom because we believe there are many other ways of going about it. I have grave reservations about not making more cellular mobile systems available. All in all, we will have to see how this duopoly performs a few years down the track. I have very grave fears that we will finish up with an English type of duopoly system. Probably, once it has been in action for a few years, the Government will have to look at changing the current measures and conditions. However, I look forward to seeing how it will work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to place on the record the success of the corporatisation and then privatisation of Telecom in New Zealand and to say that I think we have some good lessons to learn from the manner in which it has proceeded-which is to deregulate to a far greater extent than the Government's proposal does. Indeed, it is much more in line with Opposition policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular aspect that I want to deal with is the proposal to not only retain the Australian Telecommunications Authority-Austel-in the new scheme of things but, indeed, to beef it up, as it were, and give it more powers and more scope for regulating. Looking at the explanatory memorandum to the Telecommunications Bill at page 27, one sees that the sorts of powers that are set out there make it judge, jury and executioner. The inevitable result of establishing such a body, to my mind, and looking at the international experience, is that we build a bureaucracy which, in one way or another, can end up a captive of the industry which it is meant to serve.

I suggest a proposition which I think is worthwhile; that is, having a study to determine whether we require Austel at all. I think there is a very good case to be made out for following the New Zealand example. It has no industry specific regulating body but simply uses the Commerce Commission, under section 36 of the Commerce Act, to perform the regulatory functions. Similarly, in Australia, we could use the Trade Practice Commission to carry out any regulatory function which is indeed needed. As I have said, to have an industry specific regulator does not serve the interests of the people who are operating in the field, nor is it of particular assistance to consumers.

The interesting fact that I was able to discern from looking at the New Zealand experience and how, indeed, closer economic relations ought to be able to allow a greater across-Tasman liberalisation of the telecommunications industry to the benefit of Australia, was one very simple statistic. The one that impressed me most was that the cost of a toll call from New Zealand to Australia is 99c in New Zealand currency, which is about 75c in Australian currency. But the cost of a toll call the other way-from Australia to New Zealand-via OTC Ltd-is $1.50 in Australian dollars. In other words, it costs twice as much to call New Zealand from Australia as it does to call Australia from New Zealand. When we look at the other statistics, which perhaps I will have to deal with when we resume our consideration of the legislation, we see that the picture that can be painted for greater deregulation rather than less is the way we ought to go. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
