INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 7.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to raise some matters which particularly affect my State. I believe that an unforgivable fraud has been perpetrated against the South Australian public. South Australians have been led to believe, by and large, that `their bank', the State Bank of South Australia, was properly managed. They have been led to believe that the bank's problems are relatively new and the impression has been created that but for high interest rates and a falling property market everything would have been okay.

SPEECH.PARA: Certain information available to me leads me to conclude that all has not been well for some considerable time and that the bank's problems spread far wider than rising interest rates and falling property markets. For management and the board to manage properly, they must be able to rely on the information available to them. While shareholders-you and I-rely on external auditors to ascertain the veracity of public accounts, management and the board have internal audit to ensure that the information on which they base their decisions is accurate and reliable.

In an entity such as a bank, and especially a bank determined to grow and grow fast in a risk laden competitive market, internal audit should be given the highest priority. It should have the resources, the qualified staff and the independence to do its job. Above all, it must have free and ready access to the board. It now appears that the bank's internal audit department had none of these requisites. The information available to me indicates that the internal audit function was regarded by some not as a friend but as a foe. While Australians have been watching every dollar they earn, desperately trying to meet their mortgage payments, the State Bank has not watched taxpayers' dollars anywhere nearly as carefully as it could have.

There are a number of points I want to put before the Senate that I think justify the claims that I have made, and I will deal with them seriatim. Point one: prior to January 1989 internal audit was not conducted with appropriately skilled or qualified people in all entities. A comprehensive report was prepared into the operations of the department and included a series of recommendations.

Point 2: Since January 1987, some time ago, there has been significant change in the emphasis of the internal audit department, including the introduction of an internal audit charter, organisational structure and staffing changes, and a reappraisal of audit approach.

Point 3: An internal audit committee was established from a proposal by Ms M. Chin and Mr Tim Marcus Clark's initial response-I stress, initial response-was that it was unnecessary bureaucracy. The committee was established after Ms Chin held discussions with other members of the board to rally support. Prior to this, internal and external auditors made representations to the board, but this may have been restricted, depending on the board's agenda.
Point 4: On 28 September 1988 the board minutes indicated that the board was to meet on a six-monthly basis with both internal and external audit, following completion of accounts.

Point 5: The audit committee was formed with terms of reference, drafted by Ms Chin, including, firstly, that an internal audit committee cover the financial affairs of the bank and the bank group, and, secondly, a requirement that the committee consider any matter relating to the financial affairs that it determines to be desirable and any matters referred by the board. The terms of reference for this audit committee have an overriding limitation that the committee has no executive power as to its findings and recommendations and Mr Marcus Clark stressed that the audit committee was not to take over the board's responsibility.
Point 6: The committee consisted principally of non-executive directors; however, the general manager of group finance had the right to attend and to speak at all meetings.

Point 7: Ernst and Young-one of the bank's external auditors-was unable to assess the follow-up of a number of issues raised at the audit committee, namely, a review of corporate banking and the large number of unsecured loans; concern over the lack of global risk management systems; a review of delegation of authorities for lending approvals in offshore offices; London's external auditor's concerns about the lack of proper systems, especially treasury, management of interest rates, foreign exchange trading and large exposure to the property market; the New York auditor's concern about large write-offs and tax losses; and, lastly, concern regarding Beneficial Finance Corporation Ltd about joint venture projects and off balance sheet companies-something much discussed in South Australia.

Point 8: The internal audit charter was in existence but not approved by the board until, as I understand it, 28 June 1989. This may reflect the lack of importance afforded the internal audit function by senior management. With respect to the reporting line detailed in the charter-that is, the reporting line of the internal audit where it goes through the organisation-there are a number of points. Firstly, the charter is not up to date as the audit committee is not reflected. Secondly, the line detailed is not flexible enough to ensure independence; that is, to the managing director through the Chief General Manager, Global Risk Management, or, if necessary, the Chairman of the board. In addition, the reporting line-a term I stress that is much understood by auditors-is further removed as it goes through the Chief General Manager of Finance.

Point 9: The internal audit department was fragmented, with data processing audit separately housed until 1989. It was not until July 1990 that the varying degrees of internal audit departments, namely, Beneficial Finance Corporation Ltd, Executor Trustee Australia Ltd, Oceanic Capital Corporation Ltd and United Banking Group Ltd were progressively brought together under the control of group internal audit.

Point 10: Prior to July 1985 personnel were recruited from within the bank to staff internal audit and it is only in recent times that people have been employed with tertiary qualifications and/or specific audit experience. At the board meeting of 22 August 1985 the external auditors indicated that there was a need to increase the expertise of internal audit with respect to corporate and international banking, data processing, foreign exchange and money market operations. On 25 August, I think last year, the board also noted that the skills of internal audit had improved, though treasury was still a problem. A review by KPMG Peat Marwick in August 1989 of treasury audit staff concluded that staff did not have the necessary skills and experience. In a memorandum written by G. Yelland, on 6 September last year, it was indicated that audit staff did not have the qualifications to handle the strategic risk management.
Point 11: A significant proportion of the senior staff did not have formal qualifications and the qualified staff the bank has are generally new and lack experience in bank auditing.

Point 12: Ernst and Young identified that training was provided to internal audit staff; however, it did not proceed further. Given that its review identified a lack of skills, further explanation needs to be carried out on that situation.

Point 13: The internal audit department has conducted a series of reviews in the group members; however, these were only recently completed. Reviews that have been undertaken include a review of the Ayres Finniss Group in December 1990, of Ayres Finniss Information Systems in February 1991, of the Day Cutten Group in December 1990, of the Executor Trustee Group on 1 October 1990 and of the Oceanic Group on 11 December 1990.

Point 14: The audit of Beneficial Finance Corporation may have operated ineffectively-and I stress `may have'-for two reasons: first, that the focus may not have been on the high risk areas and, secondly, that findings may not have been communicated to the board in their entirety. That is a very serious allegation to make, that findings may not have gone to the board. I refer honourable senators to my initial remarks about the importance of internal audit. It is there as a friend of management and the board and if findings are not passed on it is a very serious matter.

Point 15: While the bank rapidly expanded offshore and increased its treasury and international banking activity, the internal audit department had limited involvement in these areas. As to internal audits conducted overseas-for the London office, which was established in 1878, the first internal audit was in April 1988. For the New York office, established in November 1987, the first internal audit was in April 1988. For the Hong Kong office, which was established in May 1986, the first internal audit was in April 1989.

The external auditors Ernst and Young indicated that these reviews were relatively brief and for treasury and international activities the first audits of the New York and London offices were April-May 1990. They also noted that a reason for the lack of audit was a reluctance to provide overseas holidays to internal audit. In May 1990 the internal audit manager Ms Chin noted that there had never been any audit of information systems of the international offices. That is a damning indictment of a bank wanting to expand in a risky and competitive market internationally.

Point 16: Corporate banking was not subject to review by internal audit until June 1990. Again, can I say that that is where the banks problems have been, in corporate banking, the area of greatest expansion, I understand.

Point 17: There have been a number of instances where management was reluctant to allow internal audit unrestricted access. That is what I believe it should have. In May 1989, G. Abbot commented on not assessing group human resources information. On 20 November 1990, there was a file note by Ms Chin on the audit committee meeting that clarification was required as to `areas of restricted information'. On 21 September 1990, there was a memo from Mr S. Paddison:
I wish to sound a word of caution that I will most strongly resist the intrusion of Group Audit into areas which I believe are the proper province of management.

On 13 March 1991, apparently there was in existence an internal memo to the Chief Executive Officer advising that Mr Malouf, who I think is now the Managing Director of Beneficial Finance Corporation, but I may be wrong in that respect, was still refusing access to the Beneficial Finance Corporation salary packages. If the importance of that is lost, I remind honourable senators that Beneficial Finance Corporation is a wholly owned subsidiary of the State Bank.
Point 18: The report on internal audit to the board for the year ended 30 June 1990 indicated that there was a shift from compliance type audits to a broader risk-based approach.

Point 19: A number of special investigations were undertaken including, first, the board requested an investigation of Beneficial Finance Corporation and, secondly, it requested a review of group exposure to various key employees and directors. That aspect has been the matter of much public discussion in South Australia.

Point 20: The audit planning process appears not to be adequate. Audit planning has originated primarily from within the internal audit department and has not had strategic direction. From the aforementioned comments one could conclude that internal audit was not properly planned to do a number of things: first, to cover all areas and functions both within the bank and across the group and, secondly, to give appropriate emphasis to tasks based on risks to the individual organisations and the combined risks faced by the group as a whole.

Point 21: Three external reviews of work done by internal audit have been done so far. They are: the review of treasury and internal audit function by Peat Marwick Hungerfords in August 1989; a review of the Reserve Bank reporting functions by Touche Ross on 28 November 1990; and a review of internal audit assignments at Beneficial Finance Corporation by Price Waterhouse, dated 22 January 1991.
Point 22: There are indications that audit memoranda were circulated and that management did not respond, and the response received may not have always been in the spirit expected.

I assume from the information available to me that this list of allegations, which I have put as neatly and as closely to the original form in which I received them as possible, is known to the Auditor-General of South Australia, and that at least brings me some comfort. Indeed, these allegations may form part of the Auditor-General's investigation into the State Bank.

In conclusion, all I can say is that the internal audit function of any company, especially one that is seeking to expand in a high risk, international and competitive market, must be given all the resources, qualified staff and independence necessary to do its job. It must have free and ready access to the board. From the 22 points that I have referred to, from information available to me, it appears that the State Bank's internal audit department had none of those requisites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Where trade and industry flourish, society prospers. That makes it easier to develop a fair, gracious and civilised community, to the advantage of all. The public interest requires that trade and industry be carried out in a context most conducive to their success. The general good is prejudiced where trade and industry are damaged by the delinquent conduct of individuals or groups. The common law holds that restraint of trade is against public policy. It has done so for centuries. It holds that contracts are sacrosanct and that penalties should be visited on those who interfere with them. That, too, is an ancient maxim.

SPEECH.PARA: These two concepts have done much for the health of industry. They have helped producers and traders to carry on their businesses free from unfair competition and have assured that commercial agreements will be honoured. Consumers have benefited as a result. But there is a dark side to these concepts. They have kept other much needed ones from influencing the common law. This has left an unhappy bias in that grand institution. While it can be called in aid by those whose commercial interests are threatened, it gives little help to those whose wages and conditions are poor, to the environment when it is put at risk, or to animals faced with extinction.

Why does the common law pay much attention to the interests of commerce and industry and much less to the welfare of workers and the conservation of the world about us? Why does it give marked consideration to but one dimension of an issue? Part of the answer lies in the history of the common law. Much of its development took place in the centuries before the Industrial Revolution, an event which brought about dramatic changes to which the common law did not adequately respond. It allowed the shopfloor to develop into a place of horror, where men, women and children were dehumanised. Massive legislation was needed to counter the disaster it made possible.

On 20 June 1919, in a case between the Federated Municipal and Shire Council Employees Union of Australia and the City of Melbourne, two High Court judges, Mr Justice Isaacs and Mr Justice Rich, had the following to say:

The Industrial Revolution for a long time . . . made workman's labour a mere marketable commodity to be bought at the lowest price that individual competition between workers would permit. The degradation and suffering that ensued, the revolt against the system, the repression of illegal acts, the amelioration of the law, the organisation of labour, the gradual recognition of collective bargaining and the introduction of private conciliation and arbitration as well as of industrial laws securing better conditions for workers are all well known historical facts.

The Industrial Revolution raised many legal issues. The common law resolved these in ways highly prejudicial to the interests of workers. It provided actions for conspiracy, inducing breach of contract and intimidation which paid scant regard to any poverty, degradation or danger with which they were faced. It applied doctrines of common employment, volenti and contributory negligence to the great ruin of many injured at work.

Judges of today are captives of their predecessors, who gave a bent to the common law which favours trade and commerce over fair wages and conditions or a healthy environment. What dominated the courts of yesterday were the concepts that contracts were sacrosanct and trade was to be unfettered. They were little moved by concepts that people should receive fair wages or work reasonable hours or in decent conditions. They were influenced even less by concepts that the environment should be heeded or native animals preserved. The law dealt with issues arising from the making of contracts and the plying of trade well before it did so with those from the development of modern industry and the massive exploitation of the physical world.

Recently a Melbourne judge, in dealing with the issue of scallop dredging in Port Phillip Bay, gave great emphasis to the economic benefits that would arise from that activity were it allowed in the way pressed for by the industry. From media reports he gave scant weight, if any, to the effect dredging might have on the bay environment. In doing this he was acting in the tradition set by his predecessors.

Legislators have moved again and again to remedy the shortcomings of the common law. They have countered the harsh effect of the doctrines of common employment and contributory negligence. They have made laws for safety in the workplace. They have introduced compensation schemes for people injured while employed. Outside Australia they have given a right to strike. They have moved to protect the environment. They have looked to the protection of native animals.

In 1974 the Whitlam Government enacted the Trade Practices Act. Its purpose was to ensure fair commercial activity and to protect consumers. It has achieved much in both areas. On 3 May 1977 Mr John Howard, then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in the Fraser Government, introduced amendments to the Act. Two of the amendments, sections 45d and 45e, brought a new and unhappy dimension into the legislation. They went beyond setting out how trading companies were to conduct themselves in the marketplace and proscribed actions workers might want to take for better conditions or conservationists for a healthier environment. The use of sections 45d and 45e in industrial disputes is well established. Mudginberri is the most famous example. But it is only this year that the Trade Practices Act has been deployed against conservationists. BHP Petroleum Ltd recently sued Greenpeace pursuant to the provisions of section 45d following actions by it against the company's seismic testing ship Western Odyssey in waters off Warrnambool in Victoria.

The Australian community cannot survive without trade and industry. They must be properly protected, but they are not the sole foundation for a fair, healthy and cultured society. It also requires that there be fair working conditions and a sound environment. People need the ability to see to it that these are achieved. There are laws which enable people to pursue better wages and conditions and safety in the workplace. There are laws which enable them to pursue the well-being of the environment. But these are not always enough to achieve the proper outcomes. This is due mainly to the common law and sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act giving ascendancy to the interests of commerce and industry over the welfare of workers and the health of the environment. This can result in there being a dramatic lack of balance in the weight given to each of these matters by courts when deciding cases involving them.

The common law needs reform and the Trade Practices Act amendment to eliminate the bias that they now have against workers, conservationists and their organisations. Were this done, the community generally would benefit. It would be well done if it were done quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to detain the Senate for too long this evening-I know Senator McMullan said that he is hungry-but I should like to say a few words because I believe that it is important that my colleagues, all three of them on the Government side of the House and one on this side of the House, are aware of some tragic events that have happened in Tasmania over the last couple of days.

SPEECH.PARA: Most honourable senators would be aware that Tasmania is in the midst of the nationwide recession which we had to have. Because of our isolation, we tend to suffer these consequences much more seriously than our fellow Australians. It has already been mentioned on several occasions in this chamber-I have mentioned it myself-that Tasmania has the dubious privilege of having the second highest unemployment rate in Australia. At this point we trail Western Australia by only a minor part of one per cent. But in the light of recent events over the last few days I predict that, when the next set of figures is released, we will not see Tasmania second but at the top of the unemployment list. I refer briefly to the absolutely magnificent document, called Small Business in Australia, that David Beddall has produced. I quote from his opening remarks:

For the first time, we have a clear statement from the Commonwealth Government on what it sees as the state of small business in Australia, and the policies needed to enable small business to prosper. For too long this important sector of our economy has been ignored at all levels of government.

You can say that again. I hope the outlook for small business improves and is as bright as some of the photos in this document. I should like to know how much it cost. The fact of the matter is that, because of this Government's policies, yesterday Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd announced the closure of its operation at Port Huon. I am sure that was prompted by some of the polices of the Green movement. That will add 116 workers to my State's dole queue in the Huon Valley-an area which has been devastated by an abnormally high unemployment rate over the last few years. The announcement by APM follows disclosures early this week that the Electrona silicon plant is to close, along with the Ovaltine factory at Spreyton.

It appears that there is not one section of the State which is isolated from this economic catastrophe. Sixty-four jobs are to be lost at Electrona and a further 100 jobs are to be lost at the Ovaltine factory. The people who lose those jobs will join the 200 forest contractors and mill workers who have already been stood down because of an industrial dispute. If that does not clear up in the next few days, I am sure that further jobs will be lost in the forestry industry. On the front page of today's Mercury is a photo of a furnace worker whose job loss at the Pioneer Silicon Industries Pty Ltd smelter is his fifth in five years. That shows the mess that Tasmania is in. The only person cheering about this is a former Australian Democrats candidate in Tasmania, Patsy Harmsen, who spent thousands of dollars on trying to close down the smelter. She has had luck with the help of the State Labor Government and the ex-Treasurer's policies. She has had her day-100-odd jobs have been lost.

To compound the problem, Pasminco Metals-EZ operation at Risdon also announced yesterday that it would not be reopening its ammonia and hydrogen production divisions. The consequence of this is that 27 employees in this area have been placed at risk and Pasminco EZ will be obliged to bring its ammonia from the mainland. This is a tragedy the likes of which Tasmania has not known for many years. In fact, the events of recent days are probably the biggest employment tragedy in Tasmania's history. Over recent months, in addition to what I have mentioned, 90 workers were retrenched at Rosebery's Pasminco mine and Savage River closed for four weeks. Tioxide Australia Pty Ltd near Burnie shed 160 jobs and is destined eventually to close entirely, while the Renison tin mine has had to shed 150 jobs to stay viable.

Individually these events may not seem that big on the national scene, but when compounded they total 907 jobs. Tasmania simply cannot afford to continue to lose jobs at this rate. The State is threatened with closure. Our 10.8 per cent unemployment rate, which transposes to 23,700 individuals, is our highest level since 1984.

I am sad to say that whilst this crisis has been going on, the Premier, Mr Field, and the Federal Labor Government seem to have proven themselves unable to provide a solution. It seems that both State and Federal Labor are locked into a state of inaction. There has been plenty of action up here in the last few days, but certainly not the sort of action we like to see in Tasmania.

I call upon the governments in my own State and here to respond to this disaster in Tasmania. I call upon those who have some power to take action to assist in this matter. It is very easy for us in this place to forget the human nature of unemployment, but I remind the Senate that yesterday 116 workers at Port Huon were obliged to return home to their families and children and say that they no longer had a job, that they no longer would be able to provide for the family at this time. I am sure that they also told their families that the prospects for the future were similarly very bleak.

Finally, once again I call upon the governments to act because I believe the plight of Tasmania is being ignored. The last depression we had in Tasmania was under a previous Labor government, but at least the Labor Premier of the day, the late Albert Ogilvie, had a few brains. He borrowed 60,000 pounds from the Federal Government and he built a road up Mount Wellington. It is there for everybody to see. It is still benefiting tourism in our State. The Premier that we have in Tasmania at the moment seems to be worried only about sacking teachers and running around making statements-nothing is happening. Until we get some positive policies and some action between the State and Federal governments, I am afraid to say that all we are going to see in Tasmania is a graveyard of empty shops and broken businesses.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.01 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Foreign Affairs and Trade: Direct Marketing

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 19 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department considered the effectiveness of direct marketing; if so, please provide details of: (a) the areas in which the department believes direct marketing will be of most use to it; (b) the results it would hope to achieve from direct marketing; and (c) the types of direct marketing methods considered most relevant and effective for the department's purposes, for example, direct mail, telephone canvassing or other forms of direct marketing.

(2) Has the Department separated direct marketing as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms; if so, please provide details of the level of funding spent since 1 July 1990, the anticipated level to 30 June 1991 and the purposes for which the direct marketing will be used; if not, does the department anticipate separating direct marketing as a budget item in its expenditure details; if not, why not.
(3) Does the Department have, or is it in the process of developing, a database from which it can operate its own direct mailing or telephone canvassing projects; if so, please provide details.
(4) Has the department undertaken any direct mailing activities for this financial year; if so, please include details of the subject of the project, timing and to whom it was directed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department does not consider ``direct marketing'', as such, an appropriate or effective means of informing the community about the goals of the department as a whole, or about individual departmental programs. It utilises press releases or statements to the media for disseminating information on specific issues. For matters of interest to specific groups various Branches distribute newsletters or similar publications to individuals or organisations that have expressed interest in receiving that type of material.
(2) No, no and see my previous answer at (1) above.

(4) My department does prepare and distribute a number of publications that provide information on Australia's foreign relations. These publications include ``Backgrounder'' and ``The Monthly Record''. They do not, in my opinion, constitute a form of ``direct marketing''.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department considered the effectiveness of direct marketing; if so, please provide details of: (a) the areas in which the department believes direct marketing will be of most use to it; (b) the results it would hope to achieve from direct marketing; and (c) the types of direct marketing methods considered most relevant and effective for the department's purposes, for example, direct mail, telephone canvassing or other forms of direct marketing.

(2) Has the department separated direct marketing as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms; if so, please provide details of the level of funds spent since 1 July 1990, the anticipated level to 30 June 1991 and the purposes for which the direct marketing will be used; if not, does the department anticipate separating direct marketing as a budget item in its expenditure details; if not, why not.
(3) Does the department have, or is it in the process of developing, a database from which it can operate its own direct mailing or telephone canvassing projects; if so, please provide details.
(4) Has the department undertaken any direct mailing activities for this financial year; if so, please include details of the subject of the project, timing and to whom it was directed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Department operates mainly on the basis of providing information directly to clients through its offices and staff. This involves direct contact with large numbers of people across many benefit categories. Offices make available a large range of information products to ensure that clients are fully aware of their entitlements. This includes providing information in a variety of languages. In addition to this direct contact approach, some client groups are targeted for the provision of particular information. For example, ``Age Pension News'' is very effective in providing information about Social Security entitlements and changes to age and service pensioners.

(b) The Department uses direct marketing to ensure that information is provided to those who should be aware of it. For example, details about changes in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme were sent to all pensioners. This method of marketing has proved to be effective in distributing detailed information to specific clients.
(c) Apart from direct public contact by staff, the direct marketing methods considered most effective for my Department's purposes include:
* direct mailing of correspondence and other information material such as ``Age Pension News'' and inserts; and

* mailbox drops which can be used as part of publicity campaigns targeted at the general public, for example, for child disability allowance where the target audience is not readily identifiable through departmental or other records.

Telephone canvassing is not used currently by the Department because of possible privacy implications. A more effective and less intrusive mechanism has been to encourage clients and the general public to phone the Department's telephone information services, including the Multi-lingual Telephone Information Service for people who have difficulty understanding English. Direct marketing, such as inserts sent to clients with regular advice letters, has been used to promote these services.

(2) No. The Department has not separated direct marketing as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms. It does not anticipate doing so as direct marketing is integrated within the whole of the Department's operations. Only large separate expenditure items are identified. The Department's largest direct marketing exercise, ``Age Pension News'', is currently recorded under ``Printing''.

(3) The Department maintains a database of all clients for purposes of making payments under the Social Security Act from which it could operate direct mailing projects based on predetermined client characteristics with full protection of privacy of clients.
(4) The Department has completed the following direct mailing projects since 1 July 1990:

* ``Age Pension News'' is a newspaper designed to keep age and service pensioners up to date with issues that affect them. Editions were issued in July, September and December 1990 and February and May 1991.
This publication has a circulation of 1.4 million which includes age and service pensioners and community and business organisations which have asked to be placed on the mailing list;

* A Family Allowance Supplement guide for tax professionals was sent in September 1990 to all tax professionals;

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to a recent report about North Korea's suspected military strength possibly including nuclear weapons, and the fact that that country has the fifth largest army in the world, could this intelligence be a further threat to stability in the region.

(2) Does the United Nations have the right to inspect countries who signed the Non-proliferation Treaty in 1985 to ensure they have not violated that document; if so, what is the latest information regarding nuclear weapons in both South and North Korea.
(3) What efforts, if any, are being made to forge peace between South and North Korea.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Any serious challenge to the security and stability of Northeast Asia would have a major impact in the wider Asia-Pacific area and in the world as a whole. The Korean Peninsula has for long been a serious potential flashpoint, because of its division and the engagement there of the interests of four major powers (the United States, the USSR, China and Japan). It is true that the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) maintains a large military capability in terms of both personnel and military hardware. While the armed forces of the Republic of Korea (ROK) are smaller, they are technologically superior and military deterrence is strengthened by the ROK's security relationship with the United States. Moreover, all the major powers with strategic interests in the Korean Peninsula have a strong interest in avoiding increased tensions and possible conflict there. Nuclear proliferation in the Peninsula would, however, be seriously destabilising.

(2) Under Article III of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT), each non-nuclear-weapon State Party undertakes to conclude an agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) for the application of safeguards by the Agency on all of its present and future nuclear activities, in order to verify that its obligation not to develop or otherwise acquire nuclear weapons is being met. The IAEA is an autonomous intergovernmental organisation of the United Nations. IAEA safeguards inspections are conducted on the territory of the state concerned.

The DPRK adhered to the NPT in 1985. It has so far failed to conclude its obligatory safeguards agreement with the IAEA, due by mid-1987, despite persistent representations by Australia and other countries, both bilaterally and through multilateral action. Therefore, no inspection procedures have been agreed between the DPRK and the IAEA pursuant to that country's NPT obligations. IAEA safeguards inspectors conduct inspections on certain nuclear facilities under safeguards agreements concluded by the DPRK prior to its accession to the NPT, but the DPRK continues to undertake some nuclear activities not covered by IAEA safeguards.

The ROK adhered to the NPT and concluded its safeguards agreement with the IAEA in 1975, so that the IAEA regularly inspects all nuclear material there. The ROK has strictly abided by its obligations not to develop or otherwise acquire nuclear weapons or other explosive devices. In accordance with its long-standing policy, the United States neither confirms nor denies that it has nuclear weapons stationed in the ROK.

There have been persistent reports that the DPRK is developing a capability to produce nuclear weapons. Australia and other countries are deeply concerned about the regional security implications of such a move and the obstacle it would pose to the improvement of relations on the Korean Peninsula. They have urged the DPRK to fulfil its NPT safeguards obligations without further delay in order to dispel suspicions that it is developing a nuclear weapons capability. This position was reinforced in May 1991 in the resolution on the elimination of weapons of mass destruction which was adopted at the meeting of the Inter-Parliamentary Union in Pyongyang.

(3) The two Koreas have remained in a state of armed truce since the end of the Korean War in 1953. Three rounds of North-South talks at Prime Ministerial level were held in late 1990. While there has been no specific outcome, the talks were an initial step towards a less confrontational relationship between North and South. The dialogue was suspended by the North in February 1991 following the start of the annual ` `Team Spirit'' military exercises between the ROK and the United States. No date for its resumption has yet been agreed. Some little progress has been made in other areas, especially sports contacts.

Recent changes in the external situations of the ROK and DPRK may also help to lessen tensions on the Peninsula. The ROK has established diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and exchanged trade offices with China. The DPRK's links with the former Warsaw Pact countries have been weakened, but it has been negotiating with Japan on the normalisation of relations and has had contacts with the United States. Australia also favours efforts to draw the DPRK out of its isolation, but progress will be impeded as long as there is uncertainty about the DPRK's nuclear intentions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights opened by the United Nations for signature in New York on 19 December 1966:
(1) When did Australia sign the Protocol.
(2) Has Australia ratified or declared its accession to the Protocol; if so, when; if not, why not, and does Australia intend to ratify the Protocol.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia has not signed the Protocol.

(2) Australia has not yet ratified or acceded to the Protocol. The Government has not yet made a decision on the question of accession to the Protocol, but is currently considering the question and in particular the practical aspects of implementing the obligations which accession would involve. Once these issues are resolved, early action will be taken towards becoming a Party to the instrument.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 8 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government support the candidature of Indonesia's Manpower Minister, Cosmas Batubara, to be head of the International Labour Conference (ILC), the major decisionmaking body of the International Labour Organisation.
(2) Is the Government aware that Setia Kawan (Solidarity), the only free trade union in Indonesia, has condemned this bid by Cosmas Batubara for the position.

(3) Is the Government aware of the fact that the Indonesian Government violates Solidarity's constitutional guarantee to freedom of association and recognises only one officially based union, which it effectively controls, while refusing to recognise Solidarity.

(4) Is the Government aware of the fact that the Indonesian authorities refused permission for Solidarity's President, Johannes Princen, to attend the annual conference of the International NonGovernmental Group on Indonesia which met in Washington at the beginning of May 1991.
(5) On what grounds does the Government support Cosmas Batubara's candidature for the position of head of the ILC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Government is aware that Setia Kawan has condemned this bid by Drs Cosmas Batubara. This happened after we announced our support for Drs Batubara in late March. Setia Kawan's opposition to Drs Batubara's candidature to head the International Labour Conference was expressed by its Chairman, HJC Princen, in an interview with an AAP correspondent in Jakarta on 1 May 1991.

(3) The legal position of Setia Kawan is uncertain. Under Indonesian law Setia Kawan is required to register its existence with the Department of Home Affairs. While the Department has not yet accepted registration of Setia Kawan, it has also not formally outlawed it and Setia Kawan continues to operate. According to HJC Princen, Setia Kawan now has 30,000 signed up members. The only registered trade union in Indonesia is the All Indonesia Workers' Union (SPSI) which works in close cooperation with the Government.

(4) The Government is aware that HJC Princen's passport was withdrawn in 1985 and he has since been on a list of persons not allowed to travel overseas. The Government notes, however, that the Secretary General of Setia Kawan, Saut Aritonang, attended the International Non-Governmental Group meeting on Indonesia (INGI) in Washington on 29 April-1 May 1991 and attended an International Trade Union Conference in Perth in late May 1991.

(5) Each year the Presidency of the International Labour Conference rotates between the four regional geographical groups of the International Labour Organisation. In 1991 it is the turn of the Asia-Pacific Group to provide the President. Indonesia has not previously held the position of President, and within the Asia-Pacific Group, of which Australia is a member, very considerable support emerged for Indonesia's candidacy. Australia therefore supported the candidature of the Indonesian Minister of Manpower for the position.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What restrictions, if any, apply to the use of the Department of Social Security (DSS) database.
(2) Are there any restrictions on the use of the mailing list which is used for the distribution of Age Pension News; if so, what are they.
(3) To what extent would it be possible for the DSS database to be made available to the Minister or persons, parties or organisations outside DSS.
(4) Has the Government made available any information from its database or mailing list to the Minister or any persons, parties or organisations since the last election; if so, in what circumstances.
(5) Will the Government give an assurance that any information contained on the DSS database will not be made available to any person outside DSS.
(6) Has the DSS database been used in the past to conduct mailings: (a) for Age Pension News; or (b) other than for Age Pension News; if so, on what occasions.
(7) Do Privacy Commission guidelines condone use of persons' names in this manner.
(8) Have any such mailings complied with all guidelines published by the Privacy Commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The use of data held by the Department of Social Security is governed by Information Privacy Principle 10 in the Privacy Act. (Disclosure of information outside the Department is governed by Section 19 of the Social Security Act, section 70 of the Crimes Act and regulation 35 of the Public Service Regulations).

(2) Yes. The mailing list is contained on a computer systems magnetic tape file. DSS staff accompany the magnetic tapes from the Department's computer centre to mailing houses for the production of ink-jet address envelopes. Once the magnetic tapes have been used, DSS staff ensure immediate return to the computer centre.

The mailing houses are highly secure and are subject to strict privacy conditions, similar to those that apply to Commonwealth Public Servants. Any duplication and further use of information on the tapes would be in contravention of those privacy conditions and would also compromise their integrity as a mailing house.

(3) Data held by DSS can be disclosed to the Minister or any person outside the Department only in accordance with the provisions of section 19 of the Social Security Act or as otherwise required under law.

(4) The Department has not provided any mailing list to the Minister or any other person, party or organisation. Some information from the data base may be used in preparing replies to Ministerial correspondence. In these circumstances the use of such information is regarded as being authorised by the correspondent. It is used only in responses to the individual clients who are the subject of the correspondence.

Although information from the data base with all identifying personal details removed can be made available for research purposes, this is done only in accordance with section 19 of the Social Security Act and the Privacy Principles. Such data never include client identifiers such as names, addresses or pension numbers. It is strictly demographic information from which it is not possible to identify individuals.
Information on individual cases and bulk information may be disclosed where it is lawful to do so under the applicable legislation. See (1) above.
(6) (b) DSS data bases have been used to:
- write to clients about individual eligibility and entitlement;
- advise in general terms of changes to DSS programs (eg FAS, deeming);
- advise in general terms of concessions offered to pensioners and beneficiaries by other agencies;
- ask clients to provide information on a voluntary basis for research purposes.

(7) If a letter signed by the Minister is sent to clients the mailing is done by the Department usually with the assistance of a mailing house. See (2) above. The Minister does not have access to the mailing list. The Privacy Commissioner has not published any guidelines relating to this matter. Use of information by DSS is in accordance with Information Privacy Principle 10 in the Privacy Act.
